descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar is designed for the general campus student. Students with a music major, or a dual degree with music, are not permitted to register for this seminar. The course is designed to provide opportunities for music aficionados to experience music and music theater events from the inside-out. The only prerequisite for the course is a love of the performing arts - you don't have to read, perform, or understand music notation to succeed. However, you have to be prepared to spend a lot of time attending rehearsals and concerts (minimally six to eight hours a week), outside of the two required class sessions. During and outside of classroom sessions, the instructor and invited guests will attempt to nurture a heightened awareness of the challenges that conductors, opera and music theater directors and musicians/actors face when preparing for a performance. Through a series of observations, presentations, interviews, and interactive discussions/seminars, you will be better prepared to listen, observe, and critically analyze performing arts events on and off campus - during this academic quarter, and hopefully for the rest of your life. After Week One's introduction to the course and the music library, the Week Two class sessions will concentrate on conducting lessons and video observations of concerts and rehearsals. In these initial sessions, you will learn many of the techniques needed to lead the world's greatest instrumental and choral ensembles (of course, with many additional years of practice). Course participants, using their required conductor's baton and music CDs will learn a variety of conducting techniques - mastering beat patterns, the expressive use of the left hand, and using the conducting gesture to communicate interpretation, phrasing, dynamic shading. You may never conduct a major ensemble, but after meeting the requirements of the class you should have the knowledge and understanding to critically analyze conductors during your future career as a member of audiences for classical and popular music concerts.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course aims to provide students with the critical tools necessary to discuss and write about music originating in a variety of sociocultural and historical contexts, including those considered inside the Western European "classical" canon as well as those from other traditions. After introductory sessions covering fundamental concepts in order to facilitate musical study, we will move on to bring music into conversation with a diverse range of topics, including but not restricted to gender, ethnicity, spirituality, national identity, film, dance, and technology. Students may expect regular reading assignments (from the textbook as well as from supplementary materials provided by the instructor), weekly written responses to readings and/or listening examples, a mid-term, one essay/project, and a final exam. No prior musical training is required to take this course?all students are welcome.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Steven Cornelius and Mary Natvig, Music: A Social Experience, 2nd edition. Routledge, 2018. ISBN: 978-0415789332. Print, new: $160.00, hardcover (Amazon).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will present an overview of Western Art Music across several centuries and up to the present, with a focus on symphonic, chamber music, opera, and solo repertoire for piano and other instruments. Students will be guided from a historical perspective to develop listening skills and knowledge of musical terminology, in order to be able to relate to music in a more specific and refined way. Classes will involve discussions of assigned readings and music, listening activities, discussions, one concert report, quizzes, and short presentations.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Kristine Forney, Andrew Dell'Antonio, and Joseph Machlis, The Enjoyment of Music, Essential Listening Edition, 3rd edition. (W.W. Norton, 2016). ISBN: 978-0-393-60251-7. Print, new: $64.99 (Amazon)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This introductory course will study Western art music ("classical music") through specific repertoire throughout music history focused on three overarching topics: opera, orchestral music, and chamber music. This class requires no prior musical training; all students are welcome regardless of their musical experience. This course will provide students the terminology, tools, and ideas to discuss and engage with music at a critical level. Students are expected to: complete readings and listening assignments before class meetings; engage and participate during class lectures; attend concerts (free admissions for on campus concerts will be available); submit written assignments; and prepare for quizzes and exams.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Kristine Forney, Andrew Dell'Antonio, and Joseph Machlis, The Enjoyment of Music, Essential Listening Edition, 3rd edition. (W.W. Norton, 2016). ISBN: 978-0-393-60251-7. Print, new: $64.99 (Amazon)

name: Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Song: words sung to music, especially to express ideas and emotions. This course will tell a history of song through examples spanning from antiquity to today's Top 40. Students will learn how to analyze, discuss, and think historically about song as a genre of music, a partner to poetry, a vocal performance, and a human practice.

This course will include units on ancient Greek and Judeo-Christian biblical ideas of song; Medieval and Renaissance secular and sacred song; European art song and song cycles; spirituals and work songs; the birth of the music recording industry; protest and folk songs; and music videos and contemporary mass media. Each unit will also ask students to think cross-historically, comparing songs between centuries.

Weekly writing assignments will ask students to reflect on assigned materials; the midterm and final will also be written projects. Class time will be spent discussing assigned readings and recordings, listening as a group, and practicing oral and written description skills. This class is open to all students; no prior musical training is required.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No materials required for purchase. Assigned readings will be available as PDFs on CANVAS.

name: Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce students to and offer them an in-depth look at the history of one of America's most iconic art forms: jazz. Through readings, attentive listening to recordings and videos, live concert attendance, written assignments, and discussions of social conditions surrounding important events in jazz history, this course will guide students through the evolution of jazz styles and trends along with the contextual circumstances that influenced the music's development. Students will become familiar with the basic structures and styles of jazz as well as many of the important artists of the genre. Students will develop their critical listening skills and their ability to communicate critical thinking about jazz.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Ted Gioia, The History of Jazz, 2nd edition. Oxford University Press, 2011. ISBN: 9780195399707. Print, new: $13.81, paperback (Amazon). Print, new: $17.96 paperback, $40.00 hardcover (Barnes & Noble)

name: Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides an introduction to the broad diversity of music arising from American folk traditions. The course will approach music from perspectives that are both historical/contextual (spirituals, work songs, protest songs, cowboy songs, etc.) and regional (Appalachia, Cajun, Western Plains, etc.), and will include a philosophical and experiential look at participatory music. Assignments include weekly written reading responses, a longer essay, midterm and final exams, and a final project that may include an optional fieldwork component. The class is open to students with all levels of musical experience.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Kip Lornell, Exploring American Folk Music: Ethnic, Grassroots, and Regional Traditions in the United States. University Press of Mississippi, 2012. ISBN: 9781617032646. Print, new $30.00 paperback, $52.96 hardcover (Amazon). Print, new: $ 30.00, paperback (Barnes & Noble)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This core course will focus on what it means or meant to be a musician in different times in history and in different places around the world. It will explore different types of musical performances, such as distinctions between presentational and participatory scenarios, and present a diverse and inclusive set of case studies about specific performers, performances, and performance spaces. Goals of individual case studies include interrogating the cultural factors that shaped a performer's career and output, how performance modifies the reception and history of the musical work, and other factors such as space, place, culture, and media. Material will be drawn from classical, popular, western, global, folk, or any type of music from the recent or distant past, and may change by quarter and instructor, yet will engage contrasting musical experiences for the contemporary students who will need to navigate among forms, styles, and publics in their careers. Examples of topics for individual case studies of performers might include musicians such as Bessie Smith as a blues singer; Fritz Kreisler as a violin virtuoso; Madonna as a pop icon in the 80s; Wanda Landowska as a pioneer of the early music revival; Leonard Bernstein as a conductor and crossover composer; Andrés Segovia as the creator of the modern classical guitar tradition; Leontyne Price as a soprano; or Ravi Shankar as a performer of South Asian classical music in the west. Other case studies may consider how musical works such as Handel's Messiah or albums by the Beatles might exist in different versions for different markets on account of performance traditions. By these means, music students will gain introductory literacy in diverse types of music and performance practices, learn about the legacies of specific musicians (some of whom faced career obstacles), and better understand intersections between creativity and commerce in diverse contexts, all grounded by the idea of performance. Among individual projects may be an investigation of the history of performance in each student's specific major.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Course objectives:
-Learn about diverse musicians, their legacies, and the circumstances of their performances in varied global contexts
-Conceive of music history through the lens of performers rather than through the composer or the work
-Develop a sense of how the concept of work differs from the concept of performance, and engage, where applicable, with notions of performance practices
-Develop music research skills and verbal communication skills about music
-Historicize and locate yourself within a complex world of musicians

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No required textbook purchases. Students will be expected to attend live performances of their choice, some of which may require purchase of admission tickets.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to the resources and methods of music research and writing. It covers skills and ideas that can be applied and built upon in other courses, as well as throughout a career in music.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students in Master of Music degree program

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- A familiarity with core music research tools and an awareness of various types of print and online resources that are available
- The ability to identify pertinent books, articles, scores, recordings, and other materials and to obtain items held locally, available online, and from other libraries
- Comprehension of principles and guidelines for documenting sources according to proper citation style
- A grasp of fundamental strategies for thinking critically and writing effectively about music

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureReadingsClass participationResearch projectGuest speakersWriting assignmentsDiscussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Class participation: 5%
Papers: 60%
Research project: 35%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Textbook:
Laurie J. Sampsel. Music Research: A Handbook. 3rd ed. New York: Oxford University Press, 2019. ISBN 9780190644505, Print, new: $69.95

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The term ?popular music' is as mysterious as it is common. Should we define it according to stylistic hallmarks? Should we define it in terms of audience demographics? Or of the goals of its creators? In this seminar, we will explore these questions on the basis of challenging, borderline cases. We will begin by studying contemporary pop music in the United States, continue with my own research into the popular music of eighteenth-century Germany, and conclude with presentations by seminar participants, each of whom will develop a project that explores the questions posed above from a unique perspective.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBD

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Music and the Visual Arts

This course will consider some of the many ways in which the senses of sight and hearing interact in Western images and music-making, in select musical works inspired by concurrent ideas in the visual arts, and in some of the many forms of multi-media and performance art. We will concentrate primarily on works from the seventeenth century to the present. Each student will have ample opportunity to pursue personal interests, and to share information and ideas with the class.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All assigned reading material will be put on reserve in the Library, as well as select books being available for purchase at the Norris Center Bookstore.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course focuses on ideas of "authenticity" in music from the mid-twentieth century to the present, principally through performance practices of historical art-music (especially from the eighteenth century) and local popular music traditions (particularly rural American or "country" music). We will think about meanings of "authenticity" in music against a background of twentieth- and twenty-first century cultural and philosophical considerations of the idea, as scholars, auditors, performers, and consumers of music and music-related products. We will also think about the tensions between historical and cultural musical customs and current performance practices, as well as ways in which popular films use music to suggest various kinds of authenticities, the nostalgic, and the familiar.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore the unique place of George Gershwin (1898-1937) in American musical culture. We will undertake a close study of his work in multiple genres: popular songs; Broadway shows such as Lady, Be Good! (1924) and Of Thee I Sing (1931); concert works including Rhapsody in Blue (1924) and An American in Paris (1928); and the "American folk opera" Porgy and Bess (1935), among other works. We will analyze Gershwin's music as a hybrid of classical and popular traditions, tracing his debts to sources including African American culture and European modernism. We will also examine his posthumous legacy, including the controversies that have surrounded Porgy and Bess from its origins, through its 2012 Broadway revival, to its new production this season at the Metropolitan Opera, which we will have the opportunity to see via the Met's "Live in HD" transmission to movie theaters in February.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
By the late 18th century, the field opera in Paris had been largely conquered by non-French composers such as Gluck, Piccinni, Sacchini, Salieri, and Cherubini. This foreign "occupation" continues well into the 19th century, but by the second half of that century begins to yield to a vigorous new school of French composers who created a series of extraordinarily successful works. Some of these (Bizet's Carmen) are still popular today, others have faded somewhat (Gounod's Faust, Massenet's Manon), and still others have virtually vanished from the repertoire (Mignon by Ambroise Thomas, Lakmé by Leo Delibes). Amid these shifting sands, the tradition of grand opera as embodied in the works of Halévy and Meyerbeer have undergone a strong reassessment, while at the opposite end, the operettas of Offenbach carry on in an absurd, satirical, and delightful world of their own. In this course, we will explore a selection of these works against the background of French history from Napoleon to the end of the 19th century. Along the way we will examine the work of important librettists (Eugène Scribe, Jules Barbier, Henri Meilhac, Ludovic Halévy) and the literary and theatrical works which served as a basis for operatic plots.

Evaluation will be based on three written assignments (25 points each), a final take-home examination (20 points), and class participation (5 points); your contributions to class discussion should be based on a thorough assimilation of the reading, listening, and viewings you'll be given along the way, in addition to whatever original insights you're prepared to share). There is no midterm in this course. Graduate students have the option to undertake a research project (also 20 points) in lieu of the final exam; those who elect to do so are required to obtain the instructor's approval of topic no later than Week 5. This research paper is due on or before the date set aside for the Final Examination.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will review the history of western art music with an overall aim of providing useful skills for the graduate careers and working lives of professional musicians. Beyond the goal of identifying and addressing students' areas of weakness in preparation for music-history comprehensive exams, our special focus will be the acquisition of pedagogy skills for the college-level teaching of music history, and most of the quarter's assignments (teaching demos, sample syllabi, etc.) will be designed to enhance students' experience in this area.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Richard Taruskin and Christopher Gibbs, The Oxford History of Western Music, College Edition, 2nd edition. (Oxford University Press, 2018) ISBN: 9780190600228 Print, new: $109.56 (Amazon, paperback)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This seminar will introduce students to recent interventions into critical theory made by musicologists (broadly identified). We will investigate the possibilities of doing critical theory through sustained reflection on musical performance. We will focus on one book a week and will put music into dialog with many forms of critical thought: the ineffable, post-colonial theory, Afropessimism, critical race theory, psychoanalysis, deconstruction, and more.

We will read the following: Ana-Maria Ochoa's Aurality, Nina Eidshiem's The Race of Sound, Brigid Cohen's Stefan Wolpe and the Avant-Garde Diaspora, Fumi Okiji's Jazz as Critique, James Currie's Music and the Politics of Negation, Seth Brodsky's From 1989, Brian Kane's Sound Unseen, Gavin Steingo's
Kwaito's Promise and Mike Gallope's Deep Refrains

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All books will be on reserve or provided electronically, though I encourage you to purchase as many of the required texts as is possible.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This graduate-level seminar is intended to introduce students to a wide variety of issues in Western music intersecting with Jewish themes, representations, characters, and musicians. The principal expectation for all students is the submission of a final research paper between 15 and 20 pp. in length exclusive of title page and bibliography, double-spaced, in Chicago style. This project will be worth 50% of the final grade. Some time during the last two sessions, each student will also give a 15-20 minute presentation on the research project which will lead to the final paper; it is expected that the ensuing discussion and feedback will be incorporated into the final written project. In addition, each student will lead class discussion on two occasions (each discussion worth 20% of the final grade, while others chime in as inspired) on a topic to be agreed upon in consultation of the instructor. A final 10% of your grade will be based on your contributions to class discussions which you aren't leading.

Music and the Visual Arts

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The music of J. S. Bach has been studied intensively since the composer's death in 1750. For much of that time it was regarded in a kind of heavenly isolation. In recent decades, however, scholars have sought to situate the composer and his work in its historical circumstances, regarding Bach not as an unearthly genius but rather as an extremely talented product of his particular time and place. And yet the lost world that scholars have conjured is incomplete. If we are to truly know the environment Bach inhabited, we need to know not only about his music but also much more about the music of other composers and the musical lives of ordinary people. This course offers students the opportunity to study the musical culture of Bach's world from the perspectives of those who lived in it. The protagonists we will examine were fellow composers, amateur and professional performers, patrons, instrument builders, and audience members. We will treat them not as extras in the grand sweep of music history but rather as main characters, stars in their own private dramas. By learning more about what these people ate, what they wore, what they aspired to become, what they feared, and how they interacted with one another, we can better understand how J. S. Bach and his music figured in their lives.

The pedagogy learned in this course will relate to teaching school-aged children in brass. This will be accomplished through peer teaching.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this course is to stimulate your thinking concerning your role as a music educator, as well as the role of music in the greater educational enterprise. In this course you will explore some of the philosophical principles, concepts, and ideas that provide music education with purpose and direction. Grappling with these ideas will improve your knowledge and understanding of the things you do as a music educator, and will help you articulate the importance of music in schools. In Winter 2020, this course will feature five leading philosophy scholars from across the United States for guest residencies.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: This course is intended for Music Education Majors or PERMISSION OF INSTRUCTOR.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This course is designed to enable you to: *communicate your philosophy of music education in clear writing and oral discourse *demonstrate knowledge and understanding of various philosophical positions in and related to music education through speech and writing *develop an increased understanding of the ways philosophy can inform practice *demonstrate an understanding of the issues, challenges, and potentials of music education through writings, presentations, and discussions.

Allsup. R. (2016). Remixing the classroom: Toward an open philosophy of music education. Bloomington, IN. Indiana University Press. ISBN-10: 0253021421; ISBN-13: 978-0253021427 ($20.77)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The main objective of this course is to prepare students with the skills and methods necessary for eventual teaching in a public school orchestra program. Students will acquire a general knowledge of school orchestra programs and the specific knowledge and skills in preparation for public school teaching by observing and rehearsing instrumental ensembles in authentic school settings. Students will interact with exemplary music educators in the field, develop a bibliography of professional resources and repertoire, and attain a vocabulary of effective ensemble teaching strategies.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Because this quarter focuses on string instrumental education, students are expected to have completed at least one quarter of MUSIC_ED 237 (Strings Class).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This hands-on course is designed as an investigation of the middle school choral program and its participants. It will provide you with an overview of the multifaceted nature of choral teaching and learning, as well as serve as a foundation for the construction of your own beliefs and practices as a teacher. Students will experience application of their studies through the practicum placement which shall be determined at the beginning of the class term. In addition to your practicum; readings, assignments and classwork will provide you with practical tools to ensure that what you do on and off the podium reflects best practices to develop an outstanding, thriving choral program applicable at any educational level.

This class will also integrate edTPA responsibilities relating to Illinois State Teacher Certification Requirements.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this course is to familiarize students with methods for the collection, analysis and reporting of quantitative information. The course will cover basic concepts in statistics including operationally defining variables, coding quantitative data, reliability and validity of measurement, parametric and non-parametric analyses, and quantitative research designs.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the concepts associated with gender diversity and provide concrete connections to music education practice across a variety of music teaching and learning contexts. Through reading and discussion, we will explore the construct of gender identity, vocabulary related to gender diversity, the make-up and particular needs of the transgender community, and legislation related to gender and gender diversity in this country. We will also examine more specifically the issue of gender diversity in the context of education, anti-discrimination legislation related to gender and gender identity in educational settings, and the legal and ethical considerations for teachers working with transgender and gender non-conforming youth and young adults. Implications for the field will center on gender expansive practices that promote a social justice orientation and gender inclusivity in all aspects of music education

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class serves as an introduction to composition as both the process and the product of an artist's practice. We will explore aesthetics and style; form, content, and the elements of sound; improvisation, performance, and experimentation; and notation along with other forms of documentation. The class is open to students of all musical backgrounds, with no prior compositional experience required; an open mind and an adventurous attitude are the only prerequisites. However, it is also important that all students are willing and able to present their compositional projects by playing an instrument (no virtuosity required), singing, body percussion, and/or by using DAW's (digital audio workstation proficiency), recording applications or other technologies. In addition to lectures on compositional approaches and techniques, guided listening, and presentations by guest composers, we will learn through classroom composition activities including improvisation, sketching, recording and a lot of collaboration. The final project is a short composition, building upon the student's work already presented in the class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is a stylistically inclusive study of 21st century saxophone repertoire and practice, focusing on both innovative players and composers from the recent past (who have been catalysts for establishing present-day saxophone techniques and functions), as well as performers and composers who are currently active. In addition to examining solo, chamber, large-ensemble and orchestral works, we will discuss topics including the mechanical design of the instrument in tandem with issues of acoustic and physiological properties.
The course will be taught in a seminar/workshop style designed to allow collaborative interaction between the performer and composer participants.

Topics covered include basic acoustics, MIDI, synthesis and sampling, digital audio theory, and various other software functions. The course will culminate in the creation of an original work utilizing the techniques and aesthetic principles learned throughout the quarter.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Music and Mind

An introduction to music cognition for undergraduates in music and other students with limited background in music. Readings primarily from secondary sources with some primary sources as well.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No prerequisites. The class does deal with technical material from both music (theory) and psychology and so will provide challenges to students with less background in those disciplines.

descriptions.value: Evaluation is based on daily homework, a final project, and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Ashley, R., and Timmers, R. (eds) The Routledge Companion to Music Cognition. Ebook version, available in ePub ($27.48-$37.58, including rental, from Routledge at https://www.routledge.com/The-Routledge-Companion-to-Music-Cognition-1st-Edition/Ashley-Timmers/p/book/9781138721050# ), Kindle (from Amazon, $48.49), and Nook (from Barnes & Noble, $48.49).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course examines phrase-construction and punctuation in the musical forms of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. Students acquire familiarity with
- 1) a typology of phrases (sentences, periods, and their hybrids)
- 2) their normative usage within large-scale formal settings, such as (rounded) binary, ternary, compound ternary, rondo, sonata, and concerto forms,
- 3) a typology of sonata-form types.
The focus will often be on Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven's skillful use of these conventional formal structures to engage creatively with listeners' expectations.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Oliver Messiaen (1908-92) and Witold Lutos?awski (1913-94) belong to the greatest composers of the 20th century. In their creative exploration of musical material both of them moved beyond the confines of tonality and into an unrestricted use of the twelve tones of the chromatic scale, but both steered clear of the twelve-tone technique of the Second Viennese School (Schoenberg, Berg, Webern) and from its ramifications in the serial technique of the post-war avantgarde. Instead, they absorbed the influence of the post-tonal tradition represented by Stravinsky, Ravel, Debussy, and Bartók, and developed their own compositional techniques which match?or surpass?those of serialism in terms of rigorous calibration of pitch, texture and rhythm, yet take into account the cognitive and perceptual limitations of human performers and listeners. Articulate speakers and writers, Messiaen and Lutos?awski were the first theorists of their own music and laid out the main principles of their respective musical languages in several lectures and publications. In this class we will learn these principles and use them to analyze some of their most celebrated works. In the course of the quarter we will retrace the chronological development of their personal styles, examine consecutive stages of their oeuvre, and become acquainted with various facets of their aesthetics. Assessment will be based on two listening tests and two analytical essays demonstrating your understanding of the compositional techniques you will have learned in class.

By the end of the class the students will become familiar with a fair number of compositions by Messiaen and Lutos?awski. They will be expected to have understood the main principles of compositional techniques developed by these composers and learned how to apply them in analysis of individual works.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the class the students will become familiar with a fair number of compositions by Messiaen and Lutos?awski. They will be expected to have understood the main principles of compositional techniques developed by these composers and learned how to apply them in analysis of individual works.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Lecture: Two 80-minute lectures weekly
Independent study: Readings will include preliminary analyses of musical examples to be discussed in class.
ReadingsClass participationCase studies: In-class analysis of selected pieces
Writing assignmentsListening exercisesPresentationsDemonstrationsDiscussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Paper, final: 30%
Quizzes: 2, 20% each
Paper, mid-term: 30%

descriptions.value: No textbooks required.

descriptions.value:
Suggested Class Materials:
Paul Griffiths, Olivier Messiaen and the Music of Time. London: Faber, 1985.
Tadeusz Kaczynski, Conversations with Witold Lutoslawski. London: Chester, 1995.
Olivier Messiaen, The Technique of my Musical Language. Paris: Leduc, 1956.
Charles Bodman Rae, The Music of Lutoslawski. London: Faber, 1994.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An investigation of J. S. Bach's Cantatas from a range of perspectives, including music analysis, musicology, and theology. A particular focus will be on the intended meaning of the works in their original contexts, and the implications of these meanings for listening and performance today.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will provide an introduction to the theory and analysis of post-tonal music. Theoretically, the course will focus on pitch-class set theory, the use of referential collections such as octatonic and whole-tone scales, and twelve-tone theory. Analytically, it will address the music of Schoenberg, Berg, Webern, Bartók, Stravinsky, and other twentieth-century composers. Students will develop proficiency in applying these theories and in making sense of post-tonal works.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisites:
For undergraduates, successful completion of the theory core (Mus_Thry 111/211); for graduate students, passage of the diagnostic or successful completion of the theory review course.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required text:
Joseph Straus, Introduction to Post-Tonal Music, 4th ed. ISBN: 978-0-393-93883-8.
(It is necessary to have the 4th edition; earlier editions will not suffice.)
Print, new: $105.78 (hardcover, Barnes and Noble or Amazon)

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Knowing the own pedigree strengthens the sense of identity. This applies not just to individuals but also to communities and is equally valid for research fields. The History of Music Theory retraces the pedigree of this discipline not in the spirit of an antiquarian exercise but as a discovery of its intellectual heritage which has manifold implications for today's music-theoretical discourse. The course covers the developments of music theory from Johann Mattheson (1681-1764) to Heinrich Schenker (1868-1935) and focuses on the most important debates and controversies that divided the field in this period. The readings of primary and secondary sources and in-class discussions will help you understand how positions of different parties were conditioned by different trends within the musical and intellectual culture of their times and how they resonate (or not) with current positions in the field of music theory. The course will have a seminar format and the assessment will include your preparation for and participation in the discussions, two presentations and a final paper.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the class the student will be expected to have become familiar with the main ideas and concepts developed by music theorists from Johann Mattheson to Heinrich Schenker and understood the conflicting positions taken by different parties in the main debates and controversies that took place in the field of music theory in this period.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Seminar: One seminar (2h 50min) per week
Independent study: Preparation of final paper
Readings: Extensive weekly readings
Class participationWriting assignmentsPresentations: Research presentation
Discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Paper, final: 40%
Presentations: Two presentations (20% each)
AttendanceClass participation: Class participation and attendance (20%)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Oliver Messiaen (1908-92) and Witold Lutos?awski (1913-94) belong to the greatest composers of the 20th century. In their creative exploration of musical material both of them moved beyond the confines of tonality and into an unrestricted use of the twelve tones of the chromatic scale, but both steered clear of the twelve-tone technique of the Second Viennese School (Schoenberg, Berg, Webern) and from its ramifications in the serial technique of the post-war avantgarde. Instead, they absorbed the influence of the post-tonal tradition represented by Stravinsky, Ravel, Debussy, and Bartók, and developed their own compositional techniques which match?or surpass?those of serialism in terms of rigorous calibration of pitch, texture and rhythm, yet take into account the cognitive and perceptual limitations of human performers and listeners. Articulate speakers and writers, Messiaen and Lutos?awski were the first theorists of their own music and laid out the main principles of their respective musical languages in several lectures and publications. In this class we will learn these principles and use them to analyze some of their most celebrated works. In the course of the quarter we will retrace the chronological development of their personal styles, examine consecutive stages of their oeuvre, and become acquainted with various facets of their aesthetics. Assessment will be based on two listening tests and two analytical essays demonstrating your understanding of the compositional techniques you will have learned in class.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the class the students will become familiar with a fair number of compositions by Messiaen and Lutos?awski. They will be expected to have understood the main principles of compositional techniques developed by these composers and learned how to apply them in analysis of individual works.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Lecture: Two 80-minute lectures weekly
Independent study: Readings will include preliminary analyses of musical examples to be discussed in class
ReadingsClass participationCase studies: In-class analysis of selected pieces
Writing assignmentsListening exercisesPresentationsDemonstrationsDiscussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Paper, final: 30%
Quizzes: 2, 20% each
Paper, mid-term: 30%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Suggested class materials:
Paul Griffiths, Olivier Messiaen and the Music of Time. London: Faber, 1985.
Tadeusz Kaczynski, Conversations with Witold Lutoslawski. London: Chester, 1995.
Olivier Messiaen, The Technique of my Musical Language. Paris: Leduc, 1956.
Charles Bodman Rae, The Music of Lutoslawski. London: Faber, 1994.

name: Negotiating a Joint Venture in China

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Through a simulation-oriented course, students will be exposed to recent economic history of the People's
Republic of China, foreign direct investment law of China, and negotiating norms of US and Chinese investors.
These various knowledge sets will be brought together as each participant takes on the role of either a
Chinese investor or a US investor, negotiating the terms of a China-based joint venture and ultimately
reporting back to their respective board of directors. In addition to the negotiation exercises, the course
requires a brief, quality-driven paper on a contemporary topic relating to China as an economic actor on the
world stage.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Upon completion of this course, students will possess:
- an overview of select elements of Chinese recent history and, particularly, how they relate to China's
current foreign direct investment environment;
- an overview of select elements of China's legal system regarding foreign direct investment as well as
select typical challenges foreign investors encounter in China;
- an introduction to the proactive, results-oriented analysis in which a good commercial lawyer
engages; and
- an introduction to select documentation used in select typical China-oriented transactions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Participation, 25%
- thoughtful questions
- discussion participation
- references to assigned reading
Negotiations, 25%
- negotiations treated with ownership
- insightful report to the board (e.g., identify conflicts, constraints, resolutions)
- conclude memorandum of understanding or joint venture contract
Final Paper, 50%
- organized, clear and thoughtfully written
- seven pages

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
The class calls for the students to present the following deliverables:
- executed memorandum of understanding or joint venture contract, delivered during final session

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce students to the writing process that judges and law clerks use to decide cases and communicate with the public through orders and opinions. Students will learn about the mechanics of judicial writing, including how it differs from advocacy, as well as the ethical rules and practical considerations that guide judges and law clerks. Students will develop and practice their judicial writing skills through graded and ungraded writing, editing, and critique assignments. This course is highly useful preparation for students who wish to serve as judicial externs or law clerks, or who wish to improve their advocacy by gaining insight into how courts reach decisions.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: Communication and Legal Reasoning I and II.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be assessed on three graded writing assignments, as well as class participation which will include ungraded in-class assignments. One of the graded assignments will be a judicial opinion that will be suitable for use as a writing sample.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Last day to drop: 12/10/2019

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar is designed to provide an introduction to the law and practice of international commercial arbitration. It will consider the fundamental characteristics of international arbitration including its advantages and disadvantages as a form of dispute resolution; the network of international treaties (e.g., the New York Convention), national laws, procedural rules and guidelines that apply to international arbitration; the role of institutions and other organizations in supporting international arbitration; and the relationship between international arbitration and national courts. The seminar will cover key topics such as drafting arbitration agreements, selection of arbitrators, conflicts and other ethical issues, provisional remedies, preparing and presenting cases to tribunals (including obtaining evidence, witness testimony, experts, written submissions and hearings), arbitral awards, enforcing agreements to arbitrate, and actions to enforce and set aside arbitral awards.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on the basis of a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Blackaby and Partasides, Redfern and Hunter on International Arbitration (6th ed. 2015)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No materials required for this course

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A laboratory course focusing on quantitative physiological measurements and analyses, instrument characterization, statistical design of experiments, and training in preparation and organization of laboratory notes and reports. Prerequisites: AP stats or BME 220 or IEMS 303 or ME 359

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No class materials required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A laboratory course focusing on quantitative physiological measurements and analyses, instrument characterization, statistical design of experiments, and training in preparation and organization of laboratory notes and reports. Prerequisites: AP stats or BME 220 or IEMS 303 or ME 359.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No class materials required.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Concepts in Medical Physiology, Julian Seifter, Austin Ratner, and David Sloane
Pathophysiology of Heart Disease, edited by L.S. Lilly

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Many biological and engineered systems can be modeled as "linear" and "time invariant." This has a host of implications for how we can experimentally and mathematically approach them, gain understanding, predict, and manipulate their behavior. The course is comprised of lectures and laboratories, and the laboratory emphasis is the ?hands-on' demonstration of the concepts presented in lecture.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Practical Signals Theory with MATLAB Applications, Richard J. Tervo

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will first introduce the basic physics of MRI, including nuclear spin, magnetic moments, interactions with external magnetic fields, and relaxation processes. The second portion of the course will discuss basic concepts of image formation, including radiofrequency pulse excitation, magnetic field gradients, imaging equation, Fourier Transform, k-space, and two-dimensional spatial encoding. The final portion of the course will introduce practical imaging methods and applications, such as image artifacts, fast imaging methods, signal-to-noise, contrast-to-noise, resolution, and MR imaging of the heart and blood vessels.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None, reading materials will be provided during class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to the field of biomaterials. The course will cover metal, ceramic, and polymeric implant materials, with an emphasis on structure-property relationships that enable their applications as medical devices. Interactions of materials with the body will also be discussed. Course content will be learned and assessed via assigned case studies.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required. Instructor to recommend readings based on case studies.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Tissue engineering is a field that aims to regenerate or repair diseased or injured tissues and organs in the body. This course will use student-directed learning as the teaching tool to introduce students to the concepts, principles, and applications of tissue engineering.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Journal, magazine articles, and chapters from books. I recommend Principles of Tissue Engineering Ed. (Lanza, Langer, Vacanti). Access course information through "my blackboard" at https://courses.northwestern.edu

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: BME 366 provides an introductory overview of the broad field of movement biomechanics. BME 366 introduces the application of the mechanical engineering skillsets of rigid body kinematics and dynamics to quantitative problems associated with the study of movement. The course also evaluates skeletal muscle in terms of its role as the mechanical motor that produces musculoskeletal movement.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Fundamental and biomedical applications of diffusive and convective heat and mass transfer.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The overall goal of this course is to expose the student to the analytical techniques used to solve problems in mass and heat transfer. The approach to mass transfer and heat transfer is similar so the lectures will focus on mass transfer problems but we will solve a few heat transfer problem. We will try, in most cases, to show biological applications of the different methods.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Roselli and Diller, Biotransport Principles and Applications, Springer.
Johnson and Ethier, Problems in Biomedical Fluid Mechanics and Transport Phenomena, Cambridge University Press.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A project-based course where students work with a client to design products or processes to improve healthcare in the US and around the globe.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Drug delivery is a multidisciplinary field that aims to modify the exposure of the drug to the patient using engineering and materials science. Drug delivery allows the potential of reducing toxicity, increasing efficacy, and improved use. This course is a lecture-based and lab-based class. We will introduce the students to the fundamental interactions of drugs and drug delivery systems that have been engineered to treat and prevent a variety of diseases.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: General chemistry, organic chemistry, enrollment or completion of BME 378 and BME 306

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
? Drugs and drug action
? Introduction to drug delivery systems.
? Adsorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion
? The biopharmaceutical classification system for oral drugs
? Pharmacokinetics
? Pharmacodynamics
? Types of controlled release systems
? Testing methods for new drug delivery systems
? Analytical Chemistry techniques used in drug development and drug delivery system testing
? The liposome a self-assembling nanoparticle platform
? Bioconjugate chemistry and drug-polymer conjugates
? Contraceptive delivery systems
? FDA IND preclinical process

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureLabDiscussion

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Journal, magazine articles, and chapters from books and handouts. Access course information through Canvas.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This course is intended for juniors and seniors that are interested in a career or research in pharmaceutical sciences.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Physiology of the heart, circulatory system, lungs, and respiration from an engineering perspective. General overview and in-depth study of original work.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Pathophysiology of Heart Disease, edited by L.S. Lilly

name: Neural Control and Mechanics of Movement

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This graduate level survey course will cover the physiological elements within the vertebrate motor system and the computational problems intrinsic to the production of movement. We will cover the computational issues that arise within motor control, both those issues which are general across the production of movement by any system and those which are specific to biological motor control. Topics will include representation learning, supervised and unsupervised learning, optimal control and estimation, and reinforcement learning. The course will consist of a combination of lectures and paper discussions: lectures will present formal descriptions of computational analyses; papers will illustrate applications of these analyses or computational concepts to issues in the neural control of movement.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No required readings.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Fundamental and biomedical applications of diffusive and convective heat and mass transfer.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Roselli and Diller, Biotransport Principles and Applications, Springer
Johnson and Ethier, Problems in Biomedical Fluid Mechanics and Transport Phenomena, Cambridge University Press

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Principles of Entrepreneurship is a fundamental course for students with limited or no prior exposure to business. In this class, you will build a knowledge foundation in all the key entrepreneurial subject areas. This includes accounting, finance, and marketing. The final deliverable will be an elevator pitch. This course is cross-listed as IEMS 225. It is a core course for the Undergraduate Minor in Entrepreneurship.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Humans have been communicating through stories for 20,000 years. They have the power to persuade, engage, and inspire action. But too often, in business, we don't think about harnessing the power of stories. Storytelling for Business will teach students how to use narrative techniques and structures to create compelling stories to help them nail an interview, motivate a team, secure funding, build a brand, and inspire customers.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn to effectively employ narrative structures and techniques in a variety of business situations. Students will learn to: 1) develop a compelling, narrative-driven company brand with special focus on startup/emerging companies 2) develop a personal, professional narrative for use in interviewing, networking, pitching, and other business situations 3) use narrative and stories in professional situations, such as to lead, persuade, inspire, present, or teach 4) use brand storytelling techniques to creative compelling social media, websites, and other online platforms 5) learn to create multiplatform and multichannel brand stories.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureSeminarGroup workPresentationsDiscussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Group projectPresentationsClass participationPapersProject, finalWriting assignments

descriptions.value:
4 books are required for this course.

1.
TITLE: Winning the Story Wars: Why Those Who Tell (and Live) the Best Stories Will Rule the Future, 1st Edition
AUTHOR: Jonah Sachs
PUBLISHER: Harvard Business Review Press
ISBN: 9781422143568

2.
TITLE: Made to Stick: Why Some Ideas Survive and Others Die, 1st edition
AUTHOR: Chip Heath and Dan Heath
PUBLISHER: Random House
ISBN: 1400064287

3.
TITLE: Let the Story Do the Work: The Art of Storytelling for Business Success, 1st Edition
AUTHOR: Esther Choy
PUBLISHER: AMACOM
ISBN: 9780814438015

4.
TITLE: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire: Using Digital And Social Media for Brand Storytelling
AUTHOR: Mohanbir Sawhney and Pallavi Goodman
PUBLISHER: Kellogg Case Publishing
ISBN: N/A

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The startup ecosystem is synonymous with computer science, engineering and other tech focused educational backgrounds. However, at the heart of every successful startup is a certain level of financial literacy needed by founders to guide and navigate the startup from simply an idea to (hopefully) a lucrative exit. Without a firm grasp on accounting, many founders fail to see their startup reach its full potential, or fail outright.

The goal of this course is to lay the foundation for what a founder needs to know to successfully launch and scale a startup, taught from the accountant's perspective. You'll learn not only what exactly accounting is, but how it applies to startups specifically. In addition, we will teach the basics that will enable you to manage your accounting operations during the infancy of a startup's lifecycle. Further, we will provide founders with a level of understanding that equips them to make actionable, strategic decisions from accurate and insightful accounting.

descriptions.value: LectureSeminarLab

descriptions.value: Group projectExamsQuizzes

descriptions.value: All class materials will be available on Canvas at no additional cost to the student.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
NUvention: Web + Media (ENTREP 473, COMP_SCI 473) is a two-quarter capstone course in which students work across disciplines and Northwestern schools to design, plan, and run web-based businesses. Project areas include iPad/Tablet App, Mobile Applications, New Media, Social Gaming, Twitter or Facebook Apps, eCommerce/Deals, Analytics, Cloud, Big Data or ideas from students in the program.

Teams are able to continue to work on their projects after the completion of the course. Past NUvention: Web + Media teams have gone on to make TechCrunch, PCMag, Rolling Stone and GigaOM headlines and join incubators, while others are bootstrapping and building their businesses to this day.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Permission number from the Farley Center is required to enroll in this class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
NUvention: Energy (ENTREP 474, ISEN 430) responds to the demand for innovation and entrepreneurship in the sustainable energy and cleantech space that will increasingly be required to deal with climate change, resource constraint, and other environmental challenges. The Farley Center partnered with the Institute for Sustainability and Energy at Northwestern to offer this course through the McCormick School of Engineering.

Students from engineering, business, arts and sciences, law and other graduate schools across campus come together in interdisciplinary teams to develop a product or service, and a business plan, in the sustainable energy or cleantech industry. The objective of the course is to provide students with a realistic simulation of the challenges and opportunities entrepreneurial founding teams face trying to create a business around technologies or services that both meet a market need and have a positive environmental impact.

Past NUvention: Energy teams have gone on to compete in national business plan competitions and have collectively won more than $1 million dollars.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Course Outcomes: (Things students should be able to accomplish after completing the course)

Introduction to Electrical Conduction, Semiconductors, Crystalline structures, Imperfections, Phase Diagrams, Kinetics, Mechanical properties, Ceramics, Polymers, Corrosion, Magnetic Materials, and Thin Films.

A student completing this course will be able to look at various materials as assemblies of atoms, molecules, and clusters and understand:
1) how these assemblies (structures) dictate properties
2) how processing changes the assemblies.
3) how engineering materials are selected for various purposes
4) how materials facilitate technological development and influence society

Relationship to Department Objectives:
Supports 1, 2, 3, 4

descriptions.value: CHEM 102

mid - term exam 1/3
final exam 1/3

descriptions.value:
INTRO.TO MATERIALS SCIENCE+ENGINEERING By CHUNG

Edition 07
Publisher: TAYLOR

ISBN: 9780849392634

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Course Objectives:
1.) The objectives of this course are to develop an understanding of free enery vs. temperature relationships in binary and ternary phase diagrams, including fundamental electrochemical understanding and 2.) to develop an understanding of point defects and their role in diffusion.

Course Outcomes:
A student completing this course should be able to:
1. Relate free energy vs. temperature and composition relationships to binary phase diagrams
2. Solve basic electrochemistry problems
3. Interpret ternary phase diagrams
4. Use modern software programs to predict free energy functions and the related phase diagrams
5. Describe the relationship between point defects and the role of diffusion in solids
6. Describe the equilibrium thermodynamics of point defects in crystalline ionic and non-ionic solids
7. Describe the Kirkendall effect, diffusion in ternary systems, and the importance of short-circuit diffusion

Relationship to Department Outcomes:
Supports 2, 3, 4, 5

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: MAT SCI 314 or equivalent

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three lectures, one hour of problem solving, and one two hour laboratory per week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: In addition to lab reports, there will be weekly homework assignments, two midterm exams, and a group project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: D. A. Porter, K. E. Easterling, and M.Y.Sherif, Phase Transformations in Metals and Alloys, 3rd edition, CRC Press. ISBN 1420062107

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: P. G. Shewmon, Transformations in Metals; R. A. Swalin, Thermodynamics of Solids; Y. M. Chiang, D. Birnie, and W. D. Kingery, Physical Ceramics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Course Topics:
Materials Structure, Properties, and Performance.
Design, identification of performance criteria, selection decisions.
Mechanical behavior of manufactured articles.
Performance Efficiency formalisms; materials charts; sources of data.
Selections for structural articles; metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites.
Selections for coatings and surface treatments.
Materials Degradation; Failure analysis; Materials selection validation

Course Outcomes:
After completing this course, a student should:

1. Be able to specify performance requirements of a desired material and the process for making it, in the context of a given application.

2. Be able to analyze quantitatively the Performance Efficiency relationships for an article.

3. Be able to identify appropriate materials based on required physical and chemical properties.

4. Be able to take into account collateral performance requirement to ensure proper materials selection.

Relationship to Department Objectives http://www.matsci.northwestern.edu/mission.html
Supports 2, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 15, 16

descriptions.value: Mat Sci 201

descriptions.value: Download, or ready access to, of CES EduPack 2016

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
MAT SCI 332 This course will provide the students with an in-depth study of plastic deformation and fracture of materials, with emphasis on structure/properties relations. The role of imperfections, state of stress, temperature and strain rate upon mechanical behavior, is examined.

Teams consisting of about 4 students will carry out a project designed to simulate an industrial or university R&D investigation. Materials will be subjected to microstructural and mechanical tests from which an application will be evaluated. Each team will present an oral and a written report at the end of the quarter.

Relationship to Department Objectives
Supports 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 8, 15, 16

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: MAT SCI 316-1,2; 316-2 may be taken concurrently

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three lectures and one lab session per week. Classroom discussions are encouraged. The lab class will be divided into project teams. Lab hours can be scheduled by each team with lab instructors consent.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Weekly homework 15%
Mid-term Exam 30%
Final Exam 30%
Project Report and Oral Presentation 25%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Deformation and Fracture Mechanics of Engineering Materials, 5th ed., R.W. Hertzberg, R.P. Vinci and J.L. Hertzberg. John Wiley.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The student should be able to understand the synthesis-structures-properties-applications relationship of conducting polymers. They should be able to: 1. Draw the molecular structure of common conducting polymer monomers/polymers 2. Know basic synthetic methods 3. Understand the concept of doping and dedoping 4. Be familiar with common applications of conducting polymers and the science behind them 5. Be familiar with the history of the field, some leading scientists and classical references, and some current research activities in the field 6. Gain hands-on experiences on the synthesis of nanostructured conducting polymers and construct chemical vapor sensorsChoose one from the following (about 10 hours) 1: Polyaniline Nanofiber Sensors Session 1: Safety orientation and synthesis of polyaniline nanofibers Session 2: Purification of polyaniline nanofibers, preparation of sensor electrodes and deposition of polyaniline Session 3: Testing the sensors Pre-lab and post-lab reports are required Location: TBA 2: Polyaniline nanofiber actuators Synthesize polyaniline nanofibers and use them to make an artificial hand or a flower 3: Propose your own project on conducting polymers

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Homework and discussion (40%) Lab performance and report (30%) Literature review (undergraduate)/Proposal (graduate students) and presentation (30%) Bonus points for smart questions, creative proposals/ideas during the lab sessions (10 %)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Books: 1. Conducting Polymers, Fundamentals and Applications, by Prasanna. Chandrasekhar - 1999, ISBN: 9780792385646 2. Handbook of conducting polymers (1st, 2nd and 3rd Editions) ISBN: 9781574446654 All are reserved in Science and Engineering Library including at least 3 copies of book 1. Journal review/tutorial articles Handouts

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the second part of a two-course sequence. In this quarter, the quantum mechanical and statistical concepts developed in 351-1 are applied to the study of such materials-related subjects as electrical properties, optical properties, semiconductor junctions, magnetism, dielectrics, lasers, ferroelectrics, and associated subjects and superconductivity. In all cases, the materials aspect and technological applications of the phenomena are stressed.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Physics 135-1,2,3; Gen Eng 205-4; and Mat Sci 351-1 or equivalent.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three one-hour lectures with discussion per week. Lab on Thursday for 3 hours per week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Based on homework, laboratory reports, midterm, final exam, and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: L. Solymer and D. Walsh, Electrical Properties of Materials, revised edition, Oxford. ISBN: 978-0198702788

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Course Description:
Elementary crystallography. Basic diffraction theory; reciprocal space. Applications to structure analysis, preferred orientation. Diffractometer techniques with point detectors and 2D area detectors. Lectures, laboratory.
Course Outcomes:

1. Students will be able to identify different types of crystal structures that occur in metals, ceramics, and polymers.

2. Students will be able to perform standard x-ray diffraction measurements on metals, ceramics and polymers and quantitatively interpret the results.

3. Students will attain an intermediate level of understanding for the particle and wave physical processes underlying x-ray emission, elastic and inelastic scattering, absorption, and interference of coherent waves. They will understand how these processes manifestly explain 3D and 2D kinematical diffraction, thin-film diffraction, conventional and synchrotron x-ray sources, x-ray fluorescence spectroscopy, and low-energy electron diffraction.

4. Students will understand how to use reciprocal space graphical constructions and vector algebra to interpret diffraction from 3D and 2D single crystals, and random and textured polycrystalline samples.

Relationship to Department Objectives http://www.matsci.northwestern.edu/mission.html
Supports 1, 2, 4, 5, 13, 15

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
1. Differential and Integral Calculus
2. Vector Analysis
3. Complex Analysis (Euler's Formula and the Complex Plane)
4. Elementary Electricity and Magnetism
5. Elementary Modern Physics (Atomic Energy Levels)
6. Atomic Bonding and Coordination

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Prelim Exams: 25%
Homework 25%
Labs 30%
Final 20%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
"Elements of Diffraction", B.D. Cullity and S.R. Stock, Prentice Hall (3rd ed. 2001) ISBN: 0-201-61091-4
"The Basics of Crystallography and Diffraction", C. Hammond, Oxford 3rd ed. (2009)
ISBN: 9780199546459

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: For more than 500 million years, "simple" sea urchins have used fiber-reinforced, graded, ceramic materials to build self-sharpening teeth. This may be astonishing; it is, however, by no means unique. Organisms from all domains make use of the materials properties of crystalline and amorphous solids (e.g. inorganic minerals) to provide physical integrity and sense gravity, to guide light and even perceive the earth's magnetic field. Evolutionary optimization has led to organic-inorganic composite structures of amazing complexity, ordered across many levels of hierarchy and on length scales. In MSE 371 you will learn not only about the design, i.e. the structure and functional organization of biominerals, but also their integrated synthesis and even their importance for global processes such as the carbon cycle. We will examine some of the fundamentals of the interaction of organic and inorganic matter in biological systems, and study classic papers as well as current hot topics in this exciting and diverse field of research.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Assessments will involve a few quizzes covering basics of chemistry, biochemistry, biology, and materials science. Students will further publish a wiki on a topic of choice or prepare a short research proposal (style: 3-page NSF GRFP). Projects will be presented during reading week, no final exam will be given.

name: Senior Project in Materials Science and Engineering

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Course Objectives:
To be taken in two consecutive quarters. Independent basic or applied research project, conceived and performed under the direction of a department faculty member.

Course Outcomes: (things students should be able to accomplish after completing the course)

A student completing this course should be able to:

1. Understand the basis for making ethical decisions in the practice of science and engineering.

2. Write a research report consistent with standard practices.

3. Give effective oral and written reports of ongoing and completed work.

Relationship to Department Outcomes: (http://www.matsci.northwestern.edu/mission.html)
Supports 2, 5, 7, 10, 11, 13, 16

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Senior standing in materials science program

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
The grade will be based on the biweekly progress reports, presentations and participation in class, end of quarter write-up, final presentation and thesis and overall research effort. Grades are determined jointly by Dr. Stair and the research advisor, as follows:
Participation in weekly meetings & progress reports (10%)
Overall Research Effort (20%)
Final Oral Presentation (30%)
Final Written Report (40%)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
The ACS Style Guide: A Manual for Authors and Editors , Janet S. Dodd, Ed.; American Chemical Society: Washington , D.C, 1986. On reserve.
Web resource on technical writing: http://www.writing.eng.vt.edu/csp.html
