name: Special Topics
topic: Criminal Justice Reporting: A Class Taught Inside

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This class is part of a new program at Northwestern, the Northwestern Prison Education Program (NPEP), in which NU faculty teach incarcerated students at Stateville Correctional Center. The NPEP students receive NU credit hours. This class will consist of ten NPEP students and ten NU students, in this case all from Medill. The incarcerated students and Evanston students will be equals in the class. The class will meet in Stateville Prison, an hour's drive from Evanston.

In this class we'll read an array of writings on Criminal Justice, from investigative reporting to personal accounts to argumentative essays. How best to convey the complexities and inequities in our criminal justice system, from the police to the courts to our prisons? How best to highlight what's working? Students in the class will write a number of short pieces, exercises in reporting and interviewing as well as exercises in essay writing. We will workshop pieces in the class.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: The class is open to Juniors and Seniors. By application only.

name: Special Topics
topic: Media History & The Native American Experience

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Journalism practice and user behavior with media content are continuously changing in the era of digital journalism. There is a growing demand for innovative approaches that address rapidly changing needs. Northwestern University has identified diversity and inclusion as one of its teaching and learning objectives. In this media history class, we will generate multimedia content for an "Indigenous Tour of Northwestern." Students will research Native American people, places, policies, and historic social movements that intersect with locations on the Northwestern campus. They will collect and digitize historical records, maps, newspaper and magazine accounts, and generate new content in the form of video and audio interviews for use in a virtual reality tour (VR) and an augmented reality (AR) walking tour of the Evanston campus. This unique digital humanities project is intended to become a resource for faculty, staff, and students, visitors and community members.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The discussion seminar course will explore the calculated efforts to ensure that political power in the U.S. stays in the hands of those in power against all demographic odds and projections. It is often said, particularly now, that the right to vote is what keeps the United States from descending into autocracy or one-party rule. Yet, the right to vote is not protected directly in the Constitution, and American history is filled with examples of successful ways for those in power, at both national and local levels, to keep and entrench their power by manipulating THE VOTE. A core purpose of the course is to brief students on how this has been done in the U.S. and to prepare them to know it when they see it and to report on it or otherwise address it.



Among the topics we will cover are:

The Vote, the Constitution and its Amendments, the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and the end of the Voting Rights Act: Origins and traditions throughout the U.S. that have limited the vote to property-owning white men until the 15th Amendment in 1870; denied generations of women the right to vote until the 19th Amendment 50 years later in 1920; and ended in 2013 the Voting Rights Act protections against racial discrimination in voting that were enacted 48 years earlier in 1965.

Immigration and demographics: Selective limits and bans on lawful migration into the U.S. and on naturalizations have reduced the numbers and types of people allowed to enter and stay in the country and become citizens who can vote.

Voter suppression: Techniques used by states, ostensibly to address potential vote fraud, such as disqualifying felons and ex-felons from voting, poll taxes, literacy tests, grandfather clauses and other Jim Crow laws; requiring photo IDs; purging voter rolls when registered voters don't vote in consecutive elections; using unverified crosscheck lists to create the impression of illegal duplicate voting; limiting early voting; closing targeted polling places, all of which tend to disproportionately impact minorities, African-American communities, lower-income residents, majority-Hispanic districts, and senior citizens; and the Supreme Court decisions in Bush v. Gore (2000) and Rucho v. Common Cause (2019).

Voter registration, turnout and non-voters: The predictable limits that have produced a nation in which voting tends to include only about 60% of the voting eligible population for presidential elections, about 40% for midterm elections, and about 25% in municipal elections.

Census: Every ten years, the census bureau does its most intensive count of the U.S. population. The data is used to draw district boundaries for the purposes of determining Congressional and state legislative maps. One issue for this coming 2020 census is the citizenship question, which the Supreme Court recently addressed in U.S. Commerce Dept. v. New York (2019) and which we will dissect to understand the relationship between the census, demographic reality and elections to come.

Redistricting, gerrymandering and the Electoral College: It is legal for politicians to draw district boundaries for partisan political purposes, but not for racial reasons. That distinction was recently reinforced in Rucho v. Common Cause (2019), with the Supreme Court deciding 5-4 that intended political fixes should continue to be legal. One consequence of political gerrymandering is it allows for those in power who draw and approve the redistricting maps to further entrench their political ideologies and parties.

The Russians are coming: They came, they saw and they corrupted. Why stop now and have others, from other countries to domestic disrupters, learned the art and tricks of social media saturation?



Each week, we will approach these recurring phenomena through four lenses:

Historical: We will revisit the roots and recurrences in the evolution of voting trends and strategies.

Legal: We will extract and examine the prevailing legislation, legal cases, and principles that guide or dictate election laws and results.

Global: We will be mindful of how the U.S. is similar to and different from other countries.

Happenin': We will bring it all together by scoping out and analyzing current controversies to be better positioned to anticipate and fight back against brazen efforts to perpetuate power and thwart democratic representation and values.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Stereotypes. Coded language. Unconscious bias. How do these concepts factor into the media search for truth? How might they stand in the way of public understanding of social difference? Clearly, the media affect the way we see one another across social boundaries established by such characteristics as race, ethnicity, gender and sexuality. How do the perspectives formed by this "mediated reality" ultimately affect our decisions on public policy in such areas as political participation, equal rights and criminal justice? These and other considerations are central to professional journalism responsibility and enlightened public choice making. Without question, the media are vital to the effective operation of our democratic system by providing information that should be free of the kind of bias that can distort the public participation process.

Through discussion of principles of media professionalism and ethics, and an examination of some of the hot topics featured in today's headlines, this course will set a framework for recognizing and analyzing media narrative framing, as well as the representation of traditionally marginalized groups within that narrative frame. Ultimately, we will develop a deeper appreciation of media responsibility. Just as important, we will expand our sense of media literacy in considering a path forward?whether as professional journalists, or engaged citizens?as we navigate the challenging terrain of an increasingly diverse society, one in which we all can appreciate the value of social difference and multiple perspectives.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: You will learn best practices in video preparation, reporting and editing. Each week you will add new skills to your repertoire. Through an immersive, approach,?students will become familiar and skilled in shooting and editing video, planning structuring a video piece, and determining what makes a good visual story.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to the disruptive technological innovations that have transformed the journalism industry in the past 20 years, and pushes students to identify trends that could potentially shake things up in the coming years. With a balanced mix of contextual readings, lectures, discussions, and simulations, students will explore these technologies through several lenses: information gathering, storytelling, production, dissemination, and consumption. Hands-on technical training in HTML and CSS will begin to give the students tools to build web-based journalism projects.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to the disruptive technological innovations that have transformed the journalism industry in the past 20 years, and pushes students to identify trends that could potentially shake things up in the coming years. With a balanced mix of contextual readings, lectures, discussions, and simulations, students will explore these technologies through several lenses: information gathering, storytelling, production, dissemination, and consumption. Hands-on technical training in HTML and CSS will begin to give the students tools to build web-based journalism projects.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will build upon the reporting and writing foundations and enter the realm of sports analysis and commentary. Students will go beyond describing what happened, using advanced metrics to explain how and why things happen, while developing the ability to explain what it means and where it will lead. There will be emphasis on creating a distinctive writing voice as well as the ability to deliver commentary across visual and audio platforms.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
-The Best American Sports Writing, 2018 Edition, Edited by Jeff Pearlman. A collection of outstanding sports stories by some of America's best-known sportswriters. (Kindle or paperback)

-Field Guide to Covering Sports by Joe Gisondi (spiral-bound)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course prepares students to graphically produce and convey information in a way that enhances and elevates its meaning. Human-centered design plays a role in each assignment, in which students put people at the center of the research and use design thinking as their lens to view the world. Students will practice alternative story techniques and explore the intersection of storytelling and art in various contexts, including mental health, the arts and movie scenes. They will develop proficiency at conceiving varied traditional and nontraditional storytelling ideas that provoke, stimulate and expand design awareness. Upon successful completion of Thinking & Communicating Visually, students will have proven processes for idea generation that can be applied in almost any industry. The course format is a blend of lecture, demonstration and travel to London to see some of the most unique and creative storytelling techniques found in motion pictures. Students will develop a multimedia final project for the course that is based on their London experience.

Creatives draw inspiration from both obvious and unexpected resources and London provides some unique opportunities for students, such as the House of Mina Lima, one of the most extraordinary studio-galleries in the world. It is packed with exceptional storytelling props from the Harry Potter film franchise that are creative, whimsical and sometimes totally bizarre. Building upon that students will also visit the Warner Brothers Studio where the films' sets are stored, and the Victoria and Albert Museum to observe innovative approaches to storytelling. One day is set aside for a workshop with Deborah Withey, former creative director of the Virginia Pilot and Detroit Free Press, who now runs Cheese +Pickles Creative & Therapeutic Arts Studio in Wales, specializing in storytelling as the medium of creative and therapeutic art.

In this course, students will:

Create and develop a visual response to communication problems, including understanding of hierarchy, typography, aesthetics, composition and construction of meaningful images

Become more visually observant and critical

Develop communication problem solving skills including identifying the problem, researching and analyzing, and finding a solution

Gain the important perspective that storytelling isn't limited to editorial journalism

Learn to deliver immersive storytelling techniques with all the wow factors, taking the audience on a visual journey; knowing how and when to apply just the right visual rhythm to interactive elements that are both informative and graphically stimulating

Create a multimedia photo essay, magazine spread, nontraditional story format, cross-platform multimedia final project using non-coding software that permits the mixture of words, images, graphics, videos and 360 motion into one fabulous deliverable

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Adobe Creative Cloud $19.99 per. month membership https://www.adobe.com/creativecloud/plans.html

Small sketch book $ 2.99

The principles and Practice of Graphic Design: Digital copies of the book can be found in the northwestern Library or you can purchase Graphic Design School 6 edition by Wiley publishing $ 55 at this link.

http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/Section/id-WILEY2_SEARCH_RESULT.html?query=Graphic%20design

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class is designed to introduce you to audio journalism. Audio is a creative way to tell stories and the goal of this class is to get you comfortable with the medium. These days radio is on demand - you can listen via podcast and online. It's not just for your car or alarm clocks. The audience is expanding and even legacy media are incorporating audio journalism on their websites. You will learn how to plan, record, edit and mix audio. You will produce news spots, vox, sound and one news feature story.

name: Global Journalism
topic: The Dampening of Democracy in South Africa's Rainb

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Johannesburg, like Chicago, is a bustling city with a mixture of wonder and woe. From persistent inequalities in housing and education to gleaming edifices of financial success, these "tale of two cities" twins have much in common. South Africa has made progress since the fall of racial apartheid in 1994, but there is much work still to be done. The multiracial "Rainbow Nation," is a young democracy with a constitution considered one of the most progressive in the world. But many of the rights promised have yet to be fulfilled for Johannesburg's 4.4 million people. These gaps provide ample material on which to report. The 2019 national election period was only the sixth time that blacks had been allowed to vote.

Your trip will begin with briefings with experts, visits to the Apartheid Museum and other attractions, and tours - from the fashionable Sandton, "Africa's richest square mile," to the famous Soweto, a key site in the struggle against apartheid.

We will apply a "solutions journalism" lens to our reporting on the following tentative topics:

The Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR)
Gender Based Violence
Experimental News Media Platforms
Education

In this course, you will:

Develop a global view of the urbanization and human rights issues facing major cities.
Better understand, through the lens of South Africa, the forces shaping the developing continent, including technology, age, gender and immigration issues.
Learn interviewing and reporting strategies in a foreign country.
Produce a reporting project that, it is hoped, will be published after the trip.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to give students news producing, interviewing and anchoring experience. You will learn how to "line produce" a traditional newscast with specialized software that television newsrooms use. In addition, you will get in-depth interviewing experience in the context of field and show producing. Excellent and ethical writing and editing will continue to be emphasized through the use of timely CNN footage.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This News Reporting class teaches you to develop a beat focused on subject areas such as business, politics, urban affairs, science, environment, sports, the arts and other content areas. You may also choose a general assignment beat for a mix of story responsibilities. As reporters for the Medill News Service, you will write breaking news, enterprise and news feature stories, with multimedia components and graphics always welcome. You will provide photograph for every story and we will develop opportunities for collaborative, team-reported stories as well. Plan to learn and create strategies for thorough reporting, informed by a range sources, events and research. You can explore a variety of story formats, crafting well-structured, clear and elegant journalism every step of the way. We will work together as editor and reporter to develop the deeper meaning and larger issues of your stories. A significant but fluid amount of class-designated time will be spent reporting and you will publish work to the Medill Reports website.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The Magazine Writing Lab is a hands-on introduction to the core competencies of magazine writing, basic editing, and story packaging/producing for short-form works. This course will introduce you to the basics of "magazine think," the process by which magazine writers and editors pitch, assign, write, edit and eventually publish magazine journalism in a host of formats for publications in a print/digital/social world. Throughout the quarter, we will focus on the building blocks of magazines?audience, voice, story framing, magazine architecture, editorial judgment, narrative structure, curation and aggregation, and all-important short-form story treatments to create magazine-style pieces, both in print and multimedia, for publication. Ultimately, the course arms students with the skills necessarily to create multi-platform, magazine-style stories throughout the quarter for possible publication on the Medill Reports website.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This class is designed to provide students with a solid foundation in video journalism. It is intended for students interested in pursuing careers in all forms of video journalism including documentary, television news and interactive web reporting.

The primary emphasis of this class will be on reporting; getting the facts right, getting the right sources and telling the story in an engaging and understandable way while using a camera to gather stories and using video to tell stories.

Students will also learn how to write to their pictures, how to write for the ear, how to make stories compelling and character-driven.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This News Reporting class teaches you to develop a beat focused on subject areas such as business, politics, urban affairs, science, environment, sports, the arts and other content areas. You may also choose a general assignment beat for a mix of story responsibilities. As reporters for the Medill News Service, you will write breaking news, enterprise and news feature stories, with multimedia components and graphics always welcome. You will provide photograph for every story and we will develop opportunities for collaborative, team-reported stories as well. Plan to learn and create strategies for thorough reporting, informed by a range sources, events and research. You can explore a variety of story formats, crafting well-structured, clear and elegant journalism every step of the way. We will work together as editor and reporter to develop the deeper meaning and larger issues of your stories. A significant but fluid amount of class-designated time will be spent reporting and you will publish work to the Medill Reports website.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course explores the economic and business concepts that are key to understanding global economic challenges and their impact on businesses, consumers and society. Major industrialized nations are facing a common set of challenges: aging populations and declining birth rates, years of economic stagnation, heavy debt burdens and, more recently, escalating trade conflicts. Nowhere are these challenges more evident than in Japan, a country that was a global economic powerhouse in the 1980s, but collapsed in the early 1990s and has never fully recovered. Negative interest rates, Abenomics, womenomics, massive investments in robotics, and a loosening of immigration policy are all strategies that Japan has put in place, so far with marginal success. Japan is the host country for the 2020 Summer Olympics - an investment it hopes will provide an economic jolt while burnishing its international reputation. Before traveling to Japan, students will research and pitch stories they would like to pursue while on the ground in Tokyo.

Led by Medill lecturer Ceci Rodgers, students will travel to one of the most fascinating cities in the world, Tokyo, in the third-largest economy in the world, Japan, where they will explore traditional and modern aspects of Japanese culture and society. They will visit museums, including the Japan Olympic Museum, and businesses, such as Pixiv and the Tokyo Stock Exchange, and media outlets. While in Japan, students will report on story topics in teams, with help from translators. Story topics may include: preparation for the Olympics; Valentine's Day in Japan; the impact of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's policies, such as a recent hike in the sales tax; robotics and mechanization of service businesses in response to an aging/declining labor force, and many others.

In this course, students will:

Develop important understanding and perspective on the global nature of the economy by seeing the similarities and inter-relatedness of business institutions in Japan and in the U.S.

Master basic business, financial and economic concepts that will enhance your reporting abilities, regardless of the topic.

Better understand the demographic forces that are shaping economic life and society in aging industrialized nations such as Japan

Gain international, intercultural experience reporting business, money and markets in a country where you do not speak the language

Make connections in Tokyo with journalists and business sources

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Building from a base of strong reporting, students will learn how to craft in-depth narrative stories. The class is two-pronged: careful study of outstanding feature stories and work on writing, reporting, and analytic skills. In the end, each student will produce his or her own substantial story suitable for publication. The course aims to encourage writing that is clear, graceful, and efficient. Students will also learn how to pitch stories and find suitable outlets for publication. Because virtually all media demand good narrative technique, the course is appropriate for students who are pursuing magazine, news reporting, documentary film, investigative, and interactive skills.?

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Books?at most, less than $40 total and probably quite a bit less. (All books are also available at the library.)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Want to work in magazines? Write narrative feature stories? Successfully pitch to varied media outlets? Magazine Editing delivers the skills writers, editors and producers need to succeed in today's multi-faceted journalism-based brands. Whether your goal is to be a writer, editor or publisher, in print or online, Magazine Editing explains and prepares you for a career in media. Students will learn and practice techniques for editing?and producing magazine-styled material in print, digital and mobile formats. The core concepts taught include how to find story ideas; how to work with a writer to develop a story from idea to execution; varieties of narrative structure; and editing basics, from organizing a narrative to improving sentences. The course will also offer insights into the business generally and prepare students for a wide range of roles in magazines and other media. ? The final project allows students to develop their own media brand.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Access to laptop or other word processing equipment

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Advanced Heath and Sciences Reporting builds on specialization skills you developed in the newsroom and during your Health and Science Seminar. Now, you take it all to the next level with advanced reporting strategies you will learn to apply as we meet as a class with renowned scientists, science reporters and other experts. At the heart of Advanced Reporting, you identify two or three high-impact stories of your choice that you produce with a deep dive into field reporting, finding stories in data and diverse research. The hunt is always on for great stories in this class. Class workshops provide access to tools for planning and sourcing experiential stories, utilizing investigative strategies, tackling data and data visualizations, and reporting with a mix of text and multimedia options. You leverage your skills and learn new skills to stretch storytelling boundaries for innovative reporting. We publish on the Medill Reports website but you also learn to pitch your stories and seek other opportunities to publish them.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Washington Reporting on Politics and Government provides students with a four-day a week reporting experience focusing on test but also including web video, graphics and photos. Students are credentialed Washington reporters covering Congress, the White House and federal agencies for media partners such as USA Today, Marketwatch.com, the McClatchy newspapers, USNews.com, ChristianScienceMonitor, com and the New York Daily News. The course emphasizes enterprise reporting, visual journalism and computer-assisted reporting skills.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Technique Practicum (1 unit) - Two days a week of advanced journalism training at sites such as Military Times newspapers, USA Today, NPR Digital, SBNation, National Law Journal, etc.

Subject Practicum (1 unit) - Two days a week of research and observation at sites such as the ACLU, Street Law, the Cato Institute, Center for War and Peace, State Department, Canadian (or other) embassy, etc.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Technique Practicum (1 unit) - Two days a week of advanced journalism training at sites such as Military Times newspapers, USA Today, NPR Digital, SBNation, National Law Journal, etc.

Subject Practicum (1 unit) - Two days a week of research and observation at sites such as the ACLU, Street Law, the Cato Institute, Center for War and Peace, State Department, Canadian (or other) embassy, etc.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Students who are in Washington in the winter will study how the U.S. determines and promotes its national security through diplomacy, the military and nongovernmental partners, through the prism of a global context. Guest lecturers include top military experts from the Pentagon and National War College, former diplomates and foreign correspondents.

During Medill Explores week, we will visit Army Headquarters or NATO Headquarters to speak to officials about the U.S. role in Europe, what are the main threats to European stability (Russia is a top threat) and how the U.S. helps allies fight those threats. In Paris, we will meet about half a dozen journalists, including Eleanor Beardsley of NPR, Vivian Walt of TIME, and Jean Lesieur, founding editorial director of France 24, to talk about foreign correspondence. We also will be briefed by Reporters Without Borders, RSF, on threats to journalists, and will go to UNESCO to hear from their journalists' safety initiative experts. Finally, we will have lunch or dinner with a French journalist who has been held hostage several times, including with murdered Medill alum James Foley. We will go to French Parliament offices to speak with experts there about French efforts to deter Russian interference in their elections. We also will hear from Nicolas Tenzer of the Centre D'Etudes et De Reflection Pour L'Action Politique (Center for Research and Study on Political Decisions) and Jean-Baptiste Jeangene Vilmer, director of the Institute for Strategic Research, Ecole Militaire. Other experts will also be briefing us on French-U.S. relations and how the Trump presidency has strained those relations.

In this course, students will:

Research the National Defense Strategy, specifically as it applies to Europe to understand the military's role in projecting American power and working with allies in Europe: what are the threats and strategies the military face

Broaden their understanding of how to interview officials in other countries

Learn how foreign correspondents opereate effectively from thought leaders and practitions, including learn how to report safely and minimize risks in reporting from other countries, especially in conflicts or dangerous situations like civil unrest

Produce stories based on the briefings and interviews set up for the week

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will focus on the elements of successful travel writing. We will explore the evolution of travel journalism, and analyze/discuss engaging travel pieces, using earlier and contemporary examples. Guest speakers will discuss development of ideas for particular audiences and media outlets that cover travel, and how to pitch, report and produce those stories. We also will cover the logistics and ethics of writing about travel and people, communities and places, familiar and unfamiliar.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This class will be a hybrid of in-person and virtual meetings on the following dates: 1/10, 1/17, 1/24, 1/31 and after Medill Explores on 2/14

name: Special Topics
topic: Medill Explores Puerto Rico: Debt, Hurricanes and

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In September 2017, Puerto Rico was decimated by Hurricane Maria which knocked out power to the entire island and left many of the 3.4 million residents without clean water, communication or shelter. The disaster and the government's lackluster response shined light on issues that had long plagued Puerto Rico: poverty and unemployment, poor infrastructure, environmental injustice and lack of political power. The devastation added to the crisis caused by the island's crippling debt, which caused the government to close schools and cut government employment, social services and health care, even as the island has suffered public health crises, including high rates of heroin addiction and HIV infection.

Almost two years later, thousands of Puerto Ricans took to the streets demanding a change in government after the Puerto Rico Center for Investigative Journalism revealed serious corruption and text messages showing mockery and disdain for the general public from then-Governor Ricardo Rossello and his colleagues. The massive protests ? coming on the heels of demonstrations by teachers, women's rights activists and other groups - have launched a movement for wholesale political and social change.

In this context, long-standing problems and the popular resistance movements to address them continue. Environmental contamination is a serious problem, including from toxic coal ash dumps and decades of U.S. military weapons testing. And even as the hurricane caused devastation, it cleared the way for gentrification and hence displacement in desirable areas like San Juan, the Afro-Caribbean coast of Loiza and the tiny island of Vieques.

In this course, you will learn about and report on such current issues on the island and also affecting Chicago's Puerto Rican community. Before the Medill Explores trip, the course will involve learning about Puerto Rico's history and current issues through news coverage, guest speakers and multimedia, with students producing brief written reflections. This is a reporting course with the goal of each student producing a published piece after the trip. The class after the trip will be focused on workshopping and completing stories. The course will also involve collaboration with the Center for Investigative Journalism in San Juan, the journalists who facilitated the latest wave of popular revolt.

Our time in Puerto Rico will involve multiple group reporting visits and interviews with sources on a range of issues, as well as some time for students to report on their own. We will be based in picturesque Old San Juan as well as the island of Vieques. We will visit and report in the rural mountainous areas hard-hit by the hurricane and energy loss; rural coastal areas affected by pollution; and urban areas dealing with socioeconomic issues.

Visits will likely include an estuary community facing extreme contamination and flooding; an Afro-Puerto Rican community struggling to hold on to its beach-front land; the famous and embattled San Juan neighborhood where the Despacito video was recorded; needle exchange groups serving drug users on the streets; a sustainable farming project; an environmental justice project in a remote mountain village; a theater troupe using art to build resilience; the Center for Investigative Journalism; and various sites in Vieques. We will drive throughout the island and will also spend some time on boats and at the beach.

Students may report in various media (print, audio, video, photo). Spanish skills are an asset but not a requirement. A flexible and enthusiastic attitude is necessary for a trip that could be at times unpredictable and tiring, but diverse and exciting.

In this course, students will:

Research, report and deepen your knowledge of Puerto Rico, the Puerto Rican diaspora and the lessons these topics teach us that are applicable to other stories about economics, disaster recovery and migration.

Broaden your journalistic view of the world through first-hand experience in a different culture, language and geographic / political context.

Learn to engage effectively and ethically with people in an unfamiliar community, culture and setting.

Learn industry best practices particularly for travel and bilingual reporting with faculty, fellow students and journalist colleagues and sources we will meet in Puerto Rico.

Produce work that connects classroom learning and reflection with on-the-ground reporting and follow-up.

Produce at least one piece of multimedia, text, audio, photo or video work, to be pitched to various media outlets, with publication options including the Social Justice News Nexus and Medill Reports.

name: Special Topics
topic: Indigenous Nations of the Pacific Northwest

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course explores Native American land, identity, and climate change issues unique to the indigenous people of the Pacific Northwest and also of critical concern to all communities in the area.This region, inhabited by dozens of Indigenous people, share intersecting environmental concerns with other communities of environmentalists, fishermen, farmers and scientists. Water contamination is a key and growing concern to everyone. General topics of interest include dam dismantling, ocean-specific wave energy, and the cost of mitigating and/or adapting to climate change.

Tribal specific topics crystallize many of the issues that impact the wider community. These include fisheries management, erosion and sustainable agriculture. Many communities share Native interests in the resurgence of canoe culture and food sovereignty.Over the past two decades the issue of tribal sovereignty has become increasingly salient, as indigenous communities struggle to defend their air, water, and other natural resources; protect their access to traditional foods; and adapt to changes in their landscapes. The right of Native governments to insist that government-to-government relationships be honored by the states in which they reside?a fundamental element of Indian sovereignty?is at the cultural, political, and legal core of these disputes.

We will travel to Washington State and base ourselves in Olympia for an eight-day stay. With help from agencies like the Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission, the Columbia River Intertribal Fisheries Commission, and the Longhouse Education and Cultural Center at Evergreen College, we will make day trips to Native communities to explore the aforementioned issues.

We will also look at area-wide challenges of soil erosion, lumbering, the depletion of pollinators and species of all kinds due to climate change, changing EPA water quality standards, and water contamination that threaten agriculture, health and the economy, all heightened by growing weather extremes in a warming world.

In this course students will:

Understand how tribal sovereignty and treaty rights inform contemporary issues of all communities in the Pacific Northwest.
Become familiar with the world view and attitudes of Indigenous and non-Indigenous stakeholders in the Pacific Northwest towards climate change.
Through visits with Native community members and other climate and environmental stakeholders, better understand the challenges of regional news gathering in this geographic region.
Gain intercultural knowledge and competence through reflection essays or producing a news report that explores a climate change issue in the Pacific Northwest.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Stereotypes. Coded language. Unconscious bias. How do these concepts factor into the media search for truth? How might they stand in the way of public understanding of social difference? Clearly, the media affect the way we see one another across social boundaries established by such characteristics as race, ethnicity, gender and sexuality. How do the perspectives formed by this "mediated reality" ultimately affect our decisions on public policy in such areas as political participation, equal rights and criminal justice? These and other considerations are central to professional journalism responsibility and enlightened public choice making. Without question, the media are vital to the effective operation of our democratic system by providing information that should be free of the kind of bias that can distort the public participation process.

Through discussion of principles of media professionalism and ethics, and an examination of some of the hot topics featured in today's headlines, this course will set a framework for recognizing and analyzing media narrative framing, as well as the representation of traditionally marginalized groups within that narrative frame. Ultimately, we will develop a deeper appreciation of media responsibility. Just as important, we will expand our sense of media literacy in considering a path forward?whether as professional journalists, or engaged citizens?as we navigate the challenging terrain of an increasingly diverse society, one in which we all can appreciate the value of social difference and multiple perspectives.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course centers on the excitement and challenges of major event coverage, in this case reporting on the NBA's All-Star Weekend events in Chicago. It is the only time all year when all of the biggest names in the sport are in one place. The goal is to make the most of the rare access to the major figures. Students will produce videos and written stories for a special page on Medill Reports, in addition to having the opportunity to do freelance work.

In this course, students will:

Learn how to generate and discover unique stories

Work with editors/producers from story assignment to coverage to completion on deadline

Learn interviewing techniques for press conferences/large media gatherings

Hear tips from some of the top journalists in the NBA field

Model professional conduct amid media throngs who exhibit varying degrees of ethics

Pitch stories for freelance work

Be observant to file away material for future stories

name: Special Topics
topic: Global Visual Journalism in Buenos Aires

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This Medill Explores course offers students a unique opportunity to immerse themselves for a week in Buenos Aires, a city rich in colorful history and culture that is currently struggling with an economic crisis. The focus of the work produced in the class will be on visual, cultural stories, but the reporting will be deepened by readings, discussions and explorations of broader social issues, geopolitics and ethics.

The central focus of the class will be the Anthony Bourdain series Parts Unknown, which aired on CNN for several seasons before Bourdain passed away in 2018. The richly visual series?which took inspiration from a different style of filmmaking in each episode?was creative and beautifully written, produced and edited.

Students will emulate the CNN series in their work, developing stories in advance with the help of facilitators in Argentina who will also accompany them on their reporting/shooting days. In addition to doing their own stories in pairs, students will have cultural excursions to get to know the city, meetings and visits with people and locations in the Buenos Aires episode of Parts Unknown, and sessions to deepen students' knowledge of Buenos Aires, Argentina and Latin America.

In this course, students will:

Research, report and deepen their knowledge of global reporting, exploring a different and more creative way to present non-fiction documentary/news video/television.
Broaden their journalistic view of the world through first-hand experience in video reporting.
Learn to engage effectively and ethically with people in an unfamiliar community, culture and/or setting.
Learn industry best practices with faculty, local producers and fixers, directors of photography and editors from the Parts Unknown series.
Produce short video stories that connect classroom learning with the experience on the ground.

name: Special Topics
topic: Social Justice Investigations Primer: Medill Inves

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A VICE News team covering a protest group in Turkey is arrested for aiding a terrorist organization. A BBC reporter in Thailand is accused of criminal defamation for a story on a property scam. Whether you are a foreign correspondent reporting on hate speech in France, a backpack journalist covering war in Iraq, a sportswriter on the FIFA World Cup beat in Russia, or part of a Panama Papers-style global reporting consortium, journalists abroad confront unique legal risks and dilemmas. This seminar will take students around the world to examine major laws and cases involving freedom of expression and of the press that shape the practice of journalism within and across borders, especially those in its trouble spots where journalists abroad frequently go. It will examine international legal trends in topics journalists need to know to avoid themselves becoming the story, including defamation, privacy, national security, anti-terrorism, and more, and build on foundations laid in JOUR 401-0-20/21 (Ethics & Law of Journalism). The seminar will also address global regulatory controversies arising from the internet's impact on journalism, such as the manipulation of social media to spread "fake news." Readings and other class materials will be provided. A final project examining an issue or event can be an article (such as profile of a jailed journalist), op-ed, case-study, audio, video or graphic.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The 2020 midterm elections are around the corner. Amid one of the most complicated and intriguing periods in modern U.S. political history, the stakes are high, the personalities intense, the issues significant and the outcome unknown. This seminar is designed for you to develop valuable skills in political journalism and to produce portfolio-worthy coverage as the Democratic primaries unfold. We will establish a particular focus on South Carolina, the destination of our Medill Explores trip, which will take place Feb. 8 - 15. Expect to explore reporting strategies and political issues, going into the field to cover the election and issues important to voters. Along the way, we'll study policies, personalities and political messaging, going far beyond the horserace coverage that too often dominates headlines and substitutes for meaningful and thoughtful work that matters to voters and the republic. For your final project, expect to choose an issue that matters to you and go deep, potentially drawing on your South Carolina reporting. Analyses, questions and random notions that challenge the conventional wisdom are encouraged.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this class, multidisciplinary teams of design and journalism students will imagine and prototype new approaches to local journalism for underserved communities. The big picture issue being addressed is that without robust local news, citizens will not have the information they need for their everyday lives about their community's government institutions, schools, businesses and neighbors. Students will begin from an extensive user research brief developed with grant funding from the Local News Initiative. In the class, students will iteratively generate ideas, creating prototypes and gathering feedback to hone their concepts. This course focuses on imparting methods, brainstorming, rapid prototyping, user testing, business models, and engineering concerns that impinge upon products that meet the information needs of local citizens.

This is the first quarter of a two-quarter sequence. Students who enroll are encouraged to continue in Spring quarter. Ideas which show the most potential will go on for further development in the Knight Lab and have potential to be implemented at local news organizations affiliated with the Local News Initiative.

https://localnewsinitiative.northwestern.edu/

name: Special Topics
topic: The Intersection of Culture and Sports

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is a look at the intersection of culture and sports and how it impacts our coverage as reporters as it pertains primarily to three very different professional sports entities in the PGA, NBA and NHL. The centerpiece of the quarter is a fully-immersive four-day trip to Los Angeles in which students will attend and cover the Genesis Open PGA tour event, an L.A. Clippers game and either a Kings or Ducks game. We will also visit with various media professionals in L.A. In preparation for the trip, we will cover a Chicago Wolves AHL game and hear from a variety of professionals in sports media.
In this course, students will:

Research, report and deepen your knowledge and ability to cover sports, specifically professional golf, basketball and hockey.

Broaden your journalistic view of sports through first-hand experience in both an individual and team reporting framework.

Learn interviewing and reporting strategies for event coverage

Report on the various differences among the PGA, NBA and NHL

Learn to better communicate with your audience by analyzing three pro sports with uniquely different behaviors, etiquette, management perspective, and cultural and racial diversity among athletes, media and fans.

Use what you have learned to better understand the challenges of women's sports.

Produce stories that will be published in Medill Reports or other outlets either during or after the trip.

name: Persuasive Images: Rhetoric of Popular Culture

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course analyzes persuasion in the business of popular culture. The student is introduced to strategies and tactics that influence audiences in a fragmented and competitive marketplace through public communications, advertising, and marketing. The subject material includes film, television, celebrity, music, the Internet, social media, shopping centers and supermarkets, car lots, sports, fashion, and other everyday media and entertainment communication experiences.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1) Boorstin, The Image, 1992, Vintage. ISBN: 0679-74180-1
2) Crothers, Globalization and American Popular Culture, Rowman and Littlefield, 2017. ISBN: 978-1442214965
3) Rein, Kotler, Hamlin, and Stoller, High Visibility, McGraw Hill, 2006. ISBN: 0-07-145680-5

name: Rhetoric, Democracy & Empire in Classical Athens

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Study of Thucydides, Plato, Aristotle, and Aristophanes to understand perennial problems regarding the role of speech in a democratic society.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1) Thucydides, History of the Peloponnesian War
2) Plato, Gorgias
3) Aristophanes, Lysistrata

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar focuses on public commemoration as a rhetorical phenomenon. We will consider questions like these: How do societies remember the past? What do the strategies for remembering the past teach us about the present? How are "collective memories" produced and challenged? Seminar participants will read and discuss a broad range of contemporary scholarly literature on commemoration and also will practice skills in critical reading and analysis.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: VanderHaagen, Sara C. Children's Biographies of African American Women: Rhetoric, Public Memory, and Agency. Columbia: University of South Carolina Press, 2018.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, students implement tools of philosophical analysis to interrogate basic, taken-for¬-granted premises about human language and communication.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook in required for this course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
We are surrounded by technologies that support our everyday interactions.
Facebook and Twitter provide persistent services for exchanging personal information, Snaps can be compiled into stories that provide insight about your last 24 hours, ubiquitous and tangible computing environments allow objects to adapt to our everyday experiences, and new collaboration technologies enable people to work together on projects when they are thousands of miles apart. The design of such systems, however, is not simply a technical question. In order to successfully create these systems, we need to understand how people work, play, and communicate with one another in a wide variety of situations. This course illustrates the practice of understanding human interactions that take place both with and through technology; and it explores the design, creation and evaluation of technologies to support such interactions. Course topics include: design processes, prototype construction and technology evaluation techniques. Specialized topics may include social software and collaborative systems, value-sensitive design, and agent-based technologies. No programming experience is necessary. There will be occasional labs to explain technical content. Course requirements include short hands-on exercises, two exams, and a group project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required. Readings will be provided via canvas/in class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers material related to communication in the workplace. It is designed for seniors who are entering the workplace.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required for this course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course focuses on the management of nonprofit organizations. Topics include (a) the dynamics of the social sector, (b) identifying stakeholders, (c) governing and leading nonprofit organizations, (d) communication strategies for enhancing capacity, (e) organizational assessment, and (f) obtaining and managing resources. Students will self-select into teams working on specifically identified projects for clients.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Worth, M. (2018). Nonprofit Management: Principles and Practices. 5th Edition. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goal of this upper-level undergraduate seminar is to survey sociological research on online news.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required for this course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course focuses on the impact of culture on child and adolescent development. As media has become such a ubiquitous part of childhood in the US, much of this course will focus on the effect of media on child development including the impact that television, video games, computers, and touchscreen devices have on child social, emotional, cognitive, and health development. This course will enhance your understanding of child development and media effects. Secondly, during this course you will be encouraged to apply novel, critical thinking skills to interpret academic research articles and put children's media research in a broader, applied context of policy and education.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course will discuss the issues (problems, challenges, and opportunities) arising from the confluence of commerce, culture and politics under the current regime of globalization. The current phase of globalization is primarily driven by economics forces leading to a world-wide integration of markets and finances and by technological innovations shaping mobility and connectivity in our knowledge-based world. The course begins by critically attending to a set of techno-economic features of globalization, and then addressing cultural and political issues that arise with globalization.
The course will focus on following four topics: the new dynamics of global production, the new dynamics of global marketing and consumption, the new dynamics of circulation and cultural economy, and the new geography of jobs and economic inequality.
Since we live in a world primarily structured and propelled by global capitalism, we will (while discussing topics noted above) focus on a group of intriguing and powerful global corporations and their practices (both commercial and cultural): Amazon, Apple, Walmart, Uber and others.
The current phase of globalization (assuming that it gathered steam and became noticeable in 1990s) has been accompanied by a socio-political reaction called "the anti-globalization" movement. This is not a monolithic movement. It has many strands and differing agendas. This movement, in its initial phase was largely dominated by the activists from the political left. However, in its current phase the anti-globalization movements in Europe and USA are often led by the political right as evident from BREXIT and the election of Donald Trump. We will also discuss this general topic.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This writing seminar provides opportunities for research projects on the topic of environment, climate, and the various campaigns and candidates in the 2020 USA election cycle. Research can be conducted on specific elections or candidates at the federal, state, or local level; or on a specific topic or several topics found in a range of elections and/or candidates. The major project is a research paper of about 2,500?3,000 words. Some smaller assignments such as PowerPoint slides and discussion board postings help build your research for the final project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required for this course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Pop culture and entertainment media influence our expectations, beliefs, and knowledge about health and healthcare in both conscious and unconscious ways. This course examines how media representations and celebrity influence shape social and cultural meanings of health topics. We will also explore how media can intentionally be used to communicate public health information to audiences. This course will offer a multidisciplinary theoretical approach to examine the intersection of health communication and media studies to investigate the consequences of mediated health messages on audiences in the context of pop culture and entertainment media.

This undergraduate research seminar is a quarter-long writing-intensive course designed to provide the fundamental processes of applying theoretical and methodological frameworks to engage with entertainment media and pop culture critically. Students will have the opportunity to identify the implicit and explicit framing of a health topic in a media artifact of their choosing and formulate an argument for how framing affects our understanding of this health topic. Effective writing skills will be practiced through an iterative writing and peer-review process. The focus of this course is to provide students an overview of multi- disciplinary approaches to studying health in the media and media contexts in which health topics are culturally relevant for communication scholarship.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required for this class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: With the increasing threats to the future of our planet and humanity, including global warming, preventable diseases, and limited resources, effective science communication is the ethical responsibility of all scientists. However, effective and ethical science communication is only possible with compassion, willingness to engage with the public, and making meaningful connections. Throughout the quarter students will learn more about tools they need to be better communicators. They will also work on their topic of interest as it relates to science communication and craft a fifteen-page final paper, while also learning more about skills related to developing a research paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required for this class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We live in an information age, with computers of unprecedented power in our pockets. This course seeks to understand how information shapes our lives today, and how it has in the past. It does so via an interdisciplinary inquiry into four key information and communication technologies?print, telegraphy, broadcast radio/TV, and the internet?to understand the origins, development, and impacts of information in society. It will be jointly taught by faculty in Communication Studies and History.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is investigates the contribution of fan studies and fan fiction to media and cultural theory. )ur course will examine how fan studies
? has been a key space for understanding how taste and cultural discrimination operates
? has increasingly been a site of investigation for researchers trying to understand informal learning or emergent conceptions of the citizen/consumer
? has shaped legal discussions around appropriation, transformative work, and remix culture
? has become a useful window for understanding how globalization is reshaping our everyday lives.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required for this class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Each quarter, multidisciplinary teams of students, faculty, and professionals come together to collaborate in the Knight Lab Studio to produce cutting-edge digital work, research, and thought, innovating across every part of the media-making process. The Lab places students together on diverse teams to work on an important problem for the future of media, rapidly moving beyond conversation and hypothesis to well-reasoned action during the quarter. Our process combines user and audience research, design thinking, critical and analytical work, iterative building, storytelling, new technology, and a healthy dose of experimentation?often within the confines of a single, specific problem. Projects are open by application. Full project details and application available at studio.knightlab.com.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required for this class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore the ways that relational partners communicate about health, cope with health-related problems, and influence one another's health-related behaviors. By the end of this course, students will be able to articulate strategies for generating successful or beneficial health-related communication among interpersonal partners (as well as recognize problematic communicative behaviors). The capstone assignment will allow students to champion one health condition and work in a small group to teach the class about key communication behaviors.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required for this class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Human anatomy, physiology, and neurology in relation to communicative behavior. Sensory, perceptual, cognitive, and motor processes. This course is intended to introduce students to basic neurophysiological principles related to human communication. Basic mechanisms underlying the function of the nervous system beginning with single cells and progressing up through simple reflexes to more complex functions related to speech-language-hearing will be addressed. Sensory systems including the auditory, visual and somatosensory systems will be discussed in context to their relevance to communication and communication disorders.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No prerequisites

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Upon completion of the course students will be able to:

Describe mechanisms of neuron action potential generation and propagation.
Describe mechanisms of synaptic propagation.
Describe mechanisms of muscle contraction.
Describe the mechanisms underlying simple reflexes.
Describe how the sensory systems function (i.e., vision, somatosensory and hearing).
Identify associated disorders of vision, hearing, motor and cognition that may impact on human communication.
Discuss language and associated disorders and their impact on communication functioning.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture format with encouragement of class discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There are two objective mid-term examinations and a final exam

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required Text:

Bear, M.F., Connors, B.W. and Paradiso, M.S. (2015). Neuroscience: Exploring the Brain, 4th Ed.: Baltimore: Lippincott, Williams & Wilkins Publishers.

name: Biological Foundations of Speech and Music

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to audiology, which is a branch of science that studies hearing, balance and their related disorders. Its specialists, known as audiologist, are trained health-care professionals that specialize in identifying, diagnosing, treating and monitoring hearing and balance disorders. Audiologists use various testing strategies to determine whether an individual can hear within normal limits or if a balance problem exists. If a hearing loss or balance problem is identified, audiologists determine the region(s) of the system that are affected and the extent of the disorder

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No prerequisites

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Describe the field of audiology and many of the sub-specialty areas.
Relate basic principles of sound to human hearing.
Relate hearing disorders to the structure and function of the auditory system.
Describe the different types of hearing loss and their causes.
Describe evaluation procedures used in audiology AND hearing screening protocols identified in speech-language pathology (SLP) Scope of Practice documents.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Cochlear implants and other implantable hearing devices. Candidacy, device management, and performance with various devices.
There continues to be advances in the development of implantable auditory prostheses. Such prostheses include cochlear implants, bone conduction implants, middle ear implants and auditory brainstem implants. Some of these devices are capable of providing access to sound to individuals who have hearing loss that is too severe for hearing aid amplification. Other devices are designed for individuals with less severe hearing loss and can provide additional benefits over traditional amplification.
The goal of the course is to provide the student an opportunity to learn about the development of these technologies, to understand the technical aspects of each device and to consider the advantages and disadvantages of each with regard to candidacy criteria, management and outcomes. Most discussion will revolve around clinical considerations for the practicing audiologist.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Currently enrolled in the Doctor of Audiology program or by instructor permission.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Identify the hardware of the implantable auditory prostheses, understand their function, and use the devices according to manufacturers' specifications and recommendations
Identify candidacy criteria for cochlear implants and other implantable devices used in children and adults
Identify the critical components of a rehabilitative management plan for individuals with hearing loss who do not benefit from traditional hearing aid amplification
Discuss relevant literature in the field of implantable devices
Discuss current issues facing clinicians and researchers who work with either individuals with implantable devices or technical aspects of the device itself.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers the knowledge and skills required to select, fit, adjust, and validate hearing aids. In the first half of the class, we review hearing aid technology and the decisions based on that technology. In the second half of the class, we consider fitting and adjustment of the hearing aid.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: CSD 423-0 or consent of instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
At the conclusion of this course, the student will be able to:

1. Describe hearing aid types, component parts and systems

2. Describe and conduct measures of hearing aid electroacoustic performance

3. Describe hearing aid candidacy in children and adults

4. Describe hearing aid fitting considerations in children and adults

5. Describe how to evaluate hearing aid benefit

6. Describe factors to consider in counseling new hearing aid wearers.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides an overview of potential etiologies and characteristics of language disorders in children from infancy through adolescence. There is a focus on assessment, diagnosis, and effective treatment of children with specific language impairments, autism spectrum disorders, and cognitively based language impairments as well as the interplay between language, learning, and literacy. Emphasis on the integration of normative data, scientific knowledge, and clinical practice.

descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: CSD 495 utilizes both lecture and active learning formats. Students are expected to prepare for (i.e., complete required readings and assignments) in order to participate actively in class discussions and activities. Every effort will be made by the course instructor and TA's to establish scholarly debates, especially on selected case studies. The format is intended to help students develop critical thinking and problem solving skills. For most lectures, visual and audio materials including PowerPoint slides, video and audio recordings will be used to enhance classroom learning. The reading load for the course is commensurate with graduate training. The required course readings and activities are designed to complement and to supplement information presented in the course lectures. The course is designed to provide multiple formats for students to express their knowledge of the course content. Assignments, lectures, and course materials have been designed purposefully to link theoretical content from the course to clinical translation. The assignments for the course map directly onto the course learning objectives. While the intention of the course is to provide students with the theoretical foundation required for clinical practice in the areas of acquired neurocognitive and neurolinguistic impairments, students will demonstrate this knowledge in assignments and examinations based largely in clinically relevant tasks (e.g., case reports/summaries, mock clinical reports, designing therapy and assessment plans, designing and delivering individual and care partner education/training materials and plans, etc.). This course will: ?Examine the neural bases and characteristics of acquired linguistic and cognitive disorders, including aphasia, dementia, traumatic brain injury and right hemisphere syndrome; ?Explore how normal language and cognitive systems are fractionated by brain damage; ?Focus on assessment, diagnosis, prognosis, treatment and recovery processes associated with these disorders; ?Emphasize the integration of normative data, scientific knowledge, and clinical practice.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Upon successful completion of this course the student will be able to: ? Identify and describe the neural mechanisms of normal language and cognitive processing; ? Describe potential etiologies of and factors associated with acquired linguistic and cognitive disorders; ? Describe linguistic and cognitive characteristics, prognostic indicators, and recovery processes associated with acquired disorders, including aphasia, dementia, traumatic brain injury, and right hemisphere communication impairments; ? Describe appropriate assessment principles and methods for adults with acquired language and cognitive disorders and select proper tests for evaluation and differential diagnosis; ? Administer, score, and interpret assessment tools used for evaluating adults with acquired disorders, including aphasia, dementia, traumatic brain injury, and right hemisphere communication impairments ? Summarize and evaluate intervention strategies for adults with acquired disorders, including aphasia, dementia, traumatic brain injury, and right hemisphere communication impairments; ? Choose and justify language intervention targets for adults with acquired disorders, including aphasia, dementia, traumatic brain injury, and right hemisphere communication impairments; ? Demonstrate specific treatment strategies for adults with acquired disorders, including aphasia, dementia, traumatic brain injury, and right hemisphere communication impairments; ? Consider the experience of having an acquired linguistic or cognitive disorder from the perspective of the speaker; ? Describe the psychosocial impact of acquired linguistic and cognitive disorders and discuss components of education and counseling for patients, family, and other professionals.

name: Research Foundations in Communication Sciences and Disorders

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This discussion-based course provides students exposure to essential concepts in designing and interpreting research in Communication Sciences and Disorders. Students will be actively engaged in selecting research articles of interest to them and evaluating the research design. These research articles will be discussed each week. In order to gain additional experience analyzing and synthesizing a body of work, students will also complete a systematic review in an area of interest to them.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Enrolled in the CSD PhD program

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Upon successful completion of this course, the student should be able to do the following:

1. Choose a research design to answer a scientific question.
2. Weigh the strengths and weaknesses for different research designs based on the research question.
3. Critically appraise published research across different methodologies.
4. Perform replicable literature searches.
5. Synthesize a body of literature systematically.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
This is a discussion-based course in which students will actively evaluate research articles each week. All lectures are pre-recorded and are available on Canvas. Each week students will:
(a) view the week's lecture,
(b) read a chapter or article about a specific research method,
(c) read at least one example article illustrating the specific research method in the student's area of interest, (d) select an article using the specific research method and prepare a critique of this article,
(e) post this article on Canvas for peers to read,
(f) skim the 3 other peer selected articles, and
(g) present the critique to the class.

In addition, throughout the course students will complete a systematic review related to an area of interest.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The final grade will be computed based on performance during in-class discussions and the final paper

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Gravetter, F., & Forzano L. (2016). Research Methods for the Behavioral Sciences - 5th Ed
