descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Development and execution of project relevant to clinical audiology. First Quarter: critical review of clinical research. Second Quarter: research methods for audiology. Third Quarter: professional writing and communication.

COURSE DESCRIPTION: CSD 570-3 is the third of three seminars designed to assist Doctor of Audiology students in the execution of an applied research project in clinical audiology. During this quarter students continue data collection activities associated with their Capstone project and explore methods of information dissemination, including writing for journals and preparation of professional presentations. CSD 570-3 activities will be conducted under the direction of each student's Capstone Committee, with the course coordinator providing additional instruction and monitoring of progress.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
LEARNING OBJECTIVES:
At the conclusion of this course, the student will be able to:
1) Implement methods of data collection appropriate to his/her individual project
2) Describe data analyses appropriate to his/her individual project
3) Write an abstract and review of literature for a manuscript to be submitted to a peer reviewed journal
4) Complete a submission for a professional presentation

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
COURSE REQUIREMENTS:
1) DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS
Student Continues and/or Completes Data Collection and Analysis Under Supervision of Committee

2) PROFESSIONAL PRESENTATION SUBMISSION
Student Prepares a Submission for a Professional Presentation of Her/His Capstone Project

3) MANUSCRIPT ABSTRACT AND REVIEW OF LITERATURE
Student Prepares a Manuscript Abstract and Review of Literature for Her/His Capstone Project Using Format of an Approved Peer-Reviewed Journal (proposed journal submitted for approval; abstract and review of literature.

4) INTERIM REPORT
Student Prepares an Interim Report of Capstone Progress (follow interim report format of previous quarters

5) PRESENTATION
7 Minute Presentation Summarizing Project Progress

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this course is to provide the advanced audiology student with supervised clinical experiences supported by continuing academic training. By the end of the Externship, students are expected to consistently demonstrate clinical competence across the scope of audiologic practice with minimal guidance from his/her preceptor(s).

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Doctor of Audiology students register for CSD 580: Clinical Externship during each quarter of their third year. CSD 580 is a 3.0 unit course which must be taken for a grade.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the Externship, students are expected to consistently demonstrate clinical competence across the scope of audiologic practice with minimal guidance from his/her preceptor(s).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: On a quarterly basis AuD students will visit the Evanston campus for participation in (a) a Core meeting with faculty and staff; (b) case and experience-related presentations to the class, faculty, and staff; and (c) a day-long seminar with a visiting scholar. Visiting scholars will be on campus for a two-day series of meetings, lectures and seminar, typically on a Thursday and Friday. Details of speakers and dates will be provided.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 80% of the grade comes from the externship mentor's evaluation of student progress, 20% from participation in weekly discussion posts.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Please note, students may be required to complete additional academic and clinical activities dependent upon their individual training needs as identified by externship preceptors and on-campus faculty and staff.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Viewpoints is an improvisational framework which helps individuals and ensembles expand their field of perception and develop a flexibility of response. Through physical practice with the fundamental materials of performance, participants cultivate presence, spontaneity, awareness, and articulation. This course focuses on the integration of physically-based approaches into both experimental and traditional performance. Ideal for actors, directors, choreographers, devisers, and other creative artists.

descriptions.value: This course will explore traditional Flamenco dances, the historical and social context in which it is performed, and will identify these dances by their steps, rhythm and musical style. Students will be able to perform some Flamenco dances and become aware of dance etiquette, dance terminology, background, steps, style and patterns.

Either flamenco, Mexican-folklórico, or character shoes are acceptable and required for this class (for best comfort and sound shoes must all have no less than a ½ -inch tall hard heal).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is a Level 1 technique class, designed to teach and deepen knowledge of the body's potential, agility, strength, and expression. This course will include investigations into core ballet and modern positions and sequencing, release technique, floor work, improvisation, and composition. Modern I will strengthen each student's: awareness of their body patterns, ability to work somatically, confidence utilizing weight and momentum, and clarity in articulation. This class may serve as either an introduction into or a continuation of a rich, full body dancing practice.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will give students an understanding of the language of business by studying key aspect of economics, accounting, and corporate finance. With that foundational knowledge in hand, students will explore how best to project the future of their venture and prepare an overall plan. Translating a creative concept into the language of finance is the key skill needed to launch any idea, as every potential funding source asks for certain financial information. This course will teach students how to frame creative activities with the language of business and speak intelligently about the financial data behind any new creative enterprise.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The creative enterprises are in the midst of a revolution. Technological innovation and globalization have
spawned new ways of creating and distributing content. Making sense of the ongoing transformation of the
creative enterprises and the corresponding business models are the focus of this course.

This class introduces business models in creative enterprises and builds upon other courses that students
have taken in the program. Students will analyze case studies of creative enterprises to determine viable
strategies and opportunities. The class also examines the role content plays in strategy implementation.
Students are taught frameworks for understanding and evaluating content and media platforms.

The modern creative enterprises environment will be highlighted via Yellowdig, and students will hear
firsthand from executives, who will describe their business strategies. Additionally, each student will craft a
detailed business analysis of the creative enterprise of their choice and work collaboratively with a group of
students on a case study presentation to bring together the key lessons from the course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: MSLCE students only.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Creativity, Inc., 2014 by Ed Catmull, ISBN: 9780812993011

The Content Trap, 2016 by Bharat Anand, ISBN: 9780812995381

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Entertainment Industry Economics: A Guide for Financial Analysis by Harold Vogel, 2011 (8th Ed.)

Blockbusters: Hit-making, Risk-taking, and the Big Business of Entertainment, 2013 by Anita Elberse

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is a unique opportunity for students who are highly motivated and committed to their personal development and growth as a leader. Students are lead in small groups through a series of assignments that will help them increase self-awareness and gain clarity about their unique leadership skills, values, strengths and limitations. Each class will consist of group discussions and peer coaching exercises around self-reflective assignments. In addition, students meet one-on-one with a Leadership Coach.

This course meets for the first 5 weeks of the quarter and attendance at all five sessions is mandatory for enrollment.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Creative enterprises continually seek the financial resources necessary to achieve their goals, and leaders of those organizations face options: which organizational structure is best to meet our needs? Which sources of revenue are worth pursuing - and which may not be relevant to our institution? In a fast-changing environment, how will we evaluate options and risks such that we stay on the path to financial success?

In this course, students will investigate strategies for revenue generation within the creative industries, as well as approaches to raising capital. We will evaluate non-profit, for-profit and hybrid structures and create frameworks for identifying appropriate revenue sources for each. Ultimately, this course will help students build their evaluation and executive decision-making skills, preparing them for leadership roles in creative enterprises.

The course is structured in a seminar format, in which lively classroom lecture/discussion and hands-on learning takes the place of traditional, one-way lecture. Grades are based on attendance, class participation, a series of short written assignments, and a final project: creating a revenue plan for a specific creative enterprise.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1. Jonathan Gander. Strategic Analysis: A Creative and Cultural Industries
Perspective. Routledge, 2017. ISBN 978-1-138-18527-2.

2. Terry Flew. The Creative Industries: Culture and Policy. Sage Publications,
2012. ISBN 978-1-84787-576-1.

3. Michael Rushton. Strategic Pricing for the Arts. Routledge, 2015. ISBN 978-
0-415-71367-2.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Cultural institutions play a unique role in our society, and are more important than ever. But they, alongside individual artists, are facing increasing pressure and are being asked to do more with less. This course introduces students to the non-profit cultural landscape and will explore the strategic decisions with which cultural nonprofit leaders must grapple, particularly during this contemporary moment. The course begins with an overview of the nonprofit sector and the primary leadership roles. Students will learn about the fiduciary and normative roles of board members, gain an understanding of the funding landscape for non-profit cultural organizations, and will understand typical responsibilities of chief executives and artistic directors and board leadership. The course will explore management and strategic challenges that are unique to the cultural nonprofit sector through case studies, hands on experience, and discussion.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Artistic and creative enterprises encompass an ecosystem of commercial, not-for-profit, community and personal engagement with arts and forms of creative expression. Vital aspects of this ecosystem address the public purposes of arts, which include initiatives, stakeholders and institutions that affect - and are affected by - public policies. Arts and cultural leaders operate within this complex environment on the local, national and international levels. This course will look at a selection of current policy matters that artists and art leaders are dealing with within the U.S. In addition, students will engage with policy matters of their choosing with relevance to their own professional interests, within the U.S. and beyond.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Registration priority is given to students in the MSLCE program. External students may enroll with program permission.

Most items can be accessed through Canvas, with the item's specific location detailed in [brackets]. No textbooks are required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The goal for this course is simple: submit a piece of academic research for publication by the end of the quarter. The piece should (obviously) be original. You should be the primary person responsible for the research and should be the lead or sole author of the submission.

The course and assignments are structured to help you cultivate (more of) the skills, wisdom, and experience necessary to publish independent, original, and high-quality scholarship in relevant venues for your work. There are several milestones to help you measure your progress towards manuscript submission at the end of the quarter. The seminar will be run as a workshop in which you will produce written work and provide feedback on each other's work every week. Most weeks, we will also read and discuss materials related to the crafts of designing, conducting, writing, submitting, reviewing, revising, and publishing scholarly research. The experience will probably feel like a combination of a writing bootcamp and an extended group therapy session.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Becker, Howard S. Writing for Social Scientists. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Ubiquitous networks have transformed fundamentally the way we experience and interact with the world. Network science aims to capture the essence of this interconnectedness. This graduate seminar is centered on reading articles that represent cutting edge research on social, communication, and economic networks. It covers the following topics: the role of connectedness in success, superstars and influentials, recommendation, crowd wisdom and herding, teams and collaboration, machine learning, and experimentation on networks. Students learn about a selection of techniques for exploratory visualization, statistical modeling, stochastic simulation, text mining, and predictive analytics. The studied methods are useful across a variety of fields in which aggregate human behavior and network effects play a crucial role.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

name: Special Topics Research Seminar
topic: Environment and Climate Issues in MTS

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This Ph. D. seminar investigates environmental and climatological issues in relation to the field of Media, Technology, and Society. The seminar is organized into five themes, with a book and additional readings ( additional readings provided via Canvas) for each theme: Land (Schwoch, Wired Into Nature); Sea (Starosielksi, The Undersea Network); Sky (Jones-Imhotep, The Unreliable Nation); Animals (Benson, Wired Wilderness); and Humans (Latour, Down To Earth.) In addition to readings, discussions, screenings, and in-class presentations, students will conduct research relevant the themes of the class and their own Ph. D. research trajectories.

descriptions.value: Doctoral seminar on special topics at the intersection of communication / media studies, and science and technology studies

descriptions.value: This doctoral seminar will facilitate student learning of theories, strategies, and methodology in communication used to design and evaluate messages about health in various contexts and for various stakeholders.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is for graduate students who will conduct qualitative research on the behavioral and social aspects of technology use and technology design. The objective of this course is to give MTS and TSB students practical, hands-on experience with observation, interviewing, and qualitative analysis techniques. The course is run as a working seminar. Students are expected to collect their own qualitative data throughout the term. Students are also responsible for selecting and leading discussion on weekly readings. Assignments throughout the term will allow students to apply the methods discussed in class. In addition to four assignments, students will submit a final course paper in which they are expected to apply the methods learned about in the course.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The increasing role that algorithms and automation are playing in the production of information is rapidly changing the ways in which the news media is authored, curated, disseminated, and consumed. This graduate seminar provides an overview of the latest developments in algorithmic news media on topics including journalistic data mining, automated content production, news bots, platform dissemination, and algorithmic accountability and transparency. Themes of value-sensitive design, labor, and sustainability will be discussed with respect to how algorithms impact the public sphere.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Overview of class

The course studies the performance of poetry, short fiction, and non-fiction. It explores how performance helps the performer and audience to understand a text; it considers in what ways a performance can "match" a written text; and it examines the techniques of performance. Students write three critical papers and give three live, graded performances. There are some quizzes and workshops. The class is neither an acting class nor an English class, but it draws on practices fundamental to both. Much of class time will be devoted to performance of texts and rigorous critical discussion of the performances and the works on which they are based. Consequently, attendance is mandatory. It examines the role of the audience in the critical reception of the text. The course is designed for both students with little prior performance experience and those with considerable theatrical experience.

It is an excellent course for students to take who want to become excellent communicators; it hones your professional skills and gives you the poise and confidence to excel in the "real world."

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course asks the question: How are stories and storytelling central to our lives and to human communication? We will explore how storytelling performances reflect our families, communities, culture, and nation. To engage the power and significance of storytelling performance we will focus on three units: (1) Oral Narrative. Students will learn how to conduct in-depth interviews, on a particular topic, to gather oral narratives and their meanings from specific family, friends, or community members. (2) Myth. Students will read and discuss ancient and contemporary myths to unravel deeper questions about local and global experiences. (3) News Reports. Through guided instruction students will select a current news story, from electronic or newspaper journalism, they feel reveals an urgent issue they are compelled to share. Each of the three units will culminate in a performance: a solo performance of an oral narrative, a group performance of a myth and, finally, a multi-media group performance of a news story. The course is highly interactive and performance based. The unifying thread and overarching question for the course is: How does storytelling performance and creative communication help us better engage and illuminate our world and the world of others, e.g., identity, family, community, nation, social relations, political institutions and economic orders?

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course examines the relationship between hip-hop culture and contemporary theatre and performance practices. Looking beyond Broadway productions like Hamilton, we will consider hip-hop's social and cultural function as a tool for grassroots action and as a mode of identity performance. From rap skits, to hip-hop musicals, to visual albums, hip-hop continues to influence and construct theatrical spaces on and off stage. Analyzing these popular cultural forms and more, students will generate a working definition of hip-hop theatre and devise original performances inspired by the aesthetics and philosophies of hip-hop culture.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBD

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We will explore theoretical and practical questions around the intersections of oral storytelling and political organizing: How do personal stories serve as tools of persuasion, build empathy, and demonstrate ethos and pathos? How is the performance of self and oral storytelling central to political organizing? How is personal narrative communicated across various media and interpersonal interactions? What role does race, sexuality, and gender play in how personal stories are crafted, communicated, and received? Students will craft and share their own stories as it relates to a current political leader. Reading and viewing assignments include artifacts from political campaigns and theory around the social and cultural history and function of oral storytelling and autoethnography.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Acoustic experiences are integral to the (trans)formation of modern subjectivity. This course brings critical discourses on listening and sound studies into conversation with performance studies by engaging with critical and phenomenological perspectives on sound, embodiment, and society. We address how listening practices shape identity formation by discussing historical and contemporary studies in sound arts, popular music, and aural traditions, among others. Course readings draw from the fields of sound studies, philosophy, musicology and ethnomusicology, performance studies, and media studies, including texts by Ihde, Nancy, Sterne, Eidsheim, Kheshti, Labelle, Daughtry, Hirschkind, and Kapchan. Listening materials range from soundmaps, podcasts, and other popular expressions to sound installations and performance events by artists such as Francisco Lopez and Lawrence Abu Hamdan that challenge issues of representation and power. Finally we will craft our own listening practices through weekly prompts as an effort to amplify our work as researchers, artists, and listeners.

name: Topics in Performance Studies
topic: Trash! Hoarding, Bad Object Orientations, and Perf

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Buried Alive and Hoarders. Marie Kondo and the Minimalists. Big-screen TVs, fast fashion, and floating islands of plastic trash. The promises of decluttering, downsizing, and shrinking homes.

From fantastic depictions of people overwhelmed with their accumulation of things to popular self-help books that promise freedom and joy in the form of a clean home, this course is concerned with the judgments we make about people and their relationships to their stuff.

In this course we will begin to unpack "abject object orientations" by investigating the "hoarder" as a pathological figure that emerges within the 20th century. By looking to depictions of the hoarder and other "material deviants" across performance art, film, and memoir we will describe the cultural logics through which speaking of a person's orientation toward objects becomes a way of making ethical claims about them. Placing the abjectified figure of the hoarder alongside depictions of the collector, the archivist, and the artist, students will theorize the ways that race, gender, class, and sexuality shape our judgments toward, and even help to produce, shared object orientations.

For major assignments, students will be asked to prepare autoethnographic performances and compositions unpacking their own relationships to things, grounding these works the materials of Northwestern's University Archives Special Collections, Chicago's Leather Archives and Museum, and local thrift and resale stores. No previous performance experience is required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Frantz stirs to say to the world, "And then I found that I was an object in the midst of other objects." Adrian looks at him before she replies, "The more I assimilate [as much of that external world, as other, into my sense of self], the more easily I am able to see myself as an ?object in the world among others." A quiet pause and then, from another room, Hortense's voice cuts the air, "What one is after, by way of a certain sustenance of attention, is the presentness of the object in all of its internal difference, in all of its interiority and internal space." Read against the backdrop of a host of the overlapping racial and colonial histories of objectification?histories that often continue to hurt?this course will engage theories of racialization and object relations in fields of thought that include (but are not limited to) performance studies, queer and feminist theory, decolonial theory, black studies, Marxism, and psychoanalytic theory. We will engage the work of Hortense Spillers, Frantz Fanon, Saidiya V. Hartman, Fred Moten, Adrian Piper, Jodi Byrd, Lisa Lowe, Karl Marx, José Esteban Muñoz, Dorian Wood, Sandra Ruiz, David L. Eng and Shinhee Han, Melanie Klein, Adrienne Kennedy, and Theresa Hak Kyung Cha.

descriptions.value: This course introduces students to foundational production and post-production concepts and techniques. Projects will include audio and video assignments and the production of short documentary and narrative films. Through lectures, assignments, in-class exercises and screenings, critique sessions, and accompanying technical labs, students will gain a good understanding of the fundamentals of filmmaking. This is a supportive environment where students are encouraged to take risks and experiment as they discover their voice as visual storytellers. Students will have opportunities to work both individually and collaboratively.

descriptions.value: The course will provide students with a working knowledge of the fundamentals of screenwriting. Students will learn how core concepts of character, structure, plot, theme, and tone work together on the page to create narrative. Students will explore these concepts and their practice in film, as well as how they might utilize these concepts to express their personal voice and vision.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course surveys the history of international cinema from its emergence through the 1950s. We will explore the diverse forms cinema took and functions it performed during this period by looking closely at a range of films and writings about them. We will examine the industrial, social, and historical contexts within which these films were produced and experienced as well as theorizations of cinema that emerged concurrently with them. The course thus introduces students to the study of film history as well as to key national and international trends in making and thinking about cinema as it rose to prominence as a vital component of the art and culture of the twentieth century.

Topics covered include the cinema of attractions; the development of narrative filmmaking in the United States and Europe; the studio systems of Hollywood and Japan; exhibition practices; the concept of national cinemas as exemplified by the cinemas of France, Germany, and the Soviet Union; the avant-garde and cinema's relation to art movements; the coming of synchronized sound; documentary cinema; and diverse conceptualizations of cinema's political possibilities and dangers.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students should be able to identify and analyze major movements in film history through the 1950s, evaluate scholarly approaches to historicizing cinema, and conduct a research project pertaining to the history of cinema.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, short written assignments, research paper, final exam

Kristin Thompson and David Bordwell, Film History: An Introduction, 2nd,3rd, or 4th edition
(ISBN: 978-0071151412, 978-0073386133, or 978-0073514246)

name: Doc Film History & Criticism
topic: Art of the Real: A History of Documentary

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course tracks a (limited and imperfect) history of documentary that explores nonfiction film as an art form. Throughout the course, we will bring seminal films in dialogue - and in collision - with contemporary and/or lesser-known works that resonate with related themes, philosophies, formal strategies, geographies, cultures, agendas, atmospheres, and etc. We will place an emphasis on exploring diverse possibilities of nonfiction films as well as on the politics and ethics of representation. Screenings and readings will be intensive, and rewarding for both graduate students and motivated undergrads (undergrads are welcome to enroll with instructor permission).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Learning objectives include: to strengthen your understanding of a major strand in the weave of film history; to develop your strength and stamina as a film viewer; and to expand your awareness of the wide variety of social, political, cultural, and philosophical issues nonfiction filmmaking has dealt with throughout its development.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Students will be asked to write short response papers, partner with a classmate to lead discussion on an assigned week, and produce either a final research paper or final media project in conversation with films viewed in class.
