descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This survey course will explore some of the most potent, groundbreaking, funny, inspiring, and thought-provoking international documentaries directed by women. Social justice, autobiographical, cinema verite, hybrid, and traditional forms of documentary are featured to examine topics such as gender, sexuality, race, art, history, philosophy, politics, and the environment. Arab, Asian, American, Latin American, European, and African women filmmakers are included. From Academy-Award winners, to a girl with a toy camera - you'll find them all in this course. This lecture course requires no production skills. Final projects may be either a research paper, or a digital project. Cross-listed with Gender and Sexuality Studies.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the movement of musicals from the stage to the screen and from the screen to the stage. Students will explore the motivations behind such adaptations, the methods used in executing them, as well as the social, cultural, and economic effects/implications of the creative decisions involved in such a transfer.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated based on attendance, quizzes, discussion participation, short written responses/papers, a midterm analytical paper, and a final creative group project. Students will be expected to view films, listen to cast recordings, as well as read librettos and supplementary materials.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Most course materials will be provided via Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The Czech New Wave was one of the most fertile and original periods in Central European cinematography. In the 1960s a young generation of directors captured the imagination of audiences and critics at home and abroad. The New Wave encompassed a variety of revolutionary styles that have made their way into the repertoire of directors around the world. Produced under a reforming but still repressive regime, the films elegantly pushed the boundaries of the permissible by subtly weaving their messages into dramas of daily life and romantic love. Over time the directors, and the new generation of actors who worked with them, ventured into politically more accented topics like critisism of social realism and the consequences of communist policies for ordinary people.
The Wave filmmakers included V?ra Chytilová, Ivan Passer, Ji?í Menzel, Jan N?mec, Jaromil Jire?, and, the most famous of the group, Milo? Forman, who fled communsit Czechoslovakia to become of the leading directors in Hollywood. Two New Wave productions garnered the Academy Award Oscar for Best Foreign Film (Shop on Main Street and Closely Watched Trains). Others were locked away by Communist censors after the Soviet invasion of August 1968 and had to wait 20 years until the 1989 Velvet Revolution for their first screenings.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Class attendance, participation, journals 25%
Two medium-length papers (4-5 pp.) 40%
Final Paper (6-8 pp.) 35%

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Called "one of the pre-eminent national cinemas in the world" in the 1990s both by Toronto International Film Festival and New York Film Festival, Iranian postrevolutionary cinema is a vital productive activity with its own special industrial, financial, and professional structures and unique ideological, thematic, generic, and aesthetic values, which has evolved over the decades to encompass several different types of cinemas. One of these is the "art-house cinema" that is widely viewed and praised outside the country. This cinema is part of a more general transformation in the political culture of the country since the revolution of 1978-1979, but it is founded on the fertile grounds of a cinema that preceded the revolution, the "new wave cinema." Both the new wave and the art-house movements were agents in the Iranian discourses and social formations of modernity. This course examines their emergence, evolution, and diversity, including key auteurs, genres, and representation of women, in the context of Iranian national aspirations, contact with the west and the rest, and the Islamic religious values and a rich tradition of visual and performing arts.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This is an experiential course. In the Second City style, students will focus on acquiring and honing improv techniques to be used to create short-form sketches. Lectures and discussions will focus on comic theory, writing for the current moment, interior joke writing, with a focus on rewriting for performance.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation; quizzes on techniques learned; a completed packet of scenes and desk pieces, as well as a final performance grade.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Screenwriting software. The Comic Tool Box by John Vorhaus, published by Silman-James PR, copyright 1994; ISBN: 978-1879505216 Improvise: Scene from the Inside Out by Mick Napier, published by Meriwether, Englewood, CO, copyright 2004; Second Edition: ISBN 978-1-566608-198-6

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: We will attend one improv/sketch show together. Price of admission will be kept as low as possible.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Learn the history and technique of performing comedy and develop weekly ideas into a cohesive, humorous stand-up comedy set. Methods of honing and editing comedic writing will be taught, practiced, and tested in weekly class exercises and homework assignments in pursuit of a final "tight five" (five minute set) at the end of term.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly in-class writing exercises and performances, peer feedback/workshopping, 3 short response papers, final 5-minute performance and final reflective essay.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbooks are required for this class; all readings will be available as PDFs on Canvas. Students are asked to please obtain a physical notebook for weekly journaling and in-class writing exercises, as laptop use will not be permitted during class time.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Streaming service subscriptions are not required, but will drastically increase the number of comedy special options for students' required response papers (alternatives will be available to stream on Canvas for students without access to Netflix).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this class, we will develop practices for mining our own rich and complex personal histories to
create material for the screen and stage. Through writing and select acting exercises, we will
explore ways to overtly and covertly use memory to help create compelling narratives. We will
look at examples of contemporary plays, film, and television in which writers use elements of
biography to ground fictional works.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
There will be weekly assignments which include writing assignments, readings, films, and
television shows. Each student will be expected to write four short (3-10 page) scripts, and at
least one complete one-act play, short film, or pilot episode, which totals 25-30 pages in length,
and is drawn, in small or large part, from personal history.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
? The Three Wells of Screenwriting by Matthew Kalil (ISBN-13:978-1615932863)
? Long Day's Journey into Night by Eugene O'Neill (ISBN-13: 978-0300093056;
ISBN-10: 0300093055)
? Additional readings and films available on reserve and online via CANVAS.
Internet access, NU email/account, word processing program, and xeroxing of materials required
for writing workshop and class discussion .

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This class will explore the craft of playwriting, with a specific focus on the creation of
unexpected and surprising play structures. While the other concepts of playwriting, such as plot,
tone, setting, and dialogue, will be discussed, our emphasis will be on the process of creating
inventive and brave new forms of storytelling for the stage. We will read all new plays that
premiered in the last ten years.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
There will be weekly writing and reading assignments. Each student will be expected to write
five short (3-10 page) scripts, and at least one complete one-act play which totals 25-30 pages in
length.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
? An Octoroon by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins ( ISBN-13: 978-0822232261; ISBN-10:
082223226X)
? The Nether by Jennifer Haley (ISBN-10: 0573703914; ISBN-13: 978-0573703911)
? The Shipment and Lear by Young Jean Lee (ISBN: 978-1-55936-356-3)
? Additional readings available on reserve and online via CANVAS.
Internet access, NU email/account, word processing program, and xeroxing of materials required
for writing workshop and class discussion .

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An exploration of how fantasy, horror and the supernatural are developed and written for film, television and the stage. By tracing genre history and examining the recent popularity of all things "monster," students will learn how to create effective stories that resonate with a modern audience. Through script analysis, discussion and media presentation, the class will culminate with a student created full-length fantasy, horror or supernatural final script.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: RTVF 260: Foundations of Screenwriting

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Written assignments, class participation and final written project

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures, discussion and writing assignments

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
The Woman in Black by Stephen Mallatratt
ISBN-10: 0573040192

The Weir by Conor McPherson
ISBN-10: 1559361670

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Learn how to build, navigate and create a story that bridges script writing skills with the audience-driven narrative of video games. Through an overview of the history of video game storytelling, an analysis of what has worked in the past and what the future holds for the dynamic medium, students will learn how to engage players via emotional involvement in the game's interactive connection. The class will culminate with a student-built video game project and multiple game story ideas.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: RTVF 260: Foundations of Screenwriting

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Written assignments, class participation and final written project

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures, discussion, writing assignments and game assignments

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Slay the Dragon: Writing Great Video Games by by Robert Denton Bryant and Keith Giglio
ISBN-10: 1615932291

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students will study character, story, plot, dialogue, scene structure and screenplay format in an effort to create an original feature length screenplay. The course will include reading, screening and discussion of feature films. Students will create a logline, treatment, character biography and generate approximately 60 screenplay pages to be shared, in a workshop environment, for critique and feedback.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
? To understand the process of developing a story for the visual medium.
? To understand screenplay structure and form.
? To understand the importance of character in regards to plot development.
? To understand/implement visual/aural elements while crafting an original feature length screenplay.
? To appreciate the script's contribution as a necessary blueprint of a successful film.
? To understand the elements of screenwriting.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Final grades will be based on a combination of class attendance, class participation, various story development written assignments, and approximately 60 screenplay pages.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: This is a workshop class where students learn primarily through practical application. Any/all course reading will be made available via free electronic PDF handouts. Script pages are expected to be written with screenwriting software (Final Draft, Movie Magic, or Celtx). Celtx can be obtained for free via download. Students will be required to generate PDF files for critique and review. Adobe Acrobat can be obtained for free via download. Access to a computer outside of class will be necessary to participate.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Because class attendance and course grade are demonstrably and positively related, regular attendance for this class is essential. Both writing and reading in a workshop setting is a social art, and students will be required to collaborate heavily in this capacity.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is an intense writing workshop focused on developing and creating the TV Pilot.
Elements will include idea and character development, series outlines and completion of a pilot
script between 28-44 pages depending on format. This course requires weekly writing
assignments.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
REQUIRED FORMATTING SOFTWARE: FINAL DRAFT 11 Educational Downloadable at:
www.finaldraft.com.
SCRIPT RESOURCES: Will be provided in Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an intense writing workshop focused on developing a one-hour, dramatic network-level series. Participants will not be developing their own ideas, rather they will be assigned an idea to develop as a group into an original 12-part series. Focus will be on all aspects of the writers room, including development of characters, themes and outlines for the series. As a final writing project each participant will write and polish one episode. Do not register for this class unless you are able to attend all classes and feel you are able to complete weekly writing assignments.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
REQUIRED FORMATTING SOFTWARE: FINAL DRAFT 11 Educational Downloadable at: www.finaldraft.com.

SCRIPT RESOURCES: Will be provided in Canvas.

name: Introduction to Acting for the Screen

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce RTVF and Theater students to the craft of acting for the screen. With an emphasis on the actor/director relationship, it will address practices for creating and portraying characters as well as the more technical concerns of how actors place themselves in relationship to the camera for the most effective appearance onscreen. Students in this course will perform in (and, in some cases, direct) a number of exercises to build acting skills in front of the camera, in projects - both in-class and out-of-class - designed to focus on cinematic storytelling achieved primarily through performance rather than primarily through directorial technique, cinematography, editing, and sound design.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: A retrospective critique of curricular and extracurricular performance work in the Acting for Screen module. Course will involve evaluation of performer's range and capabilities in terms of future projects and identity as an actor, as well as a further advanced study of the relationship between the actor and director relative to the camera and an exploration of the film/TV casting process. Course will culminate in a self-edited actor reel for real-world use.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, in-class scene work, out-of-class film projects, compiling of material and reel production

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course will introduce students to the fundamentals of digital non-linear editing. The
emphasis of the course will be hands-on practice through a series of projects. There will be several
in-class screenings, readings, and a significant amount of time spent editing to develop your
abilities. Finally, this class is the first step to finding your own "voice" as an editor.
The projects in the class will offer experience with several different editing strategies and
techniques. They are designed to develop conceptual and technical proficiency, as well as the
working skills, strategies, and discipline necessary to provide a foundation for further exploration.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Students will be graded according to their ability to satisfactorily complete these projects in the
time frame allotted, as well as through: attendance, discussion and participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Available from NU Bookstore, Barnes & Noble or new/used from Amazon, et al:
In The Blink Of An Eye (Walter Murch, 2nd edition, Silman-Jamnes Press, 2001)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
- Although not required, a USB3 drive (7200 rpm) might be helpful if you intend to work on
any of the projects at home, if you own Premiere. Any extra media brought in for a project
(music, pics, et al) should be stored to your Scratch server and backed up to external drive.
- Not required but suggested: a USB Flashdrive. You MUST make back-ups of all your project
files throughout the semester, and although you should always save your Premiere projects
on the Scratch server, it's always best to also have an off site backup.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: All brands focus on their visual brand identity but as voice and other forms of audio become an integral part of our lives, a brand's sound is becoming increasingly important. Simultaneously, sound has become easier to embed into myriad contexts, tangible and intangible, resulting in products that use sound to communicate not only their form and function, but also their identity as an extension of a brand. Beginning with the roots of sound branding, from early radio jingles and network chimes, through to today's rich landscape of marketing channels, digital products, and voice devices, this class will explore the art and science of sound branding. Our guide will be Steve Milton, the co-founder of Listen, a NYC-based sensory experience company, and a pioneer of this emerging field. Mr. Milton's lectures on the current state and future of sound branding will be our point of departure for a series of readings, listenings, experiments, discussions, and design assignments. The two largest projects involve the end-to-end creation of a brand's sound design, and creating a speculative sound design for a product of the future.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- understand how sound design shapes our perception of product function and brand identity
- learn the process of evaluating, producing, and delivering a product/brand sound design
- understand the current state of the expanding field of sound branding, and how it may evolve in with technologies and strategies that are on the horizon

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance and participation, 2-3 smaller assignments, one mid-term project in three phases, and one final project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All course materials will be provided in-class via links or by Canvas, and any needed equipment will be available via checkout the RTVF Cage or in the university computer labs. Students should not expect to pay for any additional materials.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this course, we will merge virtual and physical worlds and we will design fiction or non-fiction storytelling, game, art pieces that create or benefit from virtual reality, alternate and fragmented reality.

VR offers a spherical visual and audio sensorium and consequently an uninterrupted and deep possibility for immersion; players' physical actions have corresponding outcomes in the virtual world; surprises or dramatic outcomes can be embedded outside the peripheral vision of the player; player's point of view is the camera which can move anywhere freely; 360-degree large scale environments can be created and experienced cost and risk free. All these qualities offer a vast set of expressive opportunities that can contribute to constructive social change.

This production class will include tutorials about QR codes, Virtual Reality (HTC Vive, Tilt Brush, Gravity Sketch, 360 filming and editing for VR, WebVR). In addition to these tools, participants can use any existing low or high technology such as USPS mail system, email, augmented reality apps, SMS, tattoo and t-shirt design, Morse code, Skype, Google image search, sound recordings, Siri, film and video, photographs, music, flash mobs, live actors, etc. Class participants will design a short virtual, alternate, or fragmented reality experience that purposefully blurs reality and fiction and narrates a story.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Along with the production of a short virtual, alternate, or fragmented reality experience and demo video, we will read assigned theoretical text exploring the concept of the flâneur, psychogeographic drifts, theory of the dérive, affordances and limitations of interactive narratives, parallel universes, fragmentation of time and space. We will also explore seminal pieces (site-specific and location-based art, performance pieces, walks, music videos, collaborative games, alternate reality film promotion campaigns). Class participants will respond to the readings with written questions/answers. Participants will also make presentations about assigned artifacts.

Participants may choose to collaborate for their Final Project. No coding skills are needed.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All readings will be available online via CANVAS.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is an introduction course for understanding computer code for producing games, media art installations, interactive narratives and all types of digital creativity.

This course is specifically designed for beginners (participants who have no background in programming) and it introduces the expressiveness of computing to visual artists, web, and game designers. We will use an open source environment called Processing, learning the basics of procedural thinking while creating games and interactive art. The course will enable participants to create their own tools for interaction and movement and enhance their understanding of basic design principles. After taking this course, participants will find it easier to mesh code for game design, media arts, and web design and create pieces with aesthetic appeal.

Participants who do not plan to pursue programming will acquire the essential knowledge about procedural thinking and will gain tools to communicate efficiently with programmers so that they can establish interdisciplinary collaborations.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: In addition to weekly design assignments, we will explore interactive games and art works via presentations of participants along with assigned readings.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Processing: A Programming Handbook for Visual Designers and Artists, Edition: 2, Casey Reas, Ben Fry ISBN: 9780262028288 Publisher: MIT Press Publication Date: 12/26/2014 Amazon $31.55. Barnes and Noble

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to web-based media through the practical use of web code, video, image editing, and animation. The course will explore different expressive media such as software, moving image, and performance, as well as show how these strategies can work in concert with each other online. Students will have the opportunity to conceptualize their own projects and select from a menu of approaches in order to execute them. Projects can include works created for the screen, the web, participation with web media at a specific site, or an event-based web work in public. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and unit projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior experience creating web media, although students with experience are welcome to enroll.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the quarter students should have a strong understanding of contemporary developments in web media and culture. Students should also have a working understanding of different tools for expressing their own ideas through web media as an individual production practice. Students should also be able to discern what tool and approach is appropriate and effective for a given concept, as well as how to seek out additional resources on their own.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All required software will be available on lab computers. Readings will be provided electronically through Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this course, we will view non-fiction and hybrid films that revolve around crime, criminal justice, and criminal court cases. Our emphasis will be on cases that are either mired in controversy and/or emblematic of wider social concerns. Readings will accompany viewings and experts will weigh in with legal, philosophical or scientific perspectives: What is accurately depicted? What is omitted? What is misrepresented? Concurrently, we will investigate the films aesthetically: How is the film structured and why? What choices are being made by the filmmaker in terms of camera, sound and editing and how do these choices affect viewers? Throughout the course, we will consider the ethics of depicting real people and traumatic events. We will also look at specific films in regard to their legal or societal impact. Assignments will include a series of short response papers and a substantial final project, which can take the form of either (up to the student) a final 12-15 page paper or an 8-12 minute film or podcast. The final should center upon a legal topic. Ideas include, but are not limited to: A comparison of two films depicting the same criminal case, a polished/edited interview with a person somehow connected to a crime, an investigation of a local court or legal advocacy center. Group projects (two people max) will be allowed.

Please note: For students who have not completed RTVF 190, if you choose to create a film or podcast for your final project, you may either use your own gear or, pending availability, you may reserve equipment from the Northwestern Library: http://libguides.northwestern.edu/circulatingequipment/summary. Technical skills such as lighting, camera, sound, and editing will not be taught in this class.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: For RTVF students, RTVF 190. LS and HUM students do not need that prerequisite

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture and Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Attendance, class participation, professionalism: 20 points Three short papers,10 points each: 30 points
Final project proposal/pitch: 10 points
Final Project: 40 points

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: For students who choose to create a short film or podcast for their final, supplies, and equipment are their responsibility. Provided they have filled out a deposit card, students who have taken RTVF-190 may check out gear from the RTVF cage. Non-RTVF Students can check out equipment through the Northwestern Library: http://libguides.northwestern.edu/circulatingequipment/summary. Students creating media project finals must back-up their work on a hard drive (approximately $60) and turn in their projects via Vimeo (basic membership is free, but if you use more than 5GB (500 MB per week), you will need to upgrade your membership https://help.vimeo.com/hc/en-us/articles/224818307-Basic-membership.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Attendance at first class required

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This production course teaches the One Person Crew approach to documentary making: recording picture and sound alone in the field. To make a documentary takes access and intimacy with your participants. Working solo has the potential to yield great trust from those in front of the camera, but it is also fraught with technical challenges, producing pitfalls, and directing difficulties. In this course you will learn to develop and produce ideas suitable for the one-person crew, and how then to distribute this work as producer. Grab your multiple hats, because you will be wearing them all as you successfully complete a short documentary in this course as Producer/Director/Cinematographer/Editor. Works from renowned solo filmmakers will be screened as example, with readings assigned that illustrate key concepts.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Written production plans and a midterm will be included in the curriculum

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will explore graphic animation and special effects work including text and title animation, basic 2D animation, motion tracking, camera tracking, compositing effects onto video footage (including green screen work), and combining 2D and 3D animation and effects with video footage. We will do this using Adobe After Effects and its related suite of plug-ins and partner apps (including Mocha and Cinema 4D).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Please note that this class requires quite a bit of computer time and attention to detail. That said, I like to create a workshop atmosphere - I expect you to be leaning over to watch each other's computers, checking different approaches and techniques, asking questions out loud rather than raising your hand, finding new and different approaches online and sharing them with the class, and generally helping each other along.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: You will make a presentation, work on several in-class exercises, complete a project, and complete a final exam project. There is the likelihood of some quizzes to make sure you are keeping up with the material.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Required materials: None

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: Recommended materials: External hard drive

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will focus on story conceptualization and the nuts-and-bolts technical execution of horror cinema made with big ambitions and tiny budgets. A reliable vehicle for social commentary, psychological probing, philosophical speculation, surrealism and straightforward fantasy, horror stories not only maintain a more consistent and durable popularity with audiences than any other cinematic genre, but its imagery and traditions offer great flexibility in style and tone that make it ideal for imaginative filmmaking on extremely limited means. The course will cover special effects, the grammar of suspense, acting for horror, and of course developing engaging stories from our deepest fears and desires, through practical labs and screening/evaluation of films made in the low-budget trenches from the late '60s through the present. This course experience can be adjusted to count as an elective in the Acting for Screen Module for Theatre and RTVF students who focus on performance in the class's short film projects and in-class exercises.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Exercise of film production skills in shooting, editing, and sound design primarily oriented to creating emotional effects of suspense and surprise; development of acting techniques to fit a variety of tones and purposes in the genre; exercise of techniques for special effects and expressionistic illusions; designing screen storytelling to deliver on concept and emotional engagement with limited available resources.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Completion of short film assignments, class-participation, oral reports on filmmaking techniques used in films screened.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Films screened in class are the primary "textbooks" for the course and will be complemented with course reserve readings and links to written and audiovisual resources relating to these films. Students may spend up to $150.00 per person on production necessities (which may include some specialized makeup supplies, for example), but as an emphasis will be placed on low-budget methods and styles, shooting assignments should not be costly. Any money spent by students will go into shooting projects, at student discretion, NOT on textbooks or other required materials.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: All films will be shown in class, in screening/discussion sessions open to any non-disruptive members of the RTVF community and will also be made available for viewing online via CANVAS.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is one of the cornerstone classes of your production experience in the film department at NU. You'll be introduced to Super 16mm film via the Arri SRII. You'll master the bulk of the lightin and grip equipment in the cage. You'll learn about light, color, lenses, emulsion, and film stocks. As well, you'll review the Panasonic HPX.In addition to the technical side of cinematography, you will begin to explore the artistic side of this art. You will expand on your work in 190 by examining framing and composition, light and shadow, and color as they apply to the moving image. You will work rigorously on your ability to translate meaning, story, and idea into image. As well, you will gain more experience in the collaborative process which is critical in the filmmaking arts.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to the theories and principles of basic sound production. Through demos, lectures, readings, screenings and exercises, students will be exposed to all of the basics of sound recording technology: the physical properties of sound, microphone design and technique, recording technology, basic mixing and effects, playback and output, and relevant techniques for working in diverse environments for different types of sound recording. Students will practice various forms of active listening, both to develop troubleshooting techniques and a more sophisticated approach to sound production. Students will need access to a computer to complete some of the assignments and readings will be posted on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course introduces students to the basic theories
and techniques necessary to conceptualize, edit, and mix sound in a post
production environment.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students successfully completing this course will:
demonstrate proficiency in mixing, editing, and processing of digital audio
for visual media; demonstrate an understanding of digital audio workstation
(DAW) signal flow and session management; exhibit creative and
professional sound design practices in their work.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Students are evaluated based on class participation,
in-class labs and exercises, and sound design projects.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
No textbook is required for this class. Readings will be
provided by the instructor via the course Canvas page. Students will need
to bring: circumaural, wired headphones of appropriate quality ($65 to $95),
and a backup drive with a capacity of at least 32GB ($7+).

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Admission to this class is through a submission process only. Juniors who are interested in the Senior Directing sequence should apply in the spring quarter.

This course is a two-quarter sequence in which each student focuses on directing a short film of greater ambition and scale than is normally feasible to complete in a single quarter. The student will demonstrate the ability to conceive, plan and execute the overall storytelling (e.g. screenplay development, directing actors, implementing audiovisual design, editing, etc.) required for the project and continue to develop their own personal methods and practices of filmmaking to develop their voice as an artist as well as engage in constructive critique of their classmates' work.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Admission to this class is through a submission process only. Juniors who are interested in the Senior Directing sequence should apply in the spring quarter.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Through in-class presentations and critiques, as well as one-on-one consultations with the instructor, the following will be emphasized: screenplay development, audio-visual design, directing (especially working with actors) and pre-production preparation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Judith Weston's Directing Actors: Creating Memorable Performances for Film & Television. Michael Wiese Productions, 1999. ISBN: 10 0-941188-24-8

Required Class Materials:
- External hard drive (at least one is required: two is recommended)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introductory seminar on history, theory, and criticism of video games. Individual works and movements will be studied through a framework that combines methods from media studies, game studies, and art history. We will situate the emerging medium of video games in a context that acknowledges multiple histories and discourses rather than defining video games as any single practice. We will distinguish between how video games extend traditions and ideas of artistic exchange and how they offer novel and unexplored modes or communication unique to the medium. The course is designed to engender an active and critical perspective on historical and developing game practices and how they relate to other cultural contexts through analysis, discussion, writing, and playing.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. This course will introduce students to the field of game studies and the history of games. Students will demonstrate their awareness of these concepts through weekly reading assignments, written responses, and discussion leading.
2. This course will equip students with critical and theoretical frameworks for investigating interactive media artworks. Students demonstrate their grasp of frameworks through presentations and discussion on their selected research subject and method.
3. This course will develop critical writing skills. Students demonstrate their proficiency in this by researching and writing the final essay, as well as the frequent reading responses.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings will be provided electronically through Canvas

name: Symposium: Issues in RTVF
topic: The History of the Recording Industry

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore the history of the recording industry from the invention of the phonograph in 1877 to recent developments in digital audio. We will examine the social, cultural, and technological factors that have shaped the development of the recording industry, and consider musical genres such as jazz, blues, rock, swing, country, muzak, dub, EDM, hip hop, and K-pop. We will consider the production, distribution, and reception of recordings, tracking the changing ways in which sounds have been produced, sold, and consumed. Recordings of popular music will be our primary focus, but we will explore synergies with the film industry, radio, gaming, and other digital forms. Some of the key themes in the course will be the intersection of sound industries; the tension between independent and major labels; questions of copyright and creativity in popular music; the relationship between technology and innovation in sonic arts; and the increasing mobility and cultural ubiquity of recorded sound. Looking back across a "century of sound" allows us to gain a deeper appreciation of our current immersion in recorded music, and to better understand some of the central debates and dynamics that have shaped the recording industry.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course students should be able to:

Understand and appreciate a wide range of sound recordings in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

Apply a historical understanding of the recording industry to current practices, companies, and artists.

Think critically about the role played by recordings in everyday life.

Apply lessons learned about the recording industry to other creative industries.

Create an original and well-informed analysis of a significant aspect of recording history.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be assessed through: 1) short response papers assigned throughout the quarter; 2) quizzes that cover material from class readings, lectures, and discussions; 3) a midterm and final research paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
David L. Morton. Sound Recording: The Life Story of a Technology (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2004).

Steve Knopper. Appetite for Self-Destruction: The Spectacular Crash of the Record Industry in the Digital Age (Soft Skull Press, 2010)

Other readings and audio files available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: When we consider the subject of children's media culture, we quickly discern a host of contradictory behaviors and attitudes: childhood is seen as a period of timeless wonder, but children are bombarded with all the latest fads and newest gadgets; we try to insulate children from the adult world, but provide them with media technologies that allow them easy access to it; we want kids to be kids, but are thrilled to introduce them to the consumer marketplace through toys, advertisements, and media franchises. This class will explore contradictions such as these by placing discourses around childhood and children's media within their broader cultural, social, and historical contexts. We will discuss a wide range of media texts, including film adaptations of classic children's literature, children's television, digital games, children's music, and online video. These case studies will allow us to engage with debates about contemporary media culture and interrogate differing perspectives on the nature of childhood. Children are often understood to be a particularly vulnerable segment of the media audience, and the investigation of children's media has much to tell us about regimes of regulation and censorship, theories about media influence on behavior and identity, and debates about the media's role in education and marketing. Our goal is to better understand children's media culture and the social institutions and practices that have shaped it, while engaging with this important cultural field through critical analysis.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class meetings involve lecture, discussion, and evening screening sessions. A key objective of the class is to develop skills in researching and writing about the social and cultural meanings of the media through the use of a range of research materials. Students are required to write two essays: the second essay will consist of a substantially revised and expanded version of the first. Some class time will be dedicated to in-class writing activities that are meant to foster a more personal engagement with the topics under discussion. A writing portfolio will consist of several revised in-class writing exercises on topics relating to your personal experiences of childhood and media.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All readings and audio files are available on Canvas. Films are shown during evening sessions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, students will explore what goes into curating, organizing and promoting film/video screenings and festivals, with the goal of producing a public event as a culminating class project. In the past, students organized a Northwestern student film festival as their class project. We will discuss audience engagement, distribution, and outlets (online, broadcast, and brick-and-mortar) and interview programmers, who work for festivals, movie theaters, micro cinemas, and cinematheques. Students will come away with insights about festival strategy for their own films and a solid understanding of the distribution and exhibition phase, allowing them to navigate that landscape more successfully as media makers and potentially as programmers. In addition to the class group project, students will also develop an individual proposal for an event or series that can encompass a wide range of work (audio, new film/video, or even archival material).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will leave the course with a portfolio that includes their interview with a programmer, a written proposals for an event or series, and in-depth documentation of a successfully realized public event that they co-produced.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated based on individual assignments and the culminating group project; as well as attendance and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Coming Soon to a Festival Near You: Programming Film Festivals. Ruoff, Jeffrey. St Andrews Film Studies, 2012. ISBN: 978-1908437020 Paperback edition approximately $22.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What does the information age feel like? This course follows the rise of hyper-modernized cultures of information that developed in Japan and the Western world in the late 20th and early 21st centuries. It does so by attending to the advent of new technologies that defined this period, and also through the rise of "neoliberalism:" an economic and political paradigm prizing the creation of new markets and a focus on the productivity and care of the self. We will attend to a variety of texts and forms (a novel, poetry, a video game, films, and critical writings) that will allow us to follow the history of neoliberalism in its global, national, and aesthetic contexts.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion, Short Lectures

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Essays, Class Participation, Projects

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: *Course Reader * Anne Allison, Precarious Japan 978-0822355625 * Claudia Rankine, Don't Let Me Be Lonely 978-1555974077 * Robert Pirsig, Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance 978-0060839871

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This doctoral seminar explores the cultural history of new media. Paying attention to the digital technologies and forms that have tended to be associated with the label "new media," such as computers and the internet, we will put pressure on the very notions of the "new" and "media" by interrogating the historical situations in which a variety of phenomena?from recorded sound and cinema to video games and virtual reality?have been designated as new media. Doing so will entail excavating the social forces and cultural practices surrounding such designations and considering the ways in which different conceptualizations of new media yield diverse genealogies. Throughout, we will thus undertake our examination of the history of new media with an eye to the theoretical and historiographical questions raised by such a project. In addition to discussing readings in class, students will give an in-class presentation and write a research paper.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Participation, one in-class presentation, and one research paper (18-20 pages)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class explores textual analysis in relation to screen studies. We examine the development of ideas about texts, textuality, and analysis in the context of Euro-American?especially French?cine-semiotics in the 1970s; the methodological self-consciousness of early textual analysis; and the limits and possibilities of an "anti-interpretive" analytic position. We also consider the vicissitudes of textual analysis in relation to questions of media history, theory, ideology, and reception. Some of the guiding questions for the class: What was textual analysis? What is it (or could it be) now? What is the object of analysis in textual analysis? How do you do things with texts?

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides an overview of the major concepts, theories and underlying theoretical foundation of cultural studies. The main objective is to help students understand, first, the classic literatures of cultural studies, including theories, origins, models, findings, representative scholars and their work, and second, the contemporary issues and theories of cultural studies. Finally, students can make use of these theories and apply them into their own research areas.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Upon finishing the course, students are expected to be able (1) to acquire fundamental knowledge on cultural studies, (2) to understand and evaluate work on cultural studies, and to be able to (3) apply cultural studies and relevant theories to develop their research and academic projects.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture + Discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Assignments/ Discussion Papers (2 x 10 points) (2 out of 3) 20 points
In class quiz (only 2 highest scores are counted) (2 out of 3) 20 points
Presentation + Presentation Report 25 points
Final Paper 25 points
In-class Discussion 10 points

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The inimitable filmmaker Dziga Vertov argued that editing occurs not just in post-production but at each phase of filmmaking process: we edit when we select a subject from among other possibilities; we edit when observing the subject during preproduction; we edit by the very act of framing with a camera during production; and we edit in the studio during postproduction. While keeping this expanded understanding of editing in mind, this course is a process-driven lab that offers strategies and perspectives for students to sculpt their existing material towards a final cut.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Learning objectives for students include: expanding your grasp of editing techniques and philosophies; gaining facility with various formal structures; and developing your ability to both give and receive critical feedback.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Students will engage with readings, visiting artists, and film screenings, as well as screen their own works-in-progress in a critique format offering feedback in a group setting.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required Texts: Documentary Editing by Jacob Bricca
All other readings available via Canvas/Course Reserves

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This class will continue in your development as a visual artist in moving images by focusing on advanced ideas of coverage, craft, and lighting. You will focus your personal style and develop it, as well as increase your body of knowledge and skill set in cinematography: lighting, lenses, cameras, and techniques. We will work with advanced lighting techniques and equipment, coverage concepts, and problem solving.



Note: this is not a course designed to teach you how to use a specific camera. Use of almost any camera is acceptable, including any camera you personally own. Cameras from the cage can be checked out based on your particular qualifications / class or workshop completion.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: RTVF 380 is required to take this course.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
We will also watch and dissect films, both short and feature-length, and you will read essays, articles, handouts, and assigned readings from the texts. You are expected to complete the readings; there will be quizzes to encourage you. Discussion of the films is a key part of exploring the craft.

We will also build one or two DIY lights at the end of the quarter for each student to keep.

- Grip materials, including substantial flat-head screwdriver or multi-tool, grip gloves, and gaff tape

name: Seminar: Studies in Film and Video Prod

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Understand basic audio concepts and terminology. - Develop critical listening skills, learn how to effectively discuss sound. - Gain a working knowledge of basic audio technology including microphones, recorders, mixers, and DAWs. Familiarity with audio editing, mixing, and design processes and methods. Develop directing and writing skills in regards to audio production.Understand audio workflows, practices and standards. Develop interviewing and field recording skills. Learn how sound and image work in tandem to tell stories. Provide and incorporate constructive criticism to and from your colleagues.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the second in a sequence of three workshop courses that second year MFA students in Writing for the Screen and Stage will complete during the 2018-2019 academic year. After completion of all three courses, each student will have created at least one full-length project for film, theatre or television.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
During RTVF 565, students writing a feature film or a play will complete at least a first and second draft. Students writing a television project will hone the premise/synopsis for a series, write an outline for the first and possibly second season of the series, write the pilot, and the bible, and dependent on episode length, fulfill any additional writing requirements in consultation with the instructor.

Throughout, we will attend readings of your works and incorporate issues/concepts from those readings into our class sessions.

Plays and Screenplays TBA

Working computer, internet access, NU email/account, word processing program, xeroxing of materials required for class discussions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore the history of the recording industry from the invention of the phonograph in 1877 to recent developments in digital audio. We will examine the social, cultural, and technological factors that have shaped the development of the recording industry, and consider musical genres such as jazz, blues, rock, swing, country, muzak, dub, EDM, hip hop, and K-pop. We will consider the production, distribution, and reception of recordings, tracking the changing ways in which sounds have been produced, sold, and consumed. Recordings of popular music will be our primary focus, but we will explore synergies with the film industry, radio, gaming, and other digital forms. Some of the key themes in the course will be the intersection of sound industries; the tension between independent and major labels; questions of copyright and creativity in popular music; the relationship between technology and innovation in sonic arts; and the increasing mobility and cultural ubiquity of recorded sound. Looking back across a "century of sound" allows us to gain a deeper appreciation of our current immersion in recorded music, and to better understand some of the central debates and dynamics that have shaped the recording industry.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course students should be able to:

  • Understand and appreciate a wide range of sound recordings in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

  • Apply a historical understanding of the recording industry to current practices, companies, and artists.

  • Think critically about the role played by recordings in everyday life.

  • Apply lessons learned about the recording industry to other creative industries.

  • Create an original and well-informed analysis of a significant aspect of recording history.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Students will be assessed through:

  1. short response papers assigned throughout the quarter;

  2. quizzes that cover material from class readings, lectures, and discussions;

  3. a midterm and final research paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
David L. Morton. Sound Recording: The Life Story of a Technology (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2004).


Steve Knopper. Appetite for Self-Destruction: The Spectacular Crash of the Record Industry in the Digital Age (Soft Skull Press, 2010).


Other readings and audio files available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course builds upon the skills learned in Introduction to Sound Production. Through technical tutorials, in-class projects, readings, discussions, and listening sessions we will examine the theory, techniques and practices surrounding audio recording and production. We will focus on advanced tracking, editing, mixing, mastering, and sound design techniques. There will be in-class tech labs and demonstration sessions that will contribute to the development of core technical skills, as well as prepare students for large-scale collaborative studio projects. This course will not only focus on the specific use of Pro Tools and the SSL recording console in the Louis Hall Soundstage, but also prepare students for the ability to translate their skills to any professional recording studio.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course looks at compelling uses of sound in moving-image art, and asks students to challenge the traditional sound-image relationship with projects that put the creation and conception of sound first. Students will look at uses of sound across experimental film, video art, and installation work to gain an understanding of the contemporary landscape. Class time will include case studies of specific artists, an introduction to 5.1 mixing, alternative mic'ing techniques and critiques of student work. By the end of this class students will have a stronger sense of the role of sound in art and experimental films and various new recording and mixing techniques to advance their creative expression.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Develop skills in sound production and post production. Build analytical skills through the evaluation and discussion of experimental film and video art.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation and 3 projects focusing on experimental audio-visual approaches.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All readings posted to canvas as downloadable pdfs.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a workshop designed to help journalists and non-journalists alike create an original audio documentary that can be used as part of their portfolio. The course will begin with three reporting exercises - interviewing strangers, profiling an individual, and finding archival material. Students will then craft a 5-10-minute audio documentary, with substantial feedback from the instructor and their classmates. Students don't need to be journalists, but will use many of the same skills and techniques taught in journalism programs. This is a production-heavy class, so students should expect to spend significant time reporting, editing and sound designing their stories. There will be guest speakers, as well the opportunity to critique seminal and experimental radio documentaries.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
• Students will create original audio documentaries

  • Students will edit and revise their audio documentaries, incorporating
    feedback from their classmates and the instructor

  • Students will gain insight into interviewing and reporting techniques

  • Students will articulate the complicated ethics of documentary work

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on the effort they put into reporting their documentaries, the revisions they make from week to week, their active participation in providing feedback to their classmates, and the completion of various individual audio exercises.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
• Out on the Wire: Ira Glass and Radio's New Masters of Story by Jessica Abel

  • a digital audio recorder

  • over-ear headphones

  • a computer with audio editing software

  • a shotgun microphone


Access to equipment and software can be found with the RTF Equipment Cage and Sound Arts and Industries SoundTank Computer Lab. Refundable $50 deposit is required for Cage access.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Because the course is only ten weeks long, and the second half is devoted to editing and revision, it's critical that students entering the course come on day one with ideas for things (people, places, subjects) that they would like to document during the class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students will learn about modern spatial audio design via the creation of media for a variety of platforms and output formats. Due to the rapidly-evolving nature of this field, this class focuses on the development of solid foundations in the core concepts of Ambisonics and current conventions of audio in XR, providing flexibility for various implementations of the technology. Students can expect to work with ambisonic recording equipment, create spatial mixes in Reaper for binaural monitoring and 12-speaker output, then implement dynamic interactions in Unity (e.g. head tracking, audio source animation, and ambient occlusion). Additionally students will explore event-driven/adaptive sound design techniques in the audio middleware. Class visits from professionals in this growing field will provide additional context for our accumulated knowledge and skills with respect to the immediate future of these platforms.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
• grasp the core concepts of ambisonic audio, and the current state of hardware and software technologies involved with its creation and deployment.

  • use ambisonic technologies and techniques to create virtual sound environments and spatial audio experiences

  • understand where ambisonic audio fits within today's rapidly evolving interactive technology ecosystem

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance and participation, three mid-sized project assignments in varying media formats, one final project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All course materials will be provided in-class via links or by Canvas, and any needed equipment will be available via checkout the RTVF Cage or in the university computer labs. Students should not expect to pay for any additional materials.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course covers the fundamentals of acoustics and its application to design of the built environment. The format is interactive; lectures have images, video, listening, sound creation, sound visualization and sound measurement. There will be one field trip to experience interesting acoustic environments in downtown Chicago and the Arup SoundLab.

We will investigate the relationship between sound and architectural space, encouraging students to think about how different types of buildings sound as well as understanding the impact that sound, noise, and vibration, have on design in the built environment. We will explore the fundamentals of sound and noise: propagation, isolation, control, and mitigation. We will also explore how to use sound as a positive contributor in architectural design - including room acoustics design theory, the effect of shape, form, geometry and material selection on acoustics.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: At the end of this class students will have an understanding of the fundamentals of the science of acoustics and its application to the built environment. They will also be able to apply these skills to evaluating environments for recording and production activities, both subjectively and quantitative using basic acoustic measurement tools.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Select papers will be provided for the class for select weekly lectures. A book list will also be provided for students interested in supplemental reading, though the texts are not required for the course.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: All lecture slides will be made available on CANVAS following the lecture.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Anatomy and physiology of the central auditory pathway, experience-related neural plasticity, right/left brain specialization, audiovisual integration, auditory learning and perception, and neural encoding of speech and music. Cross-listed with CSD 410-0 and SAI 502-0. This course will review the biological foundations of speech and music perception. Topics include an overview of the central auditory system - neuroanatomy and physiology, the acoustic properties of speech and music and how these features are encoded by the nervous system, the effect of cognitive processes on auditory perception and neural encoding, and how these auditory processes are enhanced in auditory experts (musicians/bilinguals) and impaired in populations with learning impairments.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course guides second-year IPTD students through the process of formulating a dissertation project and writing the dissertation prospectus. Topics discussed include research design, writing strategies, time management, and other graduate school and professional survival tactics.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Bolker, Writing Your Dissertation in Fifteen Minutes a Day-$15 | Booth, Colomb, and Williams, The Craft of Research, 4th edition-$15

descriptions.value: A combination of lecture, discussion, and production lab participation implementing the design and directing process of a theatrical production.

descriptions.value: Students are graded on attitude, skill, growth and initiative in addition to attendance demonstrated on their production assignment.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the connections between theatre, performance, and commemoration in the history of Western theatre through the idea of memorial mania, a term coined by memory scholar Erika Doss as "an obsession with issues of memory and history and an urgent desire to express and claim those issues in visibly public contexts." How does memorial mania manifest in the theatre? How do playwrights use historical settings to comment on their contemporary moment? How does performance act as commemorative practice? Are memorials theatrical? To explore these questions, we will examine plays that have dealt with commemoration, history, or memory in some way, read excerpts from Doss' Memorial Mania and from other scholars who examine theatre and memory, and consider why history has been used for centuries in drama.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course investigates the limits, boundaries, and possibilities of theatre by exploring theatrical texts which present complex relationships to live performance. Broadly speaking, the texts we will read and the performances we will watch fall into and transition between the categories of stageless dramas and impossible theatre. Stageless dramas cover written dramas that were arguably never meant to be staged in the theatres of their times, such as Greek philosophical dialogues, closet dramas, and virtual experiences mediated through technology. Impossible Theatre explores plays intended for the stage which contain considerable challenges for performance, including nonsensical stage directions, technically difficult feats, and censor-worthy content. The texts we will read range from tragedies of antiquity to twenty-first-century experiments, providing students with a wide breadth (although not comprehensive view) of Western theatre history. (Content Warning: Some of the texts we will be reading are explicitly violent and sexually graphic.)

name: Theatre in Context: Analysis & Research
topic: The City Space as Performance Space

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course engages with selected performance phenomena in the city space that draw on the specificity of sites, create spaces through performance, or re-articulate or re-signify places in the city space in order to further their goals. Therefore, we will investigate the relationship between bodily practice, social performance, and the production of (architectural) space. The class covers artistic, explicitly theatrical performances as well as processions and demonstrations. Some examples are historical, others contemporary. This juxtaposition enables us to explore in a multitude of research methods and methodologies. Insights gained from the research process of the historical inquiry will enable us to question our assumptions about the use of space in performance today and broaden our range of questions to ask of the performances and sources thereon.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course invites students to explore, think, and dance Blackness through engaging with the affect of scholarly texts that address Dance Studies, African American Studies, Post-Colonial Studies, Black Queer Studies, Afro-Caribbean Religion, and Black Feminist Thought; the majority of the texts authored by Black women. Students will conduct performance analysis, choreograph three dance pieces (two short performances and one final performance), reflect on readings weekly in a course journal, and complete a final research paper (5-7 pages) comprised of a performance analysis on a dance piece of their choosing.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an in-depth exploration of core works of theatre and dramatic theory from the ancient world to the present. It combines direct engagement of primary sources with lectures and seminar-style discussion to foreground the question of what theatre is, has been, and should be in any given historical period. By reading both play-texts and criticism, we will establish a foundational analytical mode for the course that considers specific textual evidence and systematic generalizations about the social and cultural work of theatre.

You may stage manage or assistant stage manage during the quarter that you are enrolled in the course or the quarter following the course. This course is open to every NU student and it is the first course in the Theatre Management Module.

For more information and instructors consent, please contact Barbara Butts at b-butts@northwestern.edu

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the movement of musicals from the stage to the screen and from the screen to the stage. Students will explore the motivations behind such adaptations, the methods used in executing them, as well as the social, cultural, and economic effects/implications of the creative decisions involved in such a transfer. Students will be evaluated based on attendance, quizzes, discussion participation, short written responses/papers, a midterm analytical paper, and a final creative group project. Students will be expected to view films, listen to cast recordings, as well as read librettos and supplementary materials.

name: Theatre and Social Change
topic: State Funded Theatre of the Americas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore how state funded theatre and performance in the 20th century was used to form emerging national, racial, and ethnic identities in the postcolonial period. The class will focus on the Caribbean and the Southern United States, where state funded performance and theatre were used not only as a means of celebrating independence movements, but also used to influence the shape of emerging state identities and national politics. The course will explore how by staging, funding, and shaping the narratives of theatrical performance, states in the Caribbean and the Southern US were invested in performing and cementing new identities that were influenced by pan-African identities, workers' movements, black nationalism, white supremacist holdovers of the antebellum era, and a rejection of colonial values. These often contradictory impulses mirrored the turmoil of the social climate that gave birth to these works. This course is designed as a seminar and will be open to all undergraduate theatre majors (although preference will be given to juniors and seniors if we reach the enrollment cap).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Can humans give life to inanimate objects, or do these objects contain a life of their own? Wherein lies our fascination with puppets and robots that imitate, yet alter the human figure? Humans have long been fascinated with replicating themselves, yet there is an uneasy tension between us and the objects we create. This course will trace the multifarious perceptions of the puppet and related forms (robots, etc.) in history and performance, analyzing recurrent themes that transcend centuries and continents. Students will engage in historical and applied research, analyze performances, develop short puppet pieces, and complete a final research paper.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Bringing new genres of music to the stage, celebrating musicals with the dramatic integrity of plays, and foregrounding questions of identity and social impact...What counts as a musical is rapidly transforming in recent years. In this workshop class, we will draw inspiration from recent trends and work in collaborative teams to write and compose musical scenes and songs for the stage. We will analyze musical scenes and numbers from 21st century shows that are expanding new boundaries for what and how musical theatre can be, and add our own stories and songs to the mix. All levels of experience welcome. (This course can be counted toward the "Creating the Musical" module.)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Theatre Orchestration is an accelerated class in instrumentation, arranging, orchestration, and creative musical design. The class explores the history of orchestration, using the analysis of past exemplary theater orchestration to inform each student's study and practical application of orchestration technique.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Standing Down Straight® for Actors is an injury-preventive, efficiency-based performance technique that guides actors to use gravity-directed relaxation as the foundation of the voice-and-movement work they do in classes, in rehearsals, and on the stage. Standing Down Straight - or, in short, SDS - offers a "less is more" approach to acting training.  It derives from the understanding that the human body has evolved over roughly 3 million years to work with efficiency. ("Efficiency" = using the least effort to achieve a goal.)  So, in this class the relaxation-based exercises and scenework we do involve learning how to work with more power and less strain; with greater animal-like fluency and fewer moments of feeling the energy in our bodies or voices is being blocked.

descriptions.value: We will explore theoretical and practical questions around engaging theater audiences and local communities in the U.S. nonprofit theater industry: How do audiences make meaning at the theater? How can theaters center justice when working with local communities? What are some challenges and best practices for fundraising, promotion, and planning for engagement programs and initiatives? Students will reflect on their own past experiences with theaters in their home communities and an off-campus visit to Victory Gardens Theater. Reading and Viewing assignments include articles, grant materials, marketing campaigns, and creative plans for audience and community engagement, and recent work by thought leaders in the field.
