name: Mathematical Inverse Methods in Earth and Environmental Sciences

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Data-driven modeling via solving inverse problems and estimating model parameters. Application of linear algebra to the modeling of physical data. Students learn to model large amounts of imperfect data using linear algebra, optimization and regularization techniques, and common physical sense. Via lab exercises and homework, the course emphasizes application over theory. Exercises include but are not restricted to 1) locating events or objects from line-of-sight signal travel times, 2) de-blurring an image, 3) characterizing the subsurface from surface measurements of wave dispersion, 4) locating engineering structures from anomalous gravity data, and 5) tomography: non-destructive characterization of internal structure of materials, human bodies, or the Earth. We will emphasize linear, discrete, ill-posed inverse problems, but will also review time series analysis, including Fourier Transforms and matched filtering, and touch on the principles of solving non-linear inverse problems via directed and random searches in model space.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Recommended Background: Linear algebra and differential calculus of multivariable functions.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 80-minute instructor-guided sessions per week and access to the computer lab at other times.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There are no required class materials.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The cycling of biogenic elements (C, N, S, Fe, Mn) in surficial environments is the focus of this course. Emphasis will be placed on microbial processes and isotopic signatures.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: 1 quarter of chemistry plus 1 quarter of either geoscience, environmental science, or biology. Taught with CIV ENV 317; students may not earn credit for both courses.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture and discussion, problem sets and a final paper and presentation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: provided on Canvas

name: Special Topics in Earth and Planetary Science

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Paleobiology: Fossils record the 3.8 billion year history of life on Earth, and extinct organisms make up 99% of all the species that ever lived. The fossil record reveals insights into evolutionary processes and the distributions and structures of organisms and ecosystems that cannot be observed by studying living organisms. This course is an introduction to the concepts of paleobiology: the nature of fossils, evolutionary trends and adaptations, systematics, paleoecology, and biogeography. We will investigate how life, from individual organisms to whole biomes, has changed over time; the geologic processes that lead to the burial and preservation of organic material; and the scientific methods by which we infer the biological processes that occurred across deep time from the limited and often biased fossil record. Course has prerequisites.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Registration is reserved for undergraduates with at least one credit of either EARTH 201 or EARTH 203, graduate students, or undergraduates who have the consent of the instructor.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Introduction to Paleobiology and the Fossil Record. Benton, M.J. and D.A.T. Harper. 2009. Wiley-Blackwell. ISBN: 9781405141574

name: Special Topics in Earth and Planetary Science

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Natural Hazards Policy
Defending society against natural hazards is a high-stakes game of chance against nature, involving tough decisions. How should a developing nation allocate its budget between building schools for towns without ones and making existing schools earthquake-resistant? Does it make more sense to build levees to protect against floods, or to prevent development in the areas at risk? Would more lives be saved by making hospitals earthquake-resistant, or by using the funds for patient care? What should scientists tell the public when?as occurred in L'Aquila, Italy, and Mammoth Lakes, California? there is a real but small risk of an upcoming earthquake or volcanic eruption? This course uses general principles and case studies to explore how we can do better by taking an integrated view of natural hazards issues, rather than treating the relevant geoscience, engineering, economics, and policy formulation separately. We will consider thought-provoking questions that confront the complex issues involved.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Recommended Background: MATH 224 or equivalent calculus

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: "Playing Against Nature, Integrating Science and Economics to Mitigate Natural Hazards in an Uncertain World" by Seth Stein and Jerome Stein (Wiley/AGU, 2014). ISBN: 9781118620823.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: All Earth and Planetary Sciences Graduate Students and Post Doctoral Fellows must complete the Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR) Training in their first year of the program. This course includes 9 online "CITI" modules as well as discussion sections. New students and fellows should contact the Assistant Chair with any questions.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Enrollment limited to PhD students in EARTH and PBC (Plant Biology and Conservation)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No materials needed.

name: First-Year Seminar
topic: Did Economics Win Two World Wars?

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: World War II was clearly the most important single event of the twentieth century. However, the seeds for World War II were laid in World War I, making it necessary to study both wars. We will study both why these wars occurred and why they turned out the way they did. In asking why wars turned out the way they did, we will emphasize the size and performance of the economies involved, and such issues as why the U.S. and Soviet Union produced so much while Germany produced so little. In the last part of the course, students will have a chance to do independent research on any aspect of World War II which interests them, economic, political or military.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: In class discussion of readings. Students will be encouraged to disagree with each other and with the readings as their knowledge of the subject develops. Active class participation is important and counts for 30 percent of the grade.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There are no exams. The class grade will be based primarily on written papers, but 30% of the total grade will be based on the quality and quantity of participation in class discussion. There will be three 5-page papers, and one final paper of up to 15 pages, including at least one original table or graph. Papers will be worth a total of 70% of the final grade.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Most of the reading is available online through the library. In addition there is an inexpensive course packet with some of the readings. The one required book for purchase: Why the Allies Won by Overy, 1997 (ISBN: 978-0393316193)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: I am a senior professor with active ongoing research in macroeconomics, ranging from inflation and unemployment to long-term growth and disputes about macroeconomic theory. I have recently published a big book on the history of the American standard of living. Military history is a hobby, as is second-guessing airline management through a private e-mail chat group that I founded more than 20 years ago.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is an introductory course in economics with an emphasis on macroeconomics. The first, more 'microeconomic' third of the course will cover general topics such as scarcity, choice, how the market system works and the effects of government intervention. This will take us up to the first midterm. We'll then turn to long-run macroeconomics and consider such things as economic growth, unemployment and perhaps the significance of the US current account deficit. This should take us through to the second midterm. We'll then look at money and inflation. We'll finish with short-run macroeconomics, with a focus on the role of monetary and fiscal policy in stabilizing the business cycle. En route, time permitting, we will consider such contemporary issues as the role of economic policy in addressing environmental concerns and the recent financial crisis.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures, TA section.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades are determined by 2 midterms and a final. (grading breakdown: first midterm 30%, second midterm 30%, final 40%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: Modern Principles: Macroeconomics by Cowen and Tabarrok, 2nd Edition. ISBN-13: 9781429239981 (3rd & 4th editions acceptable)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An introduction to economics with an emphasis on macroeconomics (business cycles, inflation, unemployment, economic growth). The first three weeks cover aspects of general microeconomics that everyone should know, including how the market system works, how prices are determined, why shortages and surpluses occur, and basic industrial competition. Topics include: supply and demand, competition versus monopoly, comparative advantage in trade, taxation, and market failures. The last two-thirds of the class build on these tools to study the behavior of the economy as a whole, particularly in an international context. Topics include: inflation, unemployment, recessions, booms, fiscal and monetary policy, budget deficits, economic development of nations, international trade, and exchange rates.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Two years of high school mathematics. Basic algebra and graphing.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures, homework, quizzes, class participation.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two midterms, one final exam, weekly quizzes and homework. You will be expected to follow the economic news because this class covers events that are unfolding in real time.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Krugman & Wells Macroeconomics, 5th edition. ISBN-10: 1-319-09875-4; ISBN-13: 978-1-319-09875-9. Books will be ordered for the campus bookstore but are probably cheaper online.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Further information about the class can be found on my webpage: https://sites.google.com/site/markwitteeconomics/home/economics-201-introduction-to-macroeconomics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is an introductory course that covers the fundamentals of microeconomics. We will study the behaviour of individuals and firms in a world of limited resources, and the interactions between the two in many different markets. With an emphasis on economic principles, students will be introduced to core terminology and modes of analysis for studying the production and distribution of goods and services in the economy. An overarching goal is to gain insight into how, when, and why markets fail or succeed. Specific topics include supply and demand, market equilibrium, elasticity, costs of production, different degrees of competition (including perfect competition and monopoly), and government interventions (price controls, taxes). You will get started thinking about the three fundamental questions in economics: (i) what goods and services should be produced?, (ii) how do we produce those goods and services?, and (iii) who gets those goods and services? This course is aimed at potential economics majors and students who are curious about having a better understanding of the popular press, or analyzing and comparing different government policies.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of this course is to give the students an introduction into the tools and skills that economists use, as well as an understanding of economic concepts related to: Consumer behavior; Firm behavior; Government interventions.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: 2 lectures (80 minutes) + 1 discussion section (Fridays)

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Three examinations (90%), the best five out of six problem sets (5%), quizzes (5%). Midterms will happen in the evening: Thursday, February 6th, and Thursday, March 5th, 6-30 - 8.30 pm.
Weights are subject to change.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Microeconomics by Daron Acemoglu, David Laibson, and John List, 1st edition, ISBN: 978-0321391575.
OR
Microeconomics by Daron Acemoglu, David Laibson, and John List, 2nd edition, ISBN: 978-0134492049

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Formally, economics is the study of the allocation of scarce resources among competing ends. Informally, economics helps us understand how household, business and government decision makers respond to incentives; the importance of proper-functioning markets in a modern capitalist economy; and the role of government in alleviating various market failures. Microeconomics focuses on individual decisions (typically using cost-benefit analysis) and the inner workings of specific markets. Picking up where macroeconomics left off, this course will introduce the principles of microeconomics and teach you how to apply these concepts to real world scenarios. Thus, this course is aimed not only at potential economics majors, but also at any student who desires the ability to understand the popular press, critically analyze government policies, and use microeconomics to make better choices as a consumer, producer, representative, or voter.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: A typical week features three lectures and a discussion section.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two midterm exams (25% each), weekly problem sets (10%) and a final exam (40%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Microeconomics by Daron Acemoglu, David Laibson, and John List, 1st edition, ISBN: 978-0321391575.
OR
Microeconomics by Daron Acemoglu, David Laibson, and John List, 2nd edition, ISBN: 978-0134492049.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to econometrics, a field in which statistical tools and data are utilized in the analysis of economic questions. We will start with simple linear regression, incorporating tools of statistical inference such as confidence intervals and hypothesis testing. Then we will incorporate more variables with multiple linear regression, and explore nonlinear regression functions, binary dependent variables, and other topics. A key part of this course will be learning to use the statistical software, Stata. Students will analyze real datasets with Stata on problem sets during the quarter, building a valuable skill set.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Econ 201, Econ 202, Math 220, Stat 210

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures and TA section

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Problem sets, one midterm, and a final exam

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Assignments in this course will require you to use the statistical software, Stata. To purchase the software for your personal computer, a 6-month license for Stata/IC is available for $48 (https://www.stata.com/order/new/edu/gradplans/student-pricing/). A single license can be used to install Stata on up to 3 computers. This is the simplest way to access Stata and the most convenient way to complete classwork in 281. There are a couple cheaper alternatives out there: If you are a Weinberg student, you can access the program through an account with NUworkspace. Stata is also available on public computers on campus (e.g. libraries, computer labs, etc.), subject to availability/hours of operation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: We will use "Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach" by Jeffrey Wooldridge (any edition is fine).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will help students understand the key economic forces that have shaped the US health care and health insurance industry. What role do the particularities of health care and health insurance as economic goods play in explaining the size and growth rate of the health care sector? What's the effect of private incentives, adverse selection, moral hazard, and regulation? What's the effect of different organizational structures of health care provision? What can we learn from comparing the US health care / health insurance system to other countries' systems? Students will learn that these issues are important in the current public policy discussion.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures, potential TA section

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The grade will be based on problem sets, midterm exam(s), a final exam and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None. Readings will be provided.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course presents a smorgasbord of topics related to money and banking. Topics range from financial markets and the term structure of interest rates to the structure and role of banks and the Federal Reserve System to monetary theory and policy.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Assumed knowledge of the material of Economics 310-1 and 311 for this class.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: A typical week features two lectures and a discussion section.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There will be one midterm exam during the quarter and a final exam. There will also be a paper. Each of the exams will account for 40% of the possible points. The paper accounts for the remaining 20%. While a grade for class discussion will not be assigned, class discussion will definitely be considered in the case of a borderline grade.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The text for the course is Money, Banking, and Financial Markets, 5th ed. by Cecchetti & Schoenholtz, McGraw-Hill, ISBN13: 9781259746741. (Same book, new edition). Additional readings may be assigned during the quarter.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is concerned with the analysis of consumer and producer choice in market economies and with the nature of equilibria in competitive, monopolistic and imperfectly competitive markets. It also deals with the foundation of the market mechanism and analysis of welfare.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students should have completed (or at least be familiar with) the material covered in Economics 201 and 202 (Introduction to Economics), and, at the minimum, Mathematics 220 (Differential Calculus). Calculus will be used extensively in the course.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The material covered in lectures will generally correspond to the material assigned in the readings, although the lectures will often present the material from a different point of view, often with calculus. Lectures should be viewed as complements to, rather than as substitutes for the reading. There will also be discussion sections. The discussion sections are an integral part of the course, and your attendance is expected. They will be used to expand on ideas presented in the text and in lectures, to discuss homework problems and as a time for you to ask questions about anything that you would like clarified. Problem assignments and due dates will be announced in class.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two midterms worth 30% each and a final worth 40%. Homework will count in borderline cases.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Microeconomics by Besanko & Braeutigam, 5th edition (ISBN: 978-1118572276)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces the major topics of microeconomics that are typically not covered in 310-1. It intends to provide students with analytical tools to understand various economic phenomena. Among the topics covered are: social choice theory, general equilibrium in perfectly competitive markets, elementary game theory, oligopoly (Cournot, Bertrand and Stackelberg models), and the economic consequences of uncertainty and asymmetric information.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Econ 310-1, Math 220 or its equivalent.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 80-minute lectures and a 1-hour discussion section per week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly homeworks, two midterms and one final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: There is no required textbook for the course. Your 310-1 textbook is likely to have some rudimentary coverage of most of the topics in the course. However, since the lectures are the primary source for the course, you can manage without any textbook. Jeffrey M. Perloff, "Microeconomics: Theory and Applications with Calculus" (Pearson/Addison- Wesley,4th edition). ISBN: 978-0-13-416738-1 (Previous editions and newer are acceptable.)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course develops several simple models for thinking about the determinants of variables like aggregate employment, unemployment, investment, consumption, interest rates, inflation, exchange rates and the balance of trade. The framework is used to address issues such as: what is the role of saving in determining the long run wealth of the country; what is the role of money in accounting for inflation; what are the factors accounting for the recurrent fluctuations in employment and output called the business cycle; what factors account for fluctuations in the US dollar; what risks, if any, do the high US government deficits and large U.S. international deficits pose for the health of the US economy? Particular attention in Winter 2019 will be given to the causes of and solutions to the U. S. financial market meltdown of 2008-09, the causes of the slow recovery since 2009, the outlook for future growth, and the ongoing problem of high unemployment and slow growth which plagues Europe.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Economics 201. If an AP credit or other reason has opted you out of the Econ 201 requirement for the econ major, then it is not a prerequisite for this course.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures and TA sessions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 10% electronic homework, 20% five closed-book quizzes, 35% two midterms, 35% final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Textbook: Robert J. Gordon, Macroeconomics, 12th edition. Information regarding textbooks and study materials will be discussed during the first class session. Students are provided with the opportunity to buy the textbook at a greatly reduced price through the publisher and should not buy the book prior to the first class when all the options for purchase will be provided. Students are advised not to buy used copies on the web or elsewhere, as that will not give them access to the electronic homework, which they will then have to purchase separately.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will deal with the economic history of Europe in the Twentieth Century, such as growth, economic crises, unification, and the economics of war. The readings will consist of a number of books and essays.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: 310-1 and 311 are required.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: There will be two lectures a week. The lecture material and readings should be viewed as largely complementary, since the lectures will explain and often dispute the readings, hence both lecture materials and readings will be necessary to pass the course with a good grade because they are complements, not substitutes. Note: all powerpoint notes, graphs and tables shown in class will be made available on the Blackboard site for this course following the lectures.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There will one mandatory midterm exam, and an inclusive final examination. The midterm will cover all reading materials and lecture material of weeks 1-4. Students who score in the top 33% in the midterm will have the option of writing a paper in lieu of the exam. The topic and methodology have to be approved by the T.A. for the course, and the paper has to be submitted by the day of the final.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Readings: Four books are required, namely

1. Stephen Broadberry and Kevin O'Rourke, eds., The Cambridge Economic History of Modern Europe- Volume 2: 1870 to the Present. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2010).
2. Gabriel Tortella, The Origins of the Twenty-First Century. New York: Routledge, 2010 Paperback ed.
3. Nicholas Crafts, Forging Ahead, Falling Behind, and Fighting Back: British Economic Growth from the Industrial Revolution to the Financial Crisis (Cambridge Cambridge University Press, 2018); and
4. Ivan T. Berend, An Economic History of Twentieth Century Europe. (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2nd edition, 2016) Paperback ed.

All other readings (all required) will be placed on the course website on Canvas in the "Files" section in a file named " Readings" divided into "weeks."

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the central issues of development economics with a geographical focus on Sub-Saharan Africa. Our methodological approach will be to use primary data and rigorous empirical methods to examine patterns of economic activity and to evaluate the effectiveness of development policies and programs. The class will be organized around weekly presentations of student research on 9 key questions of development in Africa.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Economics 281, 310-1, 2 or equivalent

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 80 minute seminars per week. Using primary data provided to them, every week each student will investigate a specific question (e.g., what is the relationship between child health and poverty in urban Ghana?) and write a short report of her or his results.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Evaluation will be based on the 9 research reports.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The data analysis will require the use of Stata. It is recommended that you install it on a laptop that you can bring to class.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The primary object of this course will be to use economic laboratory experiments - essentially interactive classroom activities from your perspective - to (1) help you solidify your understanding of economic principles, (2) give you insight into how, why, and when some models perform well while others struggle to predict outcomes, and (3) allow you to evaluate the legitimacy and applicability of conclusions based on economic experiments.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Econ 281, Econ 310-1, and 310-2

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 80-minutes lectures, 50-minute discussion section with required attendance.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Your grade will be based on problem sets, exams, final project, and participation in class experiments.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: No required text. Readings will be provided.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Labor economics studies how labor markets work. We will cover anti-poverty programs, the minimum wage, immigration, the returns to education, earnings inequality, and labor market discrimination among other topics.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Economics 281, 310-1, and 310-2

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on problem sets, two midterm exams, and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Labor Economics by George J. Borjas, 8th edition. ISBN13: 9781260004724

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course applies economic analysis to the family. Topics covered include the economics of marriage and divorce, bargaining within the household, household production, and the economics of fertility. The specific questions addressed by the course fall into two categories. On the one hand, the course uses economics to understand the family, such as who marries whom, and how many children (if any) people choose to have. On the other hand, the course also considers the wider implications for family decisions for the economy at large, such as the repercussions of assortative mating in marriage for inequality in a society, and the relevance of family decisions for long-run economic development.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: ECON 310-1

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 80-minute lectures per week

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 3 problem sets/class projects (40 percent), midterm exam (20 percent), and final exam (40 percent)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Love, Money, and Parenting by Matthias Doepke and Fabrizio Zilibotti, ISBN-13: 978-0691171517. Other reading material will be available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces questions and recent empirical research in the economics of education. Topics include the returns to schooling, the individual decision to invest in education, the effect of education on economic and social outcomes, the production of education, the markets for schools and teachers, and public policies related to education.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Econ 281 and Econ 310-1

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 80-minutes lectures, optional discussion section

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Your grade will be based on tests, written paper, and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Economics of Education by Lovenheim and Turner (ISBN 978-0-7167-7704-5)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, we will look into the many different facets of the economics of gender. We will study economic decisions that individuals and households face from a unique gender perspective. The topics we will cover include, among others: the status of women around the world, education, marriage, fertility, labor supply, household decision-making, and discrimination. The class will put an emphasis on applied microeconomic theory and empirical analysis. A combination of econometric techniques and theoretical models will feature prominently in the course. For each topic, we will study concrete examples emanating from all over the world, and make an intensive use of statistics and econometrics. We are also very much interested in understanding the relationship between research and public policy. By the end of the quarter you hopefully will have a solid microeconomic framework within which to analyze important issues in economics from a gender perspective. There will be a series of empirical papers to read for this course. These papers will be discussed in lecture and they should be prepared prior to class. Preparing the paper means reading the abstract, introduction and conclusions (not necessarily the body of the paper) to understand: 1. What is the paper's research question? 2. What methodology is used to answer the question (e.g., an experiment, a quasi-experiment, a set of correlations, etc)? 3. What are the main findings? 4. What is the economic interpretation of these findings?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Economics 310-1; 281 and 381 (310-2 recommended). To do well in this class, you should be well acquainted with uni-variate and multi-variate calculus, statistics, and regression analysis: this class takes an approach to economics that is mathematical. You will also need a very good command of introductory micro since we will use and incorporate a lot of models from consumer behavior (I recommend you brush up your notes from 310-1).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of this course is to give the student the ability to critically evaluate both the literature on gender issues and related policy debates, to identify where contributions to this literature can be made and to apply concepts learned through class assignments.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: 2 lectures + 1 discussion section. Discussion section will be held Fridays 10:00AM - 10:50AM.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Grading for this class will be based on 5 problem sets, 2 exams (midterms), quizzes, and 1 final written assignment (electronic submission). There will not be a final in-class exam. Midterms will happen:
- Thursday February 6th from 6.30 pm - 8.30pm
- Thursday March 5th from 6.30 pm - 8.30pm

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: We will read academic journal articles, policy reports, etc. Electronic copies of these readings are available through the course website or the library's electronic journals.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Between the polar extremes of monopoly and perfect competition lies the realm of imperfect competition, often inhabited by a small number of interdependent firms with varying degrees of market power. Industrial economics (or industrial organization) explores the wide range of possible market structures and the competitive and cooperative strategies employed by profit-maximizing firms when there are few sellers, entry barriers, differentiated products, or imperfect information. We will review and expand the building blocks of the theory of the firm (cost and demand functions) and analyze the conduct and performance of monopolies, particularly through a variety of pricing schemes. We will use game theory to study oligopolistic firm behavior in a variety of scenarios, ranging from simple forms of static competition (e.g., Bertrand, Cournot and Hotelling models) to complex dynamic games involving strategic behavior (e.g., committing to an entry deterrence strategy or deciding whether to join a cartel). Although the problems we solve are mostly theoretical, we will discuss many real world applications.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 80-minute meetings per week, which will feature lectures, problem solving, and discussions of how to reconcile our models with current events (e.g., antitrust concerns over search engines). There will also be a discussion session, during which the teaching assistant will present some original material, work through practice exercises, or review for an upcoming exam.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Three exams (25% each) and an Evanston product market analysis project completed by a small team of students (25%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: In lieu of a single required text, we will use a variety of readings (e.g., textbook chapters, economic journal articles, antitrust cases, recent articles from the business press, and old teaching materials) that will be posted on Canvas in PDF format. Those who prefer a standard textbook should obtain Industrial Organization: Contemporary Theory and Empirical Applications by Pepall, Richards & Norman, 5th edition (ISBN: 978-1118250303)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will strive to employ economic analysis in order to provide a coherent theory of the law. The economic approach to law assumes that punishments such as incarceration or fines are implicit prices for violating the law. According to this view, these prices may be chosen in such a way that will yield the most socially desirable outcome. Of course, it may not be appropriate to judge laws entirely based on their economic efficiency. For example, it may also be appropriate to consider outcomes that are "fair" or "just," however defined, and these outcomes may not be the most efficient. Nevertheless, there is no doubt that efficiency is one important criterion for purposes of judging the law. Given that economists are often interested in studying incentives, it is therefore quite natural that we might be both interested and perhaps even well-equipped to analyze various areas of the law. Along these lines, we will seek to employ simple economic models in order to understand the efficiency of laws in several areas, including torts, contracts, property, and crime. In studying these diverse areas of the law, the economic approach to understanding the law will be consistent throughout, and will allow us to study these different areas of the law in a unified manner.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Economics 281, 310-1, 2

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures, discussion, and discussion of problem sets

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two midterms (25% each), three problem sets (10% total), and a final exam (40%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The Economic Approach to Law by Thomas J. Miceli, 3rd Edition (978-1503600065). Any supplementary readings will be provided either online or in class.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Economics of Nonprofit Organizations will explore the economic rationale for the non-profit sector, with a particular focus on how to model theoretically the value added of a nonprofit organization and how to estimate empirically its likely impact. This is an "experiential learning" course. Students, in groups of no more than four, will work directly with nonprofit organizations to conduct an "impact audit", a new tool and standard for assessing nonprofit effectiveness. In addition to completing the pre-requisites (ECON 281, 310-1,2; or equivalent with permission of the instructor), students must complete a brief application linked here: https://northwestern.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3rNxMFSnnUUxxaJ
Contact the instructor if you are interested in taking the class but have not completed all of the pre-requisites.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Completion of ECON 281, ECON 310-1, and ECON 310-2.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two lectures per week - with class discussion as an important element.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There will be three main outputs: (1) Completion of a "guided impact report", which does not require engagement with the nonprofit organization (20% of final grade), (2) a focused impact audit of a nonprofit program, which includes rating the organization's Quality of Impact Evidence and estimating its Cost of Impact (45% of final grade), and (3) short written assignments due the night before class some but not all weeks of class (20% of final grade). Class participation and peer review will account for the remaining 15% of the final grade.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
The Most Good You Can Do, by Peter Singer, Yale University Press, 2015 ISBN-13: 978-0300219869.
The Goldilocks Challenge, Gugerty and Karlan, Oxford University Press 2018. ISBN-13: 978-0199366088.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: There will also be other course readings available once the class begins.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the issues involved in forming a portfolio of securities. In particular, by the end of the quarter, students should be familiar with the existing set of financial instruments and the related terminology, have an understanding of the tradeoffs facing investors, and have the ability to evaluate alternative investment strategies. Much of the course will rely heavily on statistics and economics and their applications in real-world finance are emphasized. Topics related to single security selection may be touched on, but the primary focus of the course is on the creation of optimal portfolios of securities. Topics include portfolio selection, asset pricing models, tests of market efficiency, performance evaluation and fixed-income securities. There will be 5-6 problem sets including case write-ups. Students are encouraged to work on the problem sets in small groups.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: ECON 360-1, Corporate Finance or BUS_INST 304, Corporate Finance or CIV_ENV 205, Economics and Finance for Engineers, or STAT 365, Introduction to the Analysis of Financial Data.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two weekly lectures plus problem sets throughout the quarter. The problems will provide practice with the types of calculations and concepts that are important to a proper understanding of the course material. Some problems will provide valuable practice for the midterm and final, while other problems will require you to obtain and make use of real-world financial data or to analyze a case and thus will give you an idea of how theory connects to reality. Sample exams will also be provided to help students practice before the actual exam.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The course grade will be based upon a combination of problem sets, class contribution, a midterm exam, and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Investments by Bodie, Kane and Marcus, 11th Edition (ISBN: 978-1259277177). 9th or 10th edition is also okay.
Four Cases (A case is a short reading that describes real business stories. It is usually written by business school professors for classroom use. Students will apply the concepts they learn in the class to these real business issues in order to enforce their learning. Each case is usually $3-$4.)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This course uses the programming language, Python. Python is free and you don't need to have prior knowledge/experience on Python to enroll in this class. However, you need to have 3-4GB of free space on your laptop for installation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Factors influencing trade in goods and services between countries and the implication of globalization. The reasons for, and the effects of, trade policy instruments such as tariffs, quotas, and voluntary export restrictions.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: ECON 281-0, ECON 310-1, ECON 310-2, ECON 311-0.

descriptions.value: International Trade: Theory and Policy, 11th Edition, Krugman, Obstfeld, Melitz, Pearson Press, 2018

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Most of economics is concerned with understanding relations among variables. Examples include the effects of education on earnings, the relation between the lengths of prison sentences and crime rates, and the relation between interest and inflation rates. Econometrics provides the statistical tools needed to infer these relations from data and test theory models of the relations. Thus, econometrics is the toolbox of empirical economics. This course covers the basic methods of empirical economics and provides tools that are needed to build and critically evaluate empirical econometric models. Topics will include the linear regression model, limited dependent variable models and causal inference.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: STAT 210 or equivalent, Econ 310-1 (310-2, 311 recommended); MATH 230, 234, 240 & 314 (or equivalent).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two lectures per week (plus a discussion section on Fridays)

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: A midterm exam, a final exam, and problem sets

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Stock, J.H. and M.W. Watson (2011). Introduction to Econometrics, 4th ed. Pearson/Addison Wesley, ISBN-13: 978-0134461991

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Econometrics is about using data to infer relations among economic variables. It aims at answering questions such as: by how much does a 5% price increase reduce the demand for a good? This course is about how to use data and modern software to build, evaluate, and use models to answer such questions. The course is taught in a computerized classroom. Each student sits at a computer terminal, which enables us to estimate and diagnose models in class. The course emphasizes the actual building of models. Each student will write a paper describing the analysis of a real data set and the conclusions reached from that analysis.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar will explore some classics of British fantasy from the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, asking what's at stake when a writer decides to create a new world. How do the challenges and opportunities offered by fantasy differ from those of the realistic novel? Why do so many fantasies draw on medieval literature? How have writers used this genre to experiment with new social arrangements, alternative ways of imagining sex and gender, and beliefs about the supernatural? Why do animals and monsters play such important roles? Is there a clear dividing line between "children's" and "adult" fantasy? The objectives of the course will be to gain a fuller understanding of this genre and to develop skill and confidence in interpreting literary texts, both orally and in writing.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class discussion and three 5-page papers. After receiving feedback on one paper of your choice, you will be required to submit a revised version. The new grade will supplant the original one.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Lewis Carroll, Alice's Adventures in Wonderland (1865); H. Rider Haggard, She (1886); Hope Mirrlees, Lud-in-the-Mist (1926); Charles Williams, All Hallows' Eve (1945); C. S. Lewis, Till We Have Faces (1956); Ursula LeGuin, The Left Hand of Darkness (1969); Philip Pullman, The Golden Compass (1995); and J. K. Rowling, Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (1998). We will also read three classic essays on fantasy: George MacDonald, "The Fantastic Imagination"; Ursula LeGuin, "From Elfland to Poughkeepsie"; and J. R. R. Tolkien, "On Fairy-Stories."

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The recent success of black speculative arts, including Ryan Coogler's Black Panther, Jordan Peele's Get Out, and Ava DuVernay's A Wrinkle in Time, invites us to consider the longer history of black writing in the speculative tradition. In this first-year writing seminar, students will develop critical thinking and reasoning skills through engagement with twentieth and twenty-first century black speculative writing. Students will also learn to develop their written and oral communication skills by articulating their ideas about this material. In the course of our reading, we will consider the role of freedom in the black speculative tradition and attempt to locate the "Afro" of Afrofuturism. We will be especially attentive to the historical specificity of the works under review. Importantly, we will engage sources that reflect the global span of writing in the black diaspora.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion; Writing Groups with Workshop.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly reading response papers; one paper with revisions.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Samuel Delany, The Tales of Nevèrÿon; Nnedi Okorafor, Shuri; N.K. Jemisin, How Long ?til Black Future Month; Francis Lawrence, I am Legend; Ryan Coogler, Black Panther; Nana Kwame Adjei-Nenyah, Friday Black.

Available at Norris.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: "Make It New": Ezra Pound borrows this slogan from an ancient Chinese emperor's bath tub: "As the sun makes it new / Day by day make it new." But what is "it"? In our seminar we'll explore poetry as an art of words, voice, song, speech, story; of describing, expressing, transforming, translating, and revealing worlds visible and invisible; of hiddenness and discovery, paradox and mystery, epiphany and surprise, the everyday, the extraordinary, the otherworldly. Reading selected poems and related prose by Baudelaire, Whitman, Dickinson, Yeats, Eliot, Pound, H. D., Williams, Bishop, Hughes, Brooks, and other poets both earlier and later, we'll see how particular poems engender and emerge from creative dialogue with other poems across historical moments, locales, languages, cultural surrounds, and sensibilities. We'll practice close-reading, analytic, and comparative skills to appreciate, discuss, and write about the formal and linguistic virtuosity-verse lines and forms, sound patterns (meter, rhythm, music, tone), diction, rhetorical tropes, figurative language, personae, voices-with which poets create imaginary worlds that enrich and extend the resources of English poetry. We'll visit our Special Collections Library to learn about print culture and see some first editions in periodical and book form. Our last class will be a poetry fest, with each student choosing and presenting a poem to the class.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Prompt, faithful attendance and active, informed participation; weekly exercises, including recitation and imitation; three short papers; class presentation, possibly collaborative; choosing and presenting a poem in our poetry fest; self-evaluation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
The Norton Anthology of Poetry, ed. Ferguson et al., 5th edition 978-0-393-97920-6.
Supplemental texts via Canvas, Library Reserve, the web.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Bilbo Baggins, Harry Potter, the Pevensie children?for many people, these characters are friends almost as dear as the people they meet in everyday life. The fantasy worlds that we enter in childhood shape our imaginations for decades to come. What makes these particular books so appealing to generation after generation of readers? How do they mold our expectations of what childhood (and adulthood) should be, and how we should experience the world? What narrative shapes do these fantasies trace out for their readers? In this course, we will read such classic works as JRR Tolkien's The Hobbit, Ursula K. LeGuin's A Wizard of Earthsea, and JK Rowling's Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. By bringing a literary lens to classic children's fantasy, you will be able to make arguments about how and why these novels have shaped the imaginations of generations of children and adults.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Active participation in discussion, two short papers, one longer paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
JRR Tolkien, The Hobbit; CS Lewis, The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe; Ursula K. LeGuin, A Wizard of Earthsea; JK Rowling, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone; Madeline L'Engle, A Wrinkle in Time; Gail Carson Levine, Ella Enchanted.

Texts will be available at: Norris

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What are the Seven Deadly Sins, how did they come into being, and how do can we make sense of the role they continue to play the 21st century popular imagination? What is the nature of moral and ethical transgression: is sin a disposition, a thought, an action, or an external force? And how does one make amends for such transgression? Over the course of the quarter, we will attempt to answer these questions by exploring the evolving representations of sin, secrets and confession that some of the most popular medieval texts. Exploring the work of preachers and poets alike, we will investigate the ways in which medieval writers adapted their depictions of sin to address the major social and political issues of their day, highlighting certain sins while hiding others as the moment required. We will also explore how modern texts and films take up and transform these medieval ideas in order to reach contemporary audiences.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Papers and Presentations.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Selections from Dante's Purgatorio and Langland's Piers Plowman; Everyman
Textbooks available at: Beck's Bookstore. Students need only purchase Dante's Purgatorio, ed. Mark Musa (ISBN 978-0140444421, approximate cost: $13-16)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: From its inception, the rise of the novel has been fed by anxieties about the overactive imaginations of passionate readers, and the dangerous effects of popular literacy. As studies of emotional over-investment and varieties of censorship, the narratives in this course address when and how literature and reading become dangerous (whether to individuals, social values, or the powers that be). How do the devotion, enthusiasm, madness, or transgression that literature can lead to sometimes prove revelatory? From another angle, how are concerns about the effects of reading and the spread of literacy partly motivated by the desire to control information, freedom, and social mobility? More broadly, how do reading and literary interpretation teach us new techniques for how (or how not) to interpret the world? The course offers a brief introduction to the remarkable story of the modern novel, while exploring the influence of literary works in society.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required texts (available at Beck's books):
J. W. von Goethe, The Sorrows of Young Werther
Jane Austen, Northanger Abbey
Frederick Douglass, Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass
Gustave Flaubert, Madame Bovary
Bahiyyih Nakhjavani, The Woman Who Read Too Much
Toni Morrison, A Mercy

name: First-Year Seminar
topic: Sexuality and Science Fiction in Literature and Fi

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Science fiction revels in stories about humans, aliens, and robots falling in love. Also referred to more broadly as speculative fiction, science fiction has long been a genre that offers authors the opportunity to imagine alternative possibilities for sexuality, gender, and race. In this course, we will investigate how a story set in a more or less distant future or on a faraway planet can offer present readers insights into how we can explore our own racial and sexual identities. From the origins of the scifi novel in the Victorian era to modern-day works like Octavia Butler's Lilith's Brood trilogy, Margaret Atwood's The Handmaid's Tale, and the popular graphic novel series, Saga: each of these works raises titillating and challenging ideas about the possible objects and subjects of erotic and romantic desire. Through these texts, we will explore critical and challenging questions: can you love a robot? What would it mean to have sex with someone of another alien race or species? Why are futuristic societies often shown attempting to control the reproductive process, especially as it relates to women's bodies?

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar Discussion.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two-page paper, medium length paper, peer-revision exercise, one discussion-leading exercise, long paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Charlotte Perkins Gilman, Herland; Octavia Butler, Dawn (Lilith's Brood Trilogy, Volume 1); Margaret Atwood, The Handmaid's Tale; Becky Chambers, The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet; Fiona Staples, Brian Vaughan, Saga (Volume 1).

Secondary Texts (brief selections, provided by professor): Frederic Jameson, Archaeologies of the Future; Lee Edelman, No Future; José Esteban Muñoz, Cruising Utopia.

Texts will be available at: Norris Bookstore.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Pirates, Cowboys, and Astronauts: Making Claims in America

The swashbuckling buccaneer. The strong, silent wrangler. The intrepid interstellar explorer. From representations in films and novels to memes and Halloween costumes, the pirate, the cowboy, and the astronaut persist as icons of popular American culture. In this course we will explore how these figures have transcended their chronicled roles in American history to function metaphorically in an American mythology that valorizes rugged individualism, white masculinity, and property ownership. By reading the works of writers ranging from Cotton Mather and Edgar Allan Poe to Willa Cather, Joy Harjo, and Octavia Butler, we will turn the pirates, cowboys, and astronauts of American myth on their heads to examine the ideologies underlying their enduring appeal. In doing so, we will ask critical questions about gender, race, and indigeneity to disrupt the dominance of the American myths of opportunity and limitless freedom.

Broadly, this is a course about making claims. We will encounter the claims staked by historical and literary pirates, cowboys, and astronauts while we simultaneously evaluate the assertions scholars make in their critical work about these figures. As you analyze and examine the claims of others, you will also be asked to stake your own claims?to make arguments?in your writing. Ultimately, this course is designed to make you a better writer, reader, and critical thinker. By approaching writing as a process that requires reflection and revision, we will train the skills you need to write well. Specifically, you will work to improve your ability to read critically, structure your thoughts clearly, use evidence effectively, and argue persuasively. This course also provides the opportunity to develop your research savvy and classroom discussion facility while challenging you to become a less credulous reader, a subtler thinker, and a more imaginative scholar.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
"They Say I Say", 4th edition; ISBN: 978-0-393-63167-8

A course pack also be provided

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Expository Writing is designed for any student who wants a strong introductory course in college-level writing. Students write three or four extended pieces of expository writing, developing each through a process of planning, drafting, revising, and editing. Students also complete several briefer exercises in which they experiment with specific writing techniques or use informal writing as a tool for exploring ideas. Class meetings are conducted as seminar discussions and workshops. In addition, the instructor meets regularly with students in individual conferences.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: A course pack will be provided.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Ever since Pentheus' fatal decision to spy on the revels of Dionysus, audiences have had a guilty fascination with the spectacle of addiction?a fascination which crosses not only centuries but disciplines, captivating scientists, policymakers, philosophers, artists, and laypeople alike. This class will trace the evolution of literary representations of addiction across several centuries, from classical depictions of god-induced madness, through the Gothic narratives of Poe and Stevenson, temperance classics such as Ten Nights in a Barroom (whose impact has often been compared to that of Uncle Tom's Cabin), to the twentieth- and twenty-first century comedies and confessionals that make the bestseller lists today. Through these readings and related critical texts, we will examine the ways that such literature provides a staging ground for public controversy and emerging theories about the artistic, cultural, ethical, and scientific significance and ramifications of addiction.

Course readings/viewing will include works of fiction, journalism, and writings from the natural and social sciences as well as popular films. We will also consider practical topics such as how University library resources and experts can help students locate and evaluate key sources and develop authoritative arguments.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion and Workshop

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: This course requires three papers and periodic writing assignments in the class portfolio (approximately 25 pages total). All papers will be written in stages and revised. Quarter grades will cover writing (approximately 70%) and class participation (30%, including attendance and in-class presentations).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Readings with excerpts from some works and some works in their entirety. Books with ISBN numbers are books that students will need to obtain for class.

The Black Cat, Edgar Allen Poe
High Price, Carl Hart
In the Realm of Hungry Ghosts, Gabor Mate

For purchase (online editions are acceptable so long as they include the same text)
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, Robert Louis Stevenson- ISBN 978-0486266886; Dover Thrift Editions
Ten Nights in a Bar Room, T.S. Arthur- ISBN 978-1594625466
The Big Book of Alcoholics Anonymous - ISBN 978-1483907253; online version also acceptable
Junky, William S. Burroughs - ISBN 978-0802120427
Drinking: A Love Story, Caroline Knapp- ISBN 978-0385315548


Video
The Philadelphia Story
Confessions of a Shopaholic
The Neurobiology of Disrupted Free Will, Nora Volkow, Director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Where are you from? What does your hometown look like, sound like, feel like? This is a crash course in learning how to write about places, partly by way of surveying American regionalism, a genre often criticized for its narrow focus on local histories, cultural manners, and peoples of particular places and geographies rather than on larger national themes. Instead of isolating our readings of regional works, we will place texts focusing on three different regions of the United States in conversation with one another. We will study the South through Alice Dunbar-Nelson, New England through Sarah Orne Jewett, and the Great Plains through Zitkála-?á. Using Digital Humanities tools such as StoryMap and ArcGIS we will build visual, digital maps tracing and connecting our readings of regionalist works. We will expand our map, potentially beyond the borders of the United States, by experimenting with our own regional writing, critically reflecting not only on the places where we are from or have come to love, but also on the Chicago/Northwestern region where we currently reside. (No prior training in digital tools nor skills in storymaking are required for this course).?

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Design Thinking and Communication (DTC), is a required two-quarter course for all first-year students at McCormick. It is also available to any Northwestern undergraduate student interested in design. Every section is co-taught by an instructor from the Writing Program and an instructor from engineering. Part of the Engineering First® curriculum, the course immediately puts students to work on real design problems submitted by individuals, non-profits, entrepreneurs, and industry members. In DTC, all students design for real people and communicate to real audiences.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Design Thinking and Communication (DTC), is a required two-quarter course for all first-year students at McCormick. It is also available to any Northwestern undergraduate student interested in design. Every section is co-taught by an instructor from the Writing Program and an instructor from engineering. Part of the Engineering First® curriculum, the course immediately puts students to work on real design problems submitted by individuals, non-profits, entrepreneurs, and industry members. In DTC, all students design for real people and communicate to real audiences.

descriptions.value: Course materials will be on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goal of this course is to develop your ability to write clearly, persuasively, and interestingly for a variety of audiences. Students will learn techniques for writing effective informative, reflective, persuasive, and research essays. These techniques include the effective use of specific details; methods of organizing ideas clearly; strategies for editing sentences for clarity and conciseness; and ways to give your writing a distinctive voice. Students will submit drafts and revisions of essays.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion is the primary teaching method. Students will also meet with the instructor individually outside of class throughout the quarter to discuss their papers.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The writing assignments comprise 85% of the course grade. Class discussion comprises 15% of the grade.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All readings will be available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
Registration for this course is not handled by the English department.

Questions about this course should be directed to the The Cook Family Writing Program.
writing-program@northwestern.edu

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course examines the intersection of story and argument, both to investigate how creative storytelling may provide the inspiration for argument and to examine how effective writers and researchers may be seen to build their arguments (legitimately or otherwise) on the foundation of story. Readings will range from discussions of the graphic novel to considerations of how everyday citizens manipulate social media to tell the stories they desire (or vice versa). We will also look at case studies that illustrate how the ever-widening gulf between the stories told by specialists and non-specialists plays out in the public sphere and the making of public policy.
This course is recommended for students who wish to refine their mastery of the essay form while experimenting with a range of creative approaches to articulating arguments and persuading audiences. Key assignments will require research into a question of the student's own choosing, refined and developed over the course of the quarter. Students are welcome to use this class to deepen their explorations of research problems that they may have begun investigating in other classes or contexts.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion and guest lectures. Students will also meet individually with the instructor and as small working groups to discuss their writing.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two short essay assignments, one in-class final presentation and a final major paper (developed in many drafts over the course of the quarter). The form the final paper takes will be determined on a case-by-case basis. Options include literature reviews, proposals written for research grants (including opportunities sponsored by the Northwestern University Office of the Provost), and drafts of formal papers.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Understanding Comics. Scott McCloud. William Morrow Paperbacks; Reprint edition (1994). ISBN 978-0060976255 (really any edition is fine)

They Say / I Say. Gerald Graff and Cathy Birkenstein. Norton (2010). ISBN 978-0393933611; any edition fine and used encouraged (though Norris will only stock 4th and latest edition). Students do NOT need the version with readings.

Writing With Power. Peter Elbow. Oxford UP (1998) ISBN 978-0195120189; any edition fine and used encouraged.

Fields of Reading, Motives for Writing (9th or 10th edition). Comley, Hamilton, et al. (Eds.). Bedford/St. Martin's. ISBN-13: 978-1457608919

Additional readings will be available online.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
Registration for this course is not handled by the English department. Questions about this course should be directed to:

Cook Family Writing Program
writing-program@northwestern.edu
555 Clark St., #201
Evanston, IL 60208
Ph: 847-491-7414

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An introduction to the major forms of poetry in English from the dual perspective of the poet-critic. Creative work will be assigned in the form of poems and revisions; analytic writing will be assigned in the form of critiques of other members' poems. A scansion exercise will be given early on. All of these exercises, creative and expository, as well as the required readings from the anthology, are designed to help students increase their understanding of poetry rapidly and profoundly; the more wholehearted students' participation, the more they will learn from the course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No prerequisites. No P/N registration. Attendance of first class is mandatory. Freshmen are NOT permitted to enroll until their winter quarter. Course especially recommended for prospective Writing Majors. Literature Majors are also welcome.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion; one-half to two-thirds of the classes will be devoted to discussion of readings and principles, the other classes to discussion of student poems.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Evidence given in written work and class participation of students' understanding of poetry; improvement will count for a great deal in estimating achievement.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: An anthology, a critical guide, 206 Reader prepared by the instructor, and the work of the other students.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This course may also be counted toward the English Literature major.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A reading and writing course in short fiction. Students will read widely in traditional as well as experimental short stories, seeing how writers of different culture and temperament use conventions such as plot, character, and techniques of voice and distance to shape their art. Students will also receive intensive practice in the craft of the short story, writing at least one story, along with revisions, short exercises, and a critical study of at least one work of fiction, concentrating on technique.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: English 206. No P/N registration. Attendance of first class is mandatory. Course especially recommended for prospective Writing Majors. Literature Majors also welcome. Teaching Method: Discussion of readings and principles; workshop of student drafts. Evaluation Method: Evidence given in written work and class participation of students' growing understanding of fiction; improvement will count for a great deal in estimating achievement.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Selected short stories, essays on craft, and the work of the other students.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An introduction to some of the many possible voices, styles, and structures of the creative essay. Students will read from the full aesthetic breadth of the essay, including memoir, meditation, lyric essay, and literary journalism. Discussions will address how the essay creates an artistic space distinct from the worlds of poetry and fiction, and how truth and fact function within creative nonfiction. Students will be asked to analyze the readings closely, and to write six short essays based on imitations of the style, structure, syntax, and narrative devices found in the readings. Students can also expect to do some brief writing exercises and at least one revision.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: English 206. No P/N registration. Attendance of first class is mandatory. Course especially recommended for prospective Writing Majors. Literature Majors also welcome.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion; one-half to two-thirds of the classes will be devoted to discussion of readings and principles, the other classes to discussion of student work.
