name: First-Year Seminar-European History
topic: Pirates in the Age of Sail

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Pirates in the Age of Sail

Pirates have long captured our imaginations. From Long John Silver to Captain Jack Sparrow, the lives of pirates have been the source material for novels, films, and tales of romance and adventure. But what were pirates really like? Were they freedom-loving swashbucklers striking a blow against corrupt empires and exploitative employers? Or were they ruthless oppressors terrorizing those who could not defend themselves? This course investigates the history of piracy in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, with a focus on pirates in the Caribbean. We will read eyewitness narratives of piracy from the early modern period. We will also examine depictions of pirates in popular culture in the nineteenth, twentieth, and twenty-first centuries, with a focus on Robert Louis Stevenson's classic novel Treasure Island and its film adaptations.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn how to interpret historical documents, how to frame a historical argument based on primary sources, and how to critique popular narratives about piracy.

Maritime, 2000, ISBN 978-0486409665).

978-0140437683).

name: First-Year Seminar-American History
topic: A Social, Political and Non-Technical History of t

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
TOPIC: A Social, Political, and Non-Technical History of the Internet

This Freshman seminar will consider the history of the internet from the mid-twentieth century to the present. This will NOT be a technical history of the computer science or actual infrastructure that constitute the internet, but rather a history of the social and political ideas contributing to and arising from a worldwide system of networked computers and protocols. In particular, the course will discuss the culture surrounding the internet?the ways that the Cold War, the counterculture, libertarianism, and environmentalism all helped define Silicon Valley and continue to shape companies that call for revolution while placing their trust in the market.

History Area of Concentration: Americas

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
The history of the internet and internet culture
How to think about technology in social and political terms
How to read and think critically about a variety of texts
How to make, sustain, and support an argument in writing

name: First-Year Seminar-Non-Western History
topic: Islam, Gender, and the Modern World

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
TOPIC: Islam, Gender, and the Modern World

Islam' is often believed to be a religion which justifies oppression of women and regulation of their public lives in theological terms. In this seminar, we will focus on South Asia?home to one of the world's largest Muslim populations today?as a site for examining the historical evolution of Islamic perspectives on gender issues from the nineteenth century to our own times. Based on texts composed by Muslim women and Muslim male theologians, we will consider the following issues: marriage and divorce, gender segregation, education, property ownership, and Muslim women's political participation. In analyzing these questions, we will elucidate the complexity of Islamic intellectual traditions and emphasize their historical dynamism, especially in colonial and post-colonial contexts. Simultaneously, we will discover the ways in which Muslim women have become agents of their own change while compromising with and negotiating multiple forms of social authority in Muslim societies.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The complexity and historicity of gender issues in Muslim societies

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Asia/Middle East

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: The Black Death and Other Pandemics

The Black Death refers to the first visitation of the bubonic plague in the fourteenth century. It was the greatest single demographic calamity in recorded history: between 1346 and 1353, the population in affected areas was depleted by as much as 60%. The plague was a true pandemic which reverberated throughout the world. This course will use the bubonic plague as a jumping off point for the study of other pandemics, analyzing the social and environmental factors that account for the spread of a given disease; efforts to understand and vanquish it; and the ultimate impact on society. The manner in which different diseases spread reflect important aspects of world history. For instance, the spread of the Black Death was dependent on the revival of long-distance trade; smallpox was spread throughout the "new world" by both territorial conquest and the human trafficking in slaves; cholera, which was transmitted infected water, was (and is) representative of poor hygiene and abject poverty - factors that were often class related. Other diseases, like tuberculosis, were (and are) often indicative of poor working conditions. As the recent outbreak of cholera in Haiti attests, many of these diseases have never been eradicated, even as new ones continue to wreak havoc. The course will conclude with an examination of the AIDS virus and ongoing outbreaks of Ebola.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The students will have a good grasp of the relation between disease, science, and society and how this nexus has played out historically.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

Christian McMillen. Pandemics: A Very Short Introduction. Oxford, 2016. 978-0199340071

And a course package

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration, European, Global

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: "Consent" is the ubiquitous standard used both by ordinary people and by legal institutions to distinguish between sexual activity that is harmful and non-harmful. But the way in which consent has been defined and constructed is also problematic in multiple ways. On one hand, women have historically found their ability to consent or not consent severely constrained by rape law and the mas.rriage contract. On the other, sex crime laws classify and stereotype a range of non-normative "queer" behaviors, such as sex work, sex in public, the sexual conduct of HIV-positive people, and underage sex, as always and necessarily harmful and inherently non-consensual. Analyzing the advantages and disadvantages of how consent has been constructed in different times and places will allow us to sharpen our critical thinking skills and envision a more just future for gender and sexual governance.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
* Understand and explain major topics and issues related to the history of the notion of consent as it relates to sexual behavior
* Develop critical-thinking skills such as evaluating historical evidence and strategic reading
* Develop cultural competency with respect to multiple issues of social diversity along the lines of gender, sexuality, race, class, age, and space

name: European Civilization: High Medieval Thru Mid-18th C

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course surveys the history of Europe from the High Middle Ages through the early modern period to the Age of Atlantic Revolutions. These centuries changed the course of European and world history. The Renaissance, the Reformations, the Scientific Revolution, and the Enlightenment unfolded at the same time as European empires spread first into the Mediterranean and then across the Atlantic, spurring the growth of global capitalism and the transatlantic slave trade. Political and religious freedoms emerged alongside new forms of persecution, control, and oppression. A divided Europe grew increasingly connected to the rest of the world as commercial goods, people, ideas, and diseases traveled across land and sea. Among the major themes we'll explore are a) how individuals who lived through these tumultuous centuries experienced their changing world and b) how changes in health, disease, and environment - including the Black Death, the Columbian Exchange, and the climactic cooling period known as the Little Ice Age - drove the religious, political, social, and economic upheavals of the late medieval and early modern periods.

History Area of Concentration: European

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The primary objective of the course is to master the skills of argumentation from primary evidence. In quizes, discussions, and examinations, students will be asked to take evidence from a variety of historical sources and make cogent, clear, and convincing arguments about the meaning and significance of past events, persons, and ideas. There will be three lectures a week. Discussion sections meeting once a week will begin with a quiz on that week's readings. There will follow a discussion of thorny or intriguing problems that emerge from the readings and/or the lectures.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Participation, Midterm and Final Exams, Short Papers

All other readings will be available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: European

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Modernity has dramatically changed the profile of Western Civilization and had a major impact on the European Jews. How did Jews contribute to European modernity? How did European Modernity change the Jews? The course will take students from French Revolution that started integrating the Jews into the fabric of European society to the establishment of the State of Israel. It will highlight the plurality of models of Jewish integration and acculturation, the formation of new Jewish identities, the split of the traditional community under the impact of Enlightenment, the rise of Reform and Orthodox trends within Judaism, and the spread of Jewish political movements ranging from socialism to nationalism. Based on a plethora of primary documents (provided in English translation), the course will explore the fascinating responses of the Jews to modernity on political, societal, theological, artistic, and cultural levels. Students will meet with the Jewish enlighteners, reform rabbis, radical revolutionaries, agricultural settlers in Palestine, European politicians, famous artists, journalists, lawyers, composers, and writers of Jewish descent - but also with impoverished proletarians, silenced victims of the Holocaust, and ordinary Jews who pass through history without leaving a trace.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: How to analyse primary sources, how to make sense of the historiographic accounts, how to frame insightful questions, and how to build a context that gives to an event its meaning.

descriptions.value: LectureDiscussion section

descriptions.value: Grades will be based on three 2-page long response papers (30 percent), participation in class and/or section discussions (30 percent), and a final 10-page (plus bibliography)-long research paper (primary source(s) analysis, 40 percent).

name: History of the United States, Precolonial to the Civil War

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, we will explore the major themes of early American history, from the first encounters between native people, Europeans, and Africans to the impassioned battles of the Civil War. Our goal will be to track the variety of meanings that America had for the people who lived here: men and women, rich and poor, free and slave. We will examine stories of growth and decay, of war and peace, of conflict and collaboration. We will also tell a story about how thirteen disparate and unruly British colonies came to form a new kind of nation: a republic, dedicated (as Abraham Lincoln would later recall) to the proposition that all men were created equal. Topics to be covered include colonial encounters, slavery, religion, social reform movements, sexuality, manifest destiny, the foundations of republican government, and the meanings of capitalism and democracy.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
As part of this course, students will:
1) Learn to use primary sources, which offer an "on the ground" sense of what early America felt like, and which form the building blocks of historical inquiry.
2) Engage in reasoned and respectful discussion and construct thoughtful, evidence-based arguments from course readings and lectures.
3) Gain a foundational understanding of the people, places, and events that shaped the early American past. Students will think historically and critically about why all these names and dates matter, having them at hand to weave into broader, interpretative arguments about the past.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course offers a general introduction to the history of African Americans in the United States from emancipation through the late twentieth century. Students will explore the myriad ways in which African Americans challenged racial segregation, exclusion, and discrimination and shaped the history of the American nation. Special topics covered include: Reconstruction, Jim Crow, black nationalism, the Harlem Renaissance, the long civil rights movement, Black Power, and Black Feminism.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: "Introduction to Asian American History" provides students with a broad survey of migratory and displacement patterns of those living in Asia as agitated by militarism, capitalism, imperialism, war, racism, sexism, classism, and nationalism stemming from within the region and abroad. What are the multiple and competing narratives of how these histories and experiences are produced? How are they evidenced and interpreted across multiple forms of visual, sonic, and textual ephemera? Once in the United States, how did similar?although not identical?processes of racialization, economic and labor exploitation, legislative and political exclusion, social and cultural othering, and strategies for survival and resistance work together to transform these heterogeneous populations into "Asian Americans"? What are the afterlives of these contentious pasts and how do they continue to inform Asian American community practices, relations, and issues today?

name: Background to African Civilization and Culture: Origins to 17th C.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: From the Sahara southwards, for the past three millennia, Africans combined complex agricultures, industrial quality metallurgy, and rich cultural knowledge of ecological process, changing their environments, creating cities, global trade networks, and new political systems along the way. This course introduces you to these stories and helps you distinguish varieties of cause and consequence in untangling the changing and mutually constitutive relationships between technology, environment, and culture. No prior knowledge of Africa or Environmental History needed.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The broad contours of Africa's regional environmental, technological, and cultural histories. The ways in which those African histories shaped histories of Europe, Southwest and South Asian.

name: History of the Modern Middle East, 1789 - Present

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course surveys the factors that shaped the political, economic, and social features of the modern Middle East from 1789 to the present. The course begins with a study of traditional (mainly Ottoman) institutions; it then traces the forces which weakened those institutions and examines the efforts of Middle Eastern leaders to resist or encourage change. The second half of the course focuses on the period since World War I. It examines the origins of the Arab-Israeli conflict, the significance of secular ideologies such as Arab nationalism and socialism, the successes and failure of the Nasser regime in Egypt, the rise of Islamism, the Iranian revolution, and the Middle East since the end of the Cold War.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will not attempt to survey chronologically the myriad events unfolding over more than three millennia of Egyptian History. Emphasis will be placed on major themes and debated issues, including the following: Problems of historical study relative to a society "without historians"; Emergence of the political order during the Prehistoric Period; Divine monarchy and the myth of permanence during the Old Kingdom; the shattering of this myth during the First Intermediate Period; The "custodial monarch" of the Middle Kingdom; The impact of Asia: new horizons, new anxieties; Aspects of cosmopolitanism and intellectual syncretism during the Empire Period; The religious revolution of Akhenaten; The myth of permanence reborn as a cult of conservation.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: characteristics of a civilization that is a foundation of global culture; awareness of how a unique religious tradition affected subsequent monotheist beliefs; why ancient Egyptian spirituality continues to inspire people in the modern secular world

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Development of American Indian Law and Policy

In this course, we focus on Native peoples as sovereign nations, not merely racial and ethnic minorities in U.S. society. Students will learn about the unique legal landscape in Native America by charting the historical development of the ever-changing body of law and policy that regulates Indian affairs. We will approach the study of federal Indian law and policy as both a tool of U.S. colonial domination and a mechanism for protecting the interests of Indigenous communities. This course emphasizes social histories and the lived experience of the law. We begin by studying Indigenous legal traditions and European imperialism, then shift our attention to the U.S. Constitution and key U.S. Supreme Court decisions, and conclude with examining the contemporary dilemmas facing Indigenous governments.

descriptions.value:
Topic: History and Theory of Information

We live in an information age, with computers of unprecedented power in our pockets. This course seeks to understand how information shapes our lives today, and how it has in the past. It does so via an interdisciplinary inquiry into four key information and communication technologies?print, telegraphy, broadcast radio/TV, and the internet?to understand the origins, development, and impacts of information in society. It will be jointly taught by faculty in Communication Studies and History.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas, European

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Islam and the Global Renaissance

This course will introduce students to various aspects of Islamic cultural and intellectual history that contributed to Renaissance thought, and to early modern "Western Civilization" generally. In modern times, of course, the Islamic world has gotten a pretty bad rap for (allegedly) lacking the things that made the modern west "modern": a spirit of rational philosophical and scientific inquiry, a commitment to religious tolerance, a humanistic respect for intellectual freedom and curiosity, a historical consciousness, and so on. But as we will see, Muslim scholars, intellectuals, and literati throughout history have not only espoused such values, many were pioneering thinkers whose works had a profound influence on the development of early modern European intellectual culture. It is a feature of our shared intellectual past that has largely been forgotten in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. But recuperating such global genealogies of modern thought - and specifically, the modern humanities - is perhaps more urgent than ever today, in our own era of resurgent ethnic, nationalist, and sectarian chauvinism around the world.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students will be expected to know more about the Islamic world, but also more about the global history of "Western" civilization. Critical writing, reading, and thinking skills will also be an emphasis of the course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Origins of Censorship

This course studies censorship in the medieval and early modern worlds across religions, cultures and disciplines. It will focus on pre- and post-publication censorship and how censorship was enforced, resisted, and accepted across Europe. The course will consider why texts have attracted censure how that affected the production, transmission and reception of problematic texts. It will not only examine the position of the censor but also the roles that scribes, printers, booksellers, royal, and ecclesiastical officials all played in the censorship process. The course will further question whether censorship is justified, or even achievable. Through this course, students will be able to reflect on manuscript and print culture, heresy, literature, the Reformation, monarchy, and the Office of the Inquisition.

Adopting an intersectional approach, we will examine women's changing roles as wage earners, mothers, and activists. We will also explore how prevailing ideas about race, gender, work, and the family shaped women's lives, in both the public and private arenas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will survey American history from the Colonial Era to the present with two premises in mind: that the natural world is not simply a passive background to human history but rather an active participant in historical change, and that human attitudes toward nature are both shaped by and in turn shape social, political, and economic behavior. The course will cover formal schools of thought about the natural world?from Transcendentalism to the conservation and environmental movements?but also discuss the many informal intersections of human activity and natural systems, from European colonialism to property regimes, migration and transportation, industry, consumer practices, war, technological innovation, political ideology, and food production.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
How human and nonhuman history are bound together.
How the nonhuman world has shaped American history.
How to better analyze texts and construct arguments.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course examines major themes and shifts in American culture over the period 1820-1890. The course will consider: popular theatre, including blackface minstrelsy; urban entertainments and cultural authority; backwoods brawling; sentimental fiction and antebellum women's culture; the emergence of cultural categories for "high" and "low" art; and the emergence of mass culture in the industrial age. Students will be introduced not only to "more" history, but also to different methods of "doing" history.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students will understand the development of a distinctive American popular culture, the role of African-Americans in the creation of American culture, and the interplay between popular and elite forms of culture in the United States.

name: Legal and Constitutional History of the United States: Colonial Period to 1850

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores some of the major questions of American legal history from the colonial era to 1850. First, we will examine how and why the American colonies developed their laws and legal institutions, and how these evolved over time. Next, we will explore the legal, political, and social forces that led to the American Revolution, and we will look at how Americans drew on their legal experiences in drafting a constitution. We will then examine how judicial and legislative action guided and enabled explosive economic growth in the nineteenth century. Not everyone was able to participate in the new economy, however; we will explore how the law created separate categories for American Indians, African Americans, and white women that limited their participation in law, politics, and society.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of this course, you should be able to: read, understand, and analyze different kinds of legal texts; understand a variety of legal concepts and doctrines and their meaning in historical context; understand the distinct roles played by different actors (judges, legislatures, lawyers, litigants, voters, etc.) within the legal system; and make cogent, evidence-based arguments about these core themes in law and legal history.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureDiscussion section

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: three papers; class participation

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None. A primary source coursepack and other readings will be available for download via Canvas; students may but are not required to purchase a printed copy of the primary source coursepack at Quartet Copies.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas

name: Development of the Modern American City: 1880-Present

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the second half of a two-quarter course dealing with urbanization and urban communities in America. The second quarter deals with the period from 1870 onward. Topics include the role of cities in the formation of an industrial society, the influence of immigration and rural-urban migration, racial discrimination, political machines, professional planning, the automobile, electronic media, and the expansion of the federal role in city government. History 322-1 is NOT a prerequisite for 322-2.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
-understand the relationships between economic and technological changes and urban development.

-understand the roles of immigration, migration, and race in shaping physical and social geography of U.S. cities.

-understand the evolution of governance in cities and suburbs, and their relationships to the national state.

-gain a sense of how all these elements of history shaped the experience of urban life in different times and locales.

-gain knowledge enabling participation in current debates about urban inequalities, racial conflict diversity, financial crises, and planning.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureDiscussion section

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students may choose one of three grading options. In all three cases, final course grades will include four components, and the first two will be the same for everyone: class participation (10%) and an in-class midterm (30%). Details on the remaining two components in each option will be given out on the first day of class, and students must make a choice by the date of the mid-term.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This will be a course about what happened to Russia after it became a major European power in the early 18th century. Becoming and then remaining a recognized power transformed Russia in many ways. In order to compete, Russia had to adopt and adapt European military ways, big chunks of European culture, and European technology. But in forcing through those changes, the Russian government became more autocratic than it ever had been before, and introduced a fatal division between the Europeanized elite and the mass of peasantry, who lived in a traditional cultural world. Those two fundament conflicts?autocratic government vs. Europeanizing elite, Europeanizing elite vs. traditional peasantry?structured Russian history down to the 1917 Revolution.

History Area of Concentration: European

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The basic characteristics of Russian history from 1700 to 1917; how to think about societies that are very different from our own.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Europe

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course examines the Holocaust of European Jews from its origins through its aftermath in the context of Nazi Germany's murderous campaigns against other groups of victims, including the disabled, sexual minorities, Roma, and Slavs. We will read first-hand accounts and analyze primary documents written by victims and perpetrators as we seek to understand the causes, course, and consequences of the genocidal policies of Germany and its Axis allies. From Vichy France in the West to the occupied Soviet territories in the East, the persecution, expropriation, and murder of millions involved countless civilians and state officials. With a special focus on Eastern Europe, where the greatest number of Jews lived and nearly all of the murdered perished, we will explore questions of local complicity, the motives of perpetrators and of those who sought to impede them, and the responses of the continent's Jews and other victims to the onslaught. The course will end with a consideration of postwar efforts to punish the Holocaust's perpetrators, to commemorate its victims, and to deny its very existence.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will gain extensive knowledge of the causes, course, and consequences of the Holocaust of European Jews from its origins through its aftermath in the context of Nazi Germany's murderous campaigns against other groups of victims. Students will learn how to read, analyze, and discuss primary sources written both by victims and perpetrators of the Holocaust.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: European

name: History of South Africa, Early Times to 1879

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: CONQUEST, VIOLENCE, & RELIGIOUS VISIONS. Long before the industrialization that revolutionized society at the end of the 19th century, South Africa's history was filled with sweeping drama. We will look at some of those earlier dramas: the troubled relations between early Dutch settlers and their pastoralist neighbors, which alternated between intimacy and genocide; Zulu state-building and its aftermath in the early 19th century, when political and military innovations supposedly led to a wave of war and insecurity; the clash of expanding frontiers, African and European, that resulted in violence and mass religious visions. Too often, these stories have been shaped by the perspective of the modern experience of racial segregation and apartheid, as if what happened before 1900 was determined by what came after. One of our tasks will be to consider the dangers of imposing grand narratives on events of the past. In the South African case, we will find, such narratives rest on anachronistic concepts of nation, race, and tribe.

descriptions.value: Three short papers; classroom participation

Most readings will be articles, documents, and book chapters posted online.

name: History of Modern China: Late Imperial China, 1600-1911

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How did China "become modern?" History 381-1 is a survey of Chinese history from the Manchu conquest of China in 1644 (which launched the Qing dynasty) to the Revolution of 1911 and the inauguration of the Republic of China. The course focuses on the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, a period of wide-ranging and profound transformations, including the transformation of the local elite, of traditional women's lives, of political culture, and of industrial production. Many of these changes had been ongoing, but they were reshaped by the challenges of European, American, and Japanese imperialism. In our discussion of imperialism we will address the violent humiliations of China's encounter with the modern West, but also will consider whether China itself can be considered to have been an "imperialist" power in Central Asia. It was during this period that the modern map of China?incorporating Xinjiang and Tibet?was drawn. We also will ponder both the applicability of the term "modern" to Chinese history and how the Chinese experience with imperialism has shaped their understanding of international relations. This is the first quarter of a two-quarter sequence on late imperial and modern Chinese history from the seventeenth century to the present (the two courses stand on their own and you do not have to take both).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will have a basic understanding of how China transitioned from a "traditional" to a "modern" empire, how to construct arguments on the basis of evidence and sound logic, and how to write clearly and convincingly.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Asia/Middle East

name: History of Modern South Asia, ca. 1750-present

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This survey course will introduce students to over two hundred years of the history of South Asia - home to nearly one-fourth of the world's population today - and South Asian communities. From the mid-eighteenth century to the present, South Asia has witnessed multiple political transitions - from Mughal sovereignty to British colonial rule, from British authority to post-colonial nation-building, and the creation of new territorial nation-states. Dilemmas rooted in histories of imperialism haunt South Asian nation-states and South Asian communities living in Europe, the United States, and other parts of the world today. In this course, we will examine a range of themes and issues related to this diverse region and its complex histories. How did the British state consolidate political control in this region? How did colonial authority transform during these centuries? How did British Indians challenge the many edifices of imperialism and wrest political independence in 1947? What is the place of imperialism in the creation and evolution of diasporic South Asian communities? In addition, we will reflect on socio-political movements that sought to redress gender and caste inequality and investigate their fraught relationship with the colonial state, anti-colonial nationalism, and the ongoing project of post-colonial nation-making. Key themes include: ideologies and practices of imperialism; anti-colonial nationalisms and their challenges; processes of post-colonial nation-making; South Asian diasporas in colonial and post-colonial eras; nationalisms, languages, religions, gender, caste, and class. In course of investigating these themes, we will run into a range of key figures and events: Rokeya Sakhawat Hossain and Sayyid Ahmad Khan; Gandhi, Jinnah, Nehru, and Ambedkar; World Wars and South Asian men; Partition, and communal violence; Indira Gandhi, Zia al-Huq, and Benazir Bhutto.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Barbara Metcalf and Thomas Metcalf, A Concise History of Modern India. 3rd revised edition. Cambridge, 2012.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History area of concentration: Asia/Middle East

name: History of Contemporary Southeast Asia Since 1945

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course addresses the history of Southeast Asia from the end of World War II to the Present, a period of rapid and sometimes bewildering change in the region. The course will explore such themes as decolonization; the establishment of authoritarian states; the participation of the region in the Global Cold War; the effects of Import Substitution Industrialization and Export Oriented Industrialization on domestic populations; the management of ethnic and religious diversity; growing social stratification; and the rise of popular democratic movements, among others. We will seek to understand commonalities of experience across Southeast Asia that might warrant it being called a ?region.'

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Asia/Middle East

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Origins of Zionism

What does the "national home" for the Jewish people, mentioned in the Balfour Declaration, imply? Why did Jewish national revivalists chose the land of Israel and not Uganda seeking to establish a Jewish State? Why did they prefer ancient and elitist Hebrew to their contemporary spoken German, Yiddish, or Russian? How did they plan to deal with the Arab population in the contemporary Palestine - and how did the Arab population in Palestine respond to their influx? Focusing on Europe between the 1860s and the 1920s, this course traces the rise of the Jewish movement of national revivalism, contextualizes it against the backdrop of the rising European nationalisms, discusses the forging of new Jewish identities, and analyzes the causes of modern Middle Eastern conflicts. The course discusses how various groups of enthusiasts and visionaries with diverse political convictions made the creation of the state possible. Students will consider the contribution to Zionist movement of political leaders, military figures, philosophers, journalists, women, farmers, writers, and artists. The diversities of Zionism will be in the focus of the class discussion. Explore how diversified groups of national-minded individuals morphed into an ambitious and contradictory modern political movement.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: How to analyze the variety of primary sources related to Jewish diaspora nationalism, how to contextualize Zionism within the context of European nationalisms of the 19th-20th century, how to explain the rivalry between Jewish and Arab nationalism, and how to explore and explain various trends in the Zionist movement.

descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students' grades will be based on two response papers (2 pages), a final take-home research paper (13 pages), active participation in class discussions, and two oral presentations

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Shlomo Avineri, The Making of Modern Zionism: The Intellectual Origins of the Jewish State (Basic Books, 2017) [paperback]

name: Topics In History
topic: Political Islam, Hamas, and Islamic Jihad

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Political Islam, Hamas and Islamic Jihad

The seminar discusses the historical background to the rise of political Islam within the Palestinian society, reviewing three periods: Mandatory Palestine (1920s - 1940s), the West Bank and Gaza under Jordan and Egypt's rule (1948-1967), and Israel since 1967. The central part of the seminar focuses in more detail on Hamas, "Islamic Jihad," and the Islamic Movement in Israel. It analyses the causes for the rise of revivalist Islam in the territories and in Israel since the 1970s. It deals with the ideology and political platform of Hamas as outlined in its "Charter" (the Islamicization of the Israel-Arab conflict, the Islamicization of the Palestinian nation identity). We will examine the doctrinal and practical principle of Jihad and the idea of martyrdom in Islam (Istishad). A special emphasis will be laid on suicide bombing from a doctrinal and practical point of view. The seminar examines the political participation of Hamas (Municipal, Legislative Council elections - 2006) and its relationship with the PLO. Finally the seminar reviews the rise of the Islamic Movement in Israel, its particular characteristics, the political divide of the movement (1996) and its role as a social, economic and cultural agent of change in the life of the Arab minority in Israel.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Understand the complexities and the political roots of a modern-day ideologist Islamist Jihadist movement.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Asia/Middle East

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Revolutionary Egypt under Nasser and Sadat

This will be a seminar-colloquium focusing on the background of the July, 1952 Revolution and controversies surrounding the course of its development. We shall examine the major issues of the British occupation, the Palace faction and the centrist Wafd Party-in the context of their spiraling confrontation. We shall analyze the background of Gamal Abd al-Nasir (Nasser) and his associates (including Anwar al-Sadat) in order to pose a fundamental question: were these individuals committed to genuine social change or did they remain bourgeois capitalists, psychologically tied to the West, and thus dependent on it? Subsequently, we shall examine Egypt's involvement with the Palestine Problem, dilemmas of economic growth, international alignments, and the 'Cold Peace' with Israel.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Background to the crucial political event in the 20th-century Arab world; context of Nasser and Sadat as social reformers and authoritarian leaders; debate over legacy of revolution in Egypt and the larger global community; opportunity to research topics of interest to student participants

For 395/301 registration, a participant's grade will be determined by evaluation of active participation in discussion (50%) and submission of a final analytical/research paper (15-25pp) (50%).

name: Topics In History
topic: The History of Predicting the Future

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: History of Predicting the Future

The past and present are shaped in large part by our beliefs about what the future holds. In this seminar, we will investigate human attempts to anticipate events yet to come, from antiquity until the present (but with an emphasis on the period since 1800). How have people in different times and places gone about anticipating the future? What phenomena have gripped their attention: weather, economy, human society, or individual fate? Have their imaginations been utopian, dystopian, or even apocalyptic, and what does that tell us about the historical moment in which they lived? And crucially, what happened when predictions failed?as so often happened? Using a global range of primary and secondary sources, from revealed prophecies and science fiction to genetic codes and financial speculations, we will examine why and how our historical subjects believed the future might be foreseeable. This course fits today's concerns about the future of the environment (notably climate change) and humanity into a long history of decision-making in the face of uncertainty.

descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas, European, Africa/Middle East, Asia/Middle East, Global

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Mass Violence

In spite of the moral condemnation by numerous religious, political and intellectual leaders and the massive (national and international) efforts aiming to prevent it, mass violence - in its extreme forms, such as mass murder and genocide affecting groups of people - was and still is a widespread phenomenon in human societies. Recently, numerous scholars have argued that, since the advent of modernity, mass violence has become more murderous, especially during the last century. Its persistence and intensification has triggered a lot of scholarly debates about its origins and nature, particularly how it functions and why so many people got implicated in the violence. This course aims to examine various theories and case studies of extreme mass violence, focusing on the dynamics of group behavior and social, political, economic, gender, and psychological factors that shaped cases of collective violence especially during the twentieth century. The main goal is to discuss various cases of extreme mass violence that targeted entire communities based on their group identity, focusing on the perpetrators and on the various explanations of their murderous behavior and the mechanism of mass violence.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By completing this course, you are expected to be able to:
? Familiarize yourselves with the major concepts and cases of extreme forms of mass violence (such as genocide, politicide, ethnic cleansing, mass atrocity)
? Read critically, understand and critically analyze works of history produced by scholars with different methodological and theoretical approaches to the study of extreme mass violence
? Acquire an understanding of the strengths, weaknesses, and challenges of the historical craft
? Improve your analytical, writing and communication skills through close readings of texts, class discussions, writing papers, and making presentations
? Learn to recognize historical arguments regarding controversial historical questions and to formulate and support an original historical argument using primary and secondary sources
? Learn how to properly structure a thesis-driven paper, how to apply appropriate methods of citation, and how to use a clear writing style that conveys historical knowledge ideas, and evidence in a mature, readily understood manner.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: European, Africa/Middle East, Global

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Shari'a in Global History

This course explores the possibilities and challenges of writing a global history of the Shar??a. The approach will be double. It will use the Shar??a as both the object of an historiographical operation and as a resource for thinking historically. For the first, the course will survey the development of the major schools jurisprudence in the eighth and ninth century, their establishment throughout Africa, Asia, and Southern Europe through the classical period, modern transformations of the Shar??a since the 18th century, and contemporary developments in which diverse actors around the globe contest the meanings and relationships of the Shar??a, liberal democracy, and the modern state. For the second, the course will identify the epistemological tools and documentary sources affiliated with the Shar??a that might be productively employed in the historian's craft. In other words, "Shar??a in Global History" will both historicize what is often over-translated as Islamic law on the global scale and think the global in historically Islamic terms.

name: Research Seminar
topic: Problems of Poverty in Anglo-American Culture

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: The Problem of Poverty in Anglo-American Culture
This course will explore recurrent attempts to define, explain, and ameliorate poverty in England and the United States from the 18th century to the late 20th. Topics include: the relationship between poverty and the commercial/industrial revolution; the place of poverty in Enlightenment and Utilitarian thought; changing (and unchanging) ideas about the connections between poverty and moral character, education, unemployment, gender, and ethnic/racial inheritance; the periodic emergence of poverty as a political issue; the concept of an "underworld" or "underclass;" and the shifting rhetoric of sympathy and fear.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
-how to talk about poverty with more precision and historical context.
-how current discussions about poverty are shaped by the inheritance of the English Poor Law.
-how economic and social developments of the 19th and 20th centuries modified that inheritance.
-how versions of the "welfare state" emerged in England and the United States.
-how the "war on poverty," the "war on drugs," and the "war on welfare" conditioned 21st century policy discussions.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: SeminarDiscussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Initial paper 5%, Participation and Presentations 20%, Stages in Research, 20%, Final research paper 55%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Jacob Riis, How The Other Half Lives. BE SURE TO GET THE DOVER EDITION: ISBN 9780486220123
Walter Trattner, From Poor Law to Welfare State. Free Press ISBN 9780684854717
Jane Addams, Twenty Years at Hull House. Signet
ISBN 9780451527394
Michael Harrington, The Other America. Scribner
ISBN 9780684826783

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: HISTORY HONORS SEMINAR - Students are admitted by invitation only.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Revolution

This course introduces major debates in the comparative history of revolution. The global analysis starts in France; proceeds with the spread of revolutionary ideologies in the Americas; returns to Europe for 1848 and 1917; tacks back to the Americas for peasant revolutions in Mexico and Cuba; and then migrates to China before ending in a consideration of the revolutions that never happened. En route we will explore the intellectual history of revolution in the works of Tocqueville, Marx, Lenin, James, and Guevara, juxtaposing these texts with more recent scholarship to shed light on their multiple qualities: primary sources, political prescriptions and analytical frameworks.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Presentation, Participation, Term Paper

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Lynn Hunt, Politics, Culture, and Class in the French Revolution
(University of California Press, 2004) ISBN 13: 9780520241565
Alexis de Tocqueville, The Ancien Régime and the Revolution (London, 2008) ISBN-13: 978-0141441641
C.L.R. James, Black Jacobins (London, 2001) ISBN-13: 978-0140299816
Sheila Fitzpatrick, The Russian Revolution (2017) ISBN-13: 978-0198806707
Alan Knight, The Mexican Revolution (Nebraska, 1990), vol 1. ISBN 0-8032-7770-9
William Hinton, Fanshen: A Documentary of Revolution in a Chinese Village (2008) ISBN-13: 978-1583671757
Samuel Farber, The Origins of the Cuban Revolution Reconsidered (University of North Carolina Press, 2006) ISBN-13: 978-0807856734

The Tocqueville, James and Marx texts may be bought in any edition, the former in French if so desired; the Marx texts are also available free online.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: History and Biography

This seminar critically examines the relationship between historical writing and the practice of biography. We will be particularly concerned with the use of biographical methods and characterization in the construction of historical narrative. Together we will read a study of the Life of Saint Teresa of Avila, a biography of the seventeenth-century Kangxi emperor; the story of a nineteenth-century French clog maker; a collective portrait of American sharecroppers during the Great Depression; the Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas; and a study of the Austrian philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein, among other texts. We will consider, inter alia, the problem of knowing other minds; the relationship between biographical fact and narrative fiction; the role of ego-documents in the construction of biography; and how to give shape to the story of a life.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance, Participation, and Presentation (30%); Prospectus (20%); Final Essay (50%)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
A.S. Byatt, The Biographer's Tale (New York: Knopf, 2001), ISBN: 978-0375725081
Jonathan Spence, Emperor of China: Self-Portrait of K'ang-His (New York: Vintage, 1988). ISBN: 978-0679720744
James Agee and Walker Evans, Let Us Now Praise Famous Men (New York: Mariner, 2001). ISBN: 978-0618127498.
Alain Corbin, The Life of an Unknown: The Rediscovered World of a Clog Maker in Nineteenth-Century France (New York: Columbia University Press, 2001). ISBN: 978-0231118408
Hugh Trevor-Roper, Hermit of Peking: The Hidden Lofe of Sir Edmund Backhouse (New York: Knopf, 1977). ISBN: 978-1906011017
Gertrude Stein, The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklass (New York: Vintage, 1990). ISBN: 978-0679724636
Carlos Eire, The Life of St. Teresa of Avila: A Biography (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2019). ISBN: 978-0691164939
Ray Monk, Wittgenstein: The Duty of Genius (London: Penguin, 1991). ISBN: 978-0140159950

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Global

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Global Indigenous Histories

In 2007, the United Nations General Assembly adopted the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP) following decades of negotiation. In this graduate seminar, we will examine the 20th century origins of the global movement for Indigenous rights and seek an understanding of the varied meanings of Indigeneity (along with Aboriginality and Autochthony) across time and space. We will emphasize the comparative study of Indigenous-state relations and highlight how the concept of Indigenous is a shorthand for peoples who are variously identified as original, first, tribal, local, and traditional, in addition to their own names for themselves. Our readings will draw from scholarship in history, anthropology, and Native American and Indigenous Studies (NAIS), spanning geographies from Hawai'i to the Russian Arctic to Cameroon.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Contact Instructor

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

name: General Field Seminar in American History

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to the history and historiography of early America, from the colonial period through the founding of the United States. Each week, moving in roughly chronological order, we will discuss major scholarly debates on topics ranging from colonial encounters, slavery, sex, and religion, to revolutionary and founding politics. We will quickly find that if the field of early American history is a stage, its cast, setting, and plot have changed profoundly over the past several decades (as Alan Taylor observes in American Colonies). Its starring actors used to be Englishmen on the eastern coast of North America. Now, historians engage a more sprawling cast of characters: men and women from hundreds of ethnic, religious, and linguistic backgrounds, who collectively inhabit an entire continent-not to mention islands and oceans. Drawing from classic accounts as well as from more recent scholarship, we will consider the benefits and the drawbacks of these more recent approaches, and we will also debate future possibilities for the field. Through close readings of texts, critical discussions, book reviews, and exploration of individual interests, we will hone our abilities to identify, assess, and develop historical arguments, methodologies, and interpretative frameworks.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Participants should expect to:
1) learn more about the people, places, and events that shaped the early American past.
2) hone your abilities to assess arguments, methodologies, and evidence while engaging some of the major scholarly debates in this field.
3) sharpen your skills as teachers and discussion leaders.
4) refine your writing skills and develop authorial "voices."

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: participation (25%); book reviews (20%); final paper (55%)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBA

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas

name: Literature of Early Modern English Hist

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar examines the early British Empire from its origins to 1800. How did Great Britain, a small windswept island off the northwestern coast of Europe, manage to build a world-spanning empire? We will begin by discussing imperial ideologies, outlining the contrasts that the British liked to draw between their own imperium and that of other global powers, especially the Spanish. We will then turn to the manifestations of empire in the Atlantic and Indian Oceans, exploring patterns of trade and settlement; transformations in international law; the development of racialized thinking; the intersection of Enlightenment science and natural history collecting; and the experiences of men and women, enslaved and free.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will read major works of history and, in so doing, will develop their own analyses of large-scale historical phenomena. Students will assess the strengths and limitations of various methodological approaches to history.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion; Presentations; Papers

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas, European, Asia/Middle East

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is a graduate field seminar on Chinese history from roughly 1550 to 1912 (some of our readings will take us to 1937). The course focuses on the early modern transformation of China under its last imperial rulers, the Qing. The seminar has two goals. The first is to introduce advanced students to some of the influential English-language scholarship published on Chinese history over the past twenty-five years, and we will focus in particular on topics that have transformed the field during this time. These topics include Chinese-Inner Asian relations and the "new Qing history," gender and sexuality, and Chinese legal culture. Other issues to be addressed include imperialism, intellectual transition, commercialization, and the social and religious roots of late imperial peasant uprisings. We will critically engage with the issue of periodization, for the course begins in a late imperial or "traditional" context and, by the end of the seminar, we will be knee deep in the scholarly literature on "modern" China. Two questions that will engage us, therefore, are: 1. can the early Qing fruitfully be characterized as China's "early modern" period and 2. by what process did China "become modern?" The second goal of the course is to enable students to explore in greater detail a topic of particular interest to them and one that will advance their personal research agendas. This latter goal will be achieved through the writing of a term paper on the most important secondary sources (in any language) relating to that topic.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: How to assess important works of historical scholarship in the early modern and modern periods.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion (25%), short paper (25%), term paper (50%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Tentative Reading list (many of these books are available online via the library catalog):

Peter Perdue, China Marches West: The Qing Conquest of Central Eurasia (Harvard, 2005).

Matthew Sommer, Sex, Law, and Society in Late Imperial China (Stanford, 2000).

Benjamin Elman, On Their Own Terms: Science in China, 1550-1900 (Harvard, 2005).

Matthew W. Mosca. From Frontier Policy to Foreign Policy: The Question of India and the Transformation of Geopolitics in Qing China. Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2013.

Melissa Macauley. Chinese Territorialism: The Southeastern Martime Frontier, 1566-1929 (forthcoming).

Pomeranz, Kenneth. The Great Divergence: China, Europe, and The Making of the Modern World Economy. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2000.

William T. Rowe. Speaking of Profit: Bao Shichen and Reform in Nineteenth-Century China. Cambridge: Harvard University Asia Center, 2018.

Tobie Meyer-Fong, What Remains: Coming to Terms With Civil War in Nineteenth-Century China (Stanford, 2013). [Available electronically via library].

Rudolf Wagner. Reenacting the Heavenly Vision: The Role of Religion in the Taiping Rebellion (Berkeley)

Paul Cohen, History in Three Keys: The Boxers as Event, Experience, and Myth (Columbia, 1997).

etc. Plus journal articles.

name: Topics in History
topic: Central Europe from the Habsburgs to Hitler

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Central Europe from the Habsburgs to Hitler

This course examines the history of the diverse lands and peoples of the Habsburg Monarchy (known in its last decades as Austria-Hungary) from its rise in the sixteenth century to its demise amid the cataclysm of the First World War. Today, the territory that the Habsburgs once ruled in Central Europe encompasses all or part of a dozen European countries from Italy in the West to Romania in the East, Poland to the north, and Bosnia to the south. At the empire's greatest expanse, its peoples spoke more than a dozen major languages and belonged to various branches of Christianity, Judaism and Islam. With an eye to this great diversity, we will read different historiographical approaches to the cultural, economic, political, social and intellectual history of the empire and its successor states. We will end with the interwar Habsburg legacy and its destruction during the years of Nazi conquest.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Graduate Students Only

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will gain extensive knowledge of the history of the Habsburg Monarchy and familiarity with its historical literature.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion, presentations, weekly response papers.

All books will also be available on reserve - no need to order any.

Evans, R. J. W. The Making of the Habsburg Monarchy, 1550-1700 (Oxford UP, 1970). [ISBN-13: 978-0198225607]
Frank, Alison. Oil Empire: Visions of Prosperity in Austrian Galicia (Harvard UP, 2007) [ISBN 9780674025417]

Schoerske, Carl. Fin-de-siècle Vienna: Politics and Culture (Penguin, 1980) [ISBN 9780394744780]

Zahra, Tara. The Great Departure: Mass Migration from Eastern Europe and the Making of the Free World (Norton, 2017) [ISBN-13: 978-0393353723]

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Note: This course is only open to first-year students accepted into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program.

This class considers the way in which ?drugs'?ranging from botanical commodities such as sugar, tobacco, and cannabis, to processed goods like cocaine, opiates, and LSD?have participated in constructing the modern world. The course explores the ways in which these drugs shape trade, law, economies, and both national and international politics. We will also consider the ideas people come to carry with them about these global goods. We will be tracing these relationships through object histories, history, and comparative political analysis.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Note: This course is only open to first-year students accepted into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Possible readings include:

Sidney Mintz, Sweetness and Power. The Place of Sugar in Modern History (1985).
Barbara L. Voss, "The Archaeology of Overseas Chinese Communities." In World Archaeology 37, no. 3 (2005): 424-39.
Randall H. McGuire, "The Study of Ethnicity in Historical Archaeology." In Journal of Anthropological Archaeology 1, no. 2 (1982): 159-78.
Alexandra Hartnett, and Shannon Lee Dawdy. "The Archaeology of Illegal and Illicit Economies." In Annual Review of Anthropology 12, no. 4 (2013).
David Courtwright, Forces of Habit. Drugs and the Making of the Modern World (2002).
Paul Gootenberg, Andean Cocaine. The Making of a Global Drug (2008)
Elaine Carey, Women Drug Traffickers. Mules, Bosses and Organized Crime (2014).
David Musto, The American Disease. Origins of Narcotics Control (1999).
Guillermo Trejo and Sandra Ley, "Why Did Drug Cartels Go to War in Mexico? Subnational Party Alternation, the Breakdown of Criminal Protection, and the Onset of Large-Scale Violence." In Comparative Political Studies (2017).
Vanda Felbab-Brown, "The Coca Connection: Conflict and Drugs in Colombia and Peru." In Journal of Conflict Studies, 25 (2005): 104-128.
Michelle Alexander, The New Jim Crow. Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness (2012).
Peter Andreas, "America's Century-Long Drug War". In Smuggler Nation: How Illicit Trade Made America (2013).

Possible films Include:

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Note: This course is only open to first-year students accepted into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program.

This class considers the way in which ?drugs'?ranging from botanical commodities such as sugar, tobacco, and cannabis, to processed goods like cocaine, opiates, and LSD?have participated in constructing the modern world. The course explores the ways in which these drugs shape trade, law, economies, and both national and international politics. We will also consider the ideas people come to carry with them about these global goods. We will be tracing these relationships through object histories, history, and comparative political analysis.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Note: This course is only open to first-year students accepted into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Media Theory: An Introduction

How do media impact our sense of such fundamental concepts as personhood, social life, and time and space? How do new technologies transform sensory experience at different moments in history? This course provides an introduction to the field of theoretical writings within the humanities addressing the nature of media and the role of technology in twentieth- and twenty-first century culture. We will pay close attention to the work of key media theorists, including (but not limited to) Walter Benjamin, Marshall McLuhan, and Donna Haraway. We will also analyze works of art, sound, film, and literature in order to catalyze, test, and expand our sense of how media matter.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Short lectures, discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Exams, short essays, discussion

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Course reader

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Economics and the Humanities: Understanding Choice in the Past, Present, and Future

This course offers a cross-disciplinary approach to the concept of alternatives and choices. At any given moment, how many alternatives are possible? Is there really such a thing as chance or choice? On what basis do we choose? How does our understanding of the past affect the future? Can we predict the future? Professor Gary Saul Morson, a specialist in literature, and Professor Morton Schapiro, President of Northwestern and a labor economist specializing in the economics of higher education, will themselves offer alternative approaches to these questions based on the presuppositions of their respective disciplines. If you enjoyed reading The Signal and the Noise and want to dig into topics and questions like uncertainty, prediction, modelling, and judgment, this class is the perfect complement.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The class will be structured as a debate with no single right answer to each question. Readings will be taken from literature, philosophy, economics, history, evolutionary theory, and other disciplines.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Assignments include weekly response papers, 3 longer argumentative essays, and class discussion participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Course materials will be provided as a reading packet and available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Space in this extremely popular course is limited to 80 students.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Shakespeare: Global, Local, Digital

Performance, Imitation, Interpretation, Adaptation. What happens when Shakespeare's plays time travel, migrate across the globe, mutate into new forms, and reach audiences through new media? From Renaissance London to 21st -century India, from apartheid South Africa to modern China, readers have remade Shakespeare's plays to address their own local issues. In this class, we will reflect on the adaptation and appropriation of Shakespeare in cultures of the world across various scales, from the local to the global, and through a range of media?from the latest digital platforms to traditional forms like print, theater, and film. Like Shakespeare's plays, our conversations will take place in multiple venues and from multiple perspectives, from the traditional classroom to the digital media lab, from the rare books room to the stages of Chicago's theaters. We will consider how Othello, Macbeth, and The Merchant of Venice have been continually reinvented across the globe in many media, exploring texts such as Shishir Kurup's Merchant on Venice, Toni Morrison's Desdemona, Msomi's uMabatha, Tayeb Salih's Season of Migration to the North, the teen film O, and scenes from films, including Throne of Blood and Tangata Whai Rawa o Weniti, Te (the Maori Merchant of Venice). Our exploration will culminate with students collaborating to build a digital curation involving Shakespeare's works.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Papers, presentations, digital curation

descriptions.value:
Shakespeare, The Merchant of Venice, ed. Halio (Oxford), ISBN 978-0199535859

Shakespeare, Macbeth (Oxford), ISBN 978-0199535835

Shakespeare, Othello, ed. Neill (Oxford), ISBN 978-0199535873

Toni Morrison, Desdemona, ISBN 978-1849433891

name: Special Topics in the Humanities
topic: Fire and Blood: Resource Extraction & Energy

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Fire and Blood: Resources, Energy, and Society

Climate crisis, directly linked to CO2 emissions from centuries of burning fossil fuels, has brought energy resources to the center of public attention. This course will survey works of anthropology, history, and geography as well as films and novels to understand how various resources and energy systems relate to sociocultural practices and politics throughout the world. Focusing on one energy resource each week, "Fire and Blood" will examine how uranium, wind, coal, light, oil, water, and other materials are made into sources of power?both physical and political. It will trace the movement of resources from the subsoil, atmosphere, or riverbeds to pipelines, power plants, dams, turbines, or other kinds of energy infrastructures; and finally, to the electrified streets of urban Mumbai, the wastelands of Navajo County, or the melting ice sheets of the Arctic. After discussing the toxic legacies of fossil fuels and nuclear things, we will end the course by reading texts on "energy transition" and post-carbon futures. By the end of the course, each student will have produced a research paper on an existing, past, or planned energy resource project of their choice from anywhere in the world.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Teaching Method consists of weekly readings, class participation and presentation, and a final research project. Weekly readings will be case studies derived from anthropological and other humanistic social sciences. Each week will focus on a different energy research. The day before class meetings, students will post a reading response on Canvas. These questions will help shape class discussion. For each meeting, two students will be responsible for presenting the readings to the class. The presentations should be geared towards starting discussions based on the main points in the readings. For the final research project, which will be developed throughout the quarter with feedback from fellow students and the instructor, students will pick an energy resource project of their choice. They will write a short research proposal outlining the project and main questions to be answered, a draft research paper including bibliography, and a final research paper. Students will also have the option to produce a poster presentation at the end of the course (details TBA). Students will be asked present their research projects during the final week of classes.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Attendance, Participation, and Weekly Presentations 15%
Weekly Reading Questions and Writing Prompts 15%
Research Paper Proposal 10%
First Draft of Research Paper 20%
Final Research Paper and Presentation 40%
