descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is focused on fluency and comprehensibility in conversation in both informal and academic settings. It is designed to help students develop and refine their English conversation, discussion, and discourse skills. While some attention will be given to American English intonation, word stress, and pronunciation, the primary purpose of this class is to explore functions of American English important for fluency in conversational speech. This will help improve your performance on tasks and activities involving spoken English, such as oral proficiency exams, presentations, teaching, and day-to-day social interactions. Active participation and evidence of progress towards proficiency must be demonstrated in order to achieve a satisfactory grade in the course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:

1. Identify personal strengths and weaknesses in their communicative competence in American English (i.e. linguistic competence, sociolinguistic competence, discourse competence, functional competence, and strategic competence) from the use of data from self-assessments and instructor feedback.
2. Demonstrate progress toward proficiency in using English for academic purposes, e.g.,
a. Improve verbal communication skills required for academic presentations in both casual settings (e.g., office-hours consultations) and formal settings (e.g., job talks)
b. Improve written communication skills required for academic presentations, e.g., organization and composition of posters, slides, and handouts.
c. Utilize various skills required for clear and effective communication across these modalities, e.g., use of conjunctions for smooth flow of verbal and/or written ideas; appropriate use of focus and emphasis in exposition; strategies for responding to questions
d. Identify and employ different strategies needed for successful communication in different situations, e.g., understanding differences between formal and casual register and terms of address; use of acronyms and jargon for expert audiences vs. plain English for lay audiences
3. Express themselves in American English more comfortably and confidently.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Small group activities, discussion, lecture, online exercises, and presentations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on in-class participation, homework assignments, and presentations.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No required texts (all will be provided by instructor)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a continuation of the fall quarter Integrated Academic Skills curriculum. The goal of the course is to give students the tools to improve their intelligibility and effectiveness when communicating in English, with an emphasis on communication in the American academic context. Students will discuss and practice strategies for making individual and group presentations, reporting on written information, narrating in the past and future time frames, working with small groups, writing email, and networking at professional events. We will develop these skills through a quarter-long group project where students will set up, conduct, and report on an interview with a member of the Northwestern community. Along the way, we will review the sound structure of English with a goal of improved pronunciation and fluency. Students will have an opportunity to consider their own oral English proficiency in light of proficiency assessments used at Northwestern, and will receive feedback on the Versant test performance as well as practice Versant sessions.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:

1. Identify and implement strategies for effective listening and communication in the American academic context, including participating in group discussions, reporting on written information, narrating in past/future timeframes, introducing oneself and networking, email, and delivering formal/informal presentations.

2. Describe key features of the sound structure of English, including the articulation of consonants and vowels, word stress, intonation, and linking.

3. Describe key components of oral language proficiency as measured by the Versant English Test and specified in the ACTFL Can-Do Statements.

4. Identify their own strengths and weaknesses when using spoken English. Demonstrate progress toward achieving goals targeting improved proficiency.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: One of the most important communication skills necessary for a successful academic career is the ability to write effectively in a variety of genres. This course aims to address the needs of nonnative speakers of English in developing their writing skills. We will focus both on the mechanics of English sentences and paragraphs as well as the local and global discourse structure of written texts. A workshop atmosphere is encouraged in the classroom, and online homework assignments encourage students to extend their writing practice into their own fields of expertise and interest. Students will also receive explicit constructive criticism from the instructor on regular electronic submissions. This class is a "hybrid" course, meaning that 50% of the class is conducted online. Rather than meeting for two and a half hours per week, we meet for only one and a quarter hours, and that face-to-face time is spent working on the issues presented in each weekly unit.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
The course is open to international graduate students, visiting scholars, research associates, faculty, and staff of Northwestern University. Auditing is permitted, though priority is given to graduate students who are officially registered for credit. Attendance policy for auditors: two absences w/o notice in a row OR three absences w/ or w/o notice throughout the quarter lead to a drop. Spots will be offered to other auditors until the official drop date. Instructor consent is required.

Students must complete an online form from English Language Programs in order to be eligible for the class and obtain a permission number. Contact elp@northwestern.edu for specific registration instructions.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:

? Describe key features of rhetorical structure of academic written English.
? Identify their specific strengths and weaknesses when using written English.
? Draft, revise, and edit a piece of writing appropriate for an American academic audience, incorporating feedback from the course instructor and peers.
? Demonstrate progress toward improved proficiency (clarity, accuracy, and effectiveness).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Small group activities, discussion, lecture, online exercises, and presentations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: You are expected to complete regular readings and assignments each week, including the online assignments. The concepts introduced in these readings and assignments will form the basis for classroom work, so it is important that you complete them in advance of the class for which they are assigned.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No required texts (all will be provided by instructor)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers topics in acoustic phonetics and speech perception. In the first half of the course, the acoustic theory of speech production is introduced and the acoustic correlates of speech sounds are presented. We also cover acoustic-phonetic features of connected speech. In the second half of the course, we turn our attention to the perception of speech signals. We address such topics as phonetic categorization, speech perception and linguistic experience, and the role of speech perception in phonology.

name: Individual Speech and Language Instruction for Nonnative Speakers of English

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, a trained tutor provides individualized language study for the purpose of increasing nonnative speakers' proficiency in English, in both academic and everyday contexts. At the beginning of the term, students will complete a needs assessment to determine which aspects of spoken English are most critical for current communication skills. These may include: accent and intelligibility, grammatical errors, sociolinguistic skills, intercultural competence, classroom communication skills, formal and informal writing tasks, and more. Together, the tutor and student will create a set of learning goals for the term. The tutor will then provide appropriate practice in each session to help the student acquire the linguistic and academic skills needed to improve communicative competence. Tutors may assign additional work to be completed outside of the session. Students will be expected to reflect on their own progress both periodically and at the end of the term. Active participation and evidence of progress towards learning goals must be demonstrated in order to achieve a satisfactory grade in the course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Instructor consent required.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: At the beginning of the quarter, students will complete an intake assessment with their tutor, and then create individual learning goals for the quarter. Students will be evaluated at the end of the quarter with a self-assessment, recorded speech samples, and documentation of progress towards individual goals by the tutor.

name: Supported Online Speech Training for Nonnative Speakers of English

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, online speech training software provides customized training for the purpose of increasing nonnative speakers' intelligibility in oral English. At the beginning of the term, students will complete an online assessment to establish a baseline of oral proficiency. The software will generate a customized course of study that provides appropriate practice in each session to help the student acquire the language and skills needed to improve intelligibility. Students will be expected to maintain milestones of usage each week during the quarter, and will have access to both periodic and end-of-quarter feedback on their progress. Students will be asked to reflect on their own learning at the end of the term. Active participation and evidence of progress towards improved proficiency must be demonstrated in order to achieve a satisfactory grade in the course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Instructor consent required.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grading is based on completion of an online assessment, meeting of weekly milestones towards usage of the software, and completion of an end of quarter assessment and written end-or-quarter reflection exercise. Students can earn up to 15 additional minutes of active time logged towards their weekly milestone by attending optional drop in help sessions.

descriptions.value: Students will be given a software account for use during the quarter.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
"Your calculus course requires access to MyLab Math (also called MyMathLab). MyLab Math is an online platform that serves as an electronic textbook, an enrichment resource, and a homework portal. MyLab Math includes access to an electronic copy of the textbook; you do not need to purchase a paper copy of the book.

You can acquire the course materials in several ways:

MyLab Math Only - Direct
Purchase MyLab Math access directly from the publisher (Pearson) after setting up your account using instructions provided on the course Canvas site. This should cost $80 (+ tax).
MyLab Math Only - Bookstore
Purchase MyLab Math access from the Northwestern Bookstore, and then set up your account using instructions provided on the course Canvas site. This should cost $106.65 (+ tax).
MyLab Math and Looseleaf Book Bundle
Purchase access to MyLab Math bundled with a looseleaf copy of the textbook from the Northwestern Bookstore, and then set up your account using instructions provided on the course Canvas site. This should cost $146.65 (+ tax).
MyLab Math Only and Used Book
Purchase access to MyLab Math using one of the first two options above (setting up your account using instructions provided on the course Canvas site), and acquire a used copy of the book separately.

IMPORTANT: MyLab Math access codes from any source other than Pearson (following the instructions provided on the course Canvas Site) or the Northwestern Bookstore will not work.

The access you purchase for your course this fall can be used across multiple quarters of calculus courses at Northwestern that use the same textbook (MATH 220-1, 220-2, 226-0, 228-1, 228-2, 230-1, 230-2)."

descriptions.value: Introduction to fundamental mathematical structures, including sets, functions, equivalence relations, and cardinal numbers. Elementary logic and proof techniques. descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
TITLE: Markov Chains and Mixing Times

Take a deck of n = 52 cards and shuffle it. It is intuitive that if you shuffle your deck sufficiently many times, the deck will be in an approximately random order. But how many shuffles are sufficient?

A shuffle is a permutation of the n cards, so we can model card shuffling as a random walk on the group S_n of permutations of n objects. It is an example of a Markov chain, a type of stochastic process that "forgets its past" as it evolves in time. Markov chain models are widely used in many areas such as statistical mechanics, theoretical computer science, cryptography, to name a few. Of great interest are questions about mixing times, that is the length of time the Markov chain has to run to be sufficiently close to its stationary distribution. Frequently, the number of elements in the state space is large, and asymptotic results about rates of convergence, as the size of the state space increases, are relevant. The seminar will examine mixing times for Markov chains as a function of the size and geometry of the state space and will include many examples. Key methods include eigenvalue techniques, coupling techniques, and strong stationary times.

For "riffle shuffles", 8 shuffles will sufficiently mix the deck. Moreover, the seminar will cover the "cut-off phenomenon": For some Markov chains, convergence to stationarity does not happen gradually over time but rather sharply (akin to a phase transition) around a point in time that depends on the size of the group. For riffle-shuffling a deck of n cards, the cut-off occurs at around 3/2 log_2(n) steps.

Prerequisites: A background in undergraduate Probability and in Markov chain theory (such as 311-1, 2 or 310-1, 2), basic Linear Algebra.

This will be an introduction to Langlands functoriality and the trace formula in its many incarnations. Topics include the classical Selberg trace formula for finite volume quotients of the upper half plane, the Selberg trace formula in its modern form, the Jacquet-Langlands correspondence and hints of functoriality, stabilization and the fundamental lemma, langlands' ideas about going "beyond endoscopy" and the relative trace formula and relative functoriality.

Prerequisites: Basic algebraic number theory, up to class field theory. Knowledge of automorphic forms is helpful, but not necessary. Background material will be explained as we proceed.

name: Making the Modern Middle East: Culture, Politics, History

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This team-taught course offers an interdisciplinary introduction to major issues in the history of the Middle East and North Africa since the nineteenth century, and also an introduction to Middle East studies as field of study. That is, we will seek to understand how the modern Middle East was "made," as well as how something called "the Middle East" emerged as a geopolitical entity and a conceptual category. Among the topics explored are the history of the idea of the "Middle East" and the multiples meanings of "modernity" in that context; the complex relations between the Middle East and the West; the historical formation of Middle East nation-states, polities, ideologies, identities, and economies; and the dynamic struggles unfolding in the region since the 2011 Arab uprisings. The course will consider the making of these structures, events, and relationships from a range of perspectives, including imaginative ones. Course material will encompass literary, cinematic, historical, and social science materials, as well as both primary documents and secondary scholarly sources.

name: Seminar in Middle East and North African Studies
topic: Revolutionary Egypt under Nasser and Sadat

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Revolutionary Egypt under Nasser and Sadat

This will be a seminar-colloquium focusing on the background of the July, 1952 Revolution and controversies surrounding the course of its development. We shall examine the major issues of the British occupation, the Palace faction and the centrist Wafd Party-in the context of their spiraling confrontation. We shall analyze the background of Gamal Abd al-Nasir (Nasser) and his associates (including Anwar al-Sadat) in order to pose a fundamental question: were these individuals committed to genuine social change or did they remain bourgeois capitalists, psychologically tied to the West, and thus dependent on it? Subsequently, we shall examine Egypt's involvement with the Palestine Problem, dilemmas of economic growth, international alignments, and the 'Cold Peace' with Israel.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Background to the crucial political event in the 20th-century Arab world; context of Nasser and Sadat as social reformers and authoritarian leaders; debate over legacy of revolution in Egypt and the larger global community; opportunity to research topics of interest to student participants

descriptions.name: Teaching Method

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: No examinations. For 392 registration, a participant's grade will be determined by evaluation of active participation in discussion (50%) and a final review essay submitted at the conclusion of the seminar (50%). For 395/301 registration, a participant's grade will be determined by evaluation of active participation in discussion (50%) and submission of a final analytical/research paper (15-25pp) (50%).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course we will study the collection of stories known in English as The Arabian Nights orThe Thousand and One Nights. While in the contemporary popular imagination the Nights is often reduced to a few well-known stories, this course will take a wider approach to the collection, and study it as the product of an ongoing process of translation, circulation, and exchange. Over the quarter, we will read the earliest of these stories, as well as follow the collection's history from its evolution in Arabic oral and manuscript traditions to its eighteenth- century "discovery" and translation into European languages. While the collection has been called a "book with no author" because of its long history of oral and textual evolution, it could just as easily be called a book of many authors, who include its anonymous Sanskrit, Persian, and Arabic originators and transmitters, its French and English translators, and its modern interpreters. The last third of the course will therefore be devoted to the modern "afterlives" of the collection in novels, film, and theater. We will consider how the Nights has been used in these works as a vehicle for deeply-considered investigations into narrative form and also clichéd and colonially-imbued images of the Middle East. Reading and watching these works next to and against the Arabic versions, we will encounter the vast variety of ways that the Nights has been a source of narrative techniques, literary themes, political allegories, and feminist debates across literary traditions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
NEUROSCI 202-0 introduces students to the cellular and molecular processes that allow the nervous system to produce behavior, with a focus on how electrochemical signals are generated, communicated and integrated to transform different sensations into appropriate actions. We all want to know how the mind works in health and what happens when things go wrong in disease. However, first we need to start with the fundamentals, which this course will provide. Learning about neuroscience is like learning a new language, which will require the introduction of new words and the memorization of terminology. Students will be expected to increase their vocabulary so they can begin to appreciate and discuss neuroscience concepts and research in an informed manner. This is not a survey course, rather it is designed to provide a solid foundation for subsequent coursework that delves more deeply into various topics in neuroscience.
Prerequisite: BIOL_SCI 217-0



Course content is divided into three sections. The first third focuses on the ionic and molecular basis for generating electric signals in neurons. The second third focuses on electrical and chemical communication between neurons, how these connections are adjusted, and how they develop. The final third will focus on simple circuits that illustrate the cellular and molecular mechanisms that allow us to taste, smell, see, hear, feel and move at the right time. It is recommended that reading be performed prior to lectures to help students discover and remedy misconceptions before the midterm exams. Information in the textbook will provide context and introduction of material in lectures.

NEUROSCI 202 will be offered during Fall 2019 and Winter 2020.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: BIOL_SCI 217-0 and must be a neuroscience major.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will acquire a deep understanding of:
1) Fundamental neurobiological principles arising from studies of the nervous system at the cellular and molecular level.
2) History and recent developments in neuroscience research.
3) Methods used to study the nervous system, including specific experimental techniques relevant to cellular and molecular neuroscience, the design, analysis and interpretation of experiments using specific techniques, and the strengths and limitations of those techniques.
4) Ethical issues raised by the growing body of information generated by neuroscience research, including the use of animals.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The format of the course will be that of a semi-flipped classroom. Instead of hearing information for the first time in lecture, students will read and assimilate the basic material from the textbook prior to class. Lectures will assume a working knowledge of the general concepts covered in the assigned chapters, and then expand upon them, principally by focusing on the techniques and recent advances in the field. Class time will also be used to solve problems and to answer questions. The idea is that the lectures will not only provide new information, but also allow students to discover and remedy misconceptions prior to the exams.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
The final grade is not curved and will be broken down as follows:
Reading Quizzes 20%
Midterm 1 20%
Midterm 2 30%
Final exam 30%

Reading quizzes will be assessed on Canvas. Exams will be short answer, and are not strictly cumulative since they will focus on specific lectures. However, the questions in later exams will by necessity assume an accumulation of basic facts and concepts raised earlier on.


NEUROSCI 202-0 WILL BE OFFERED DURING FALL 2019 AND WINTER 2020.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Emphasis on quantitative, electrophysiological studies of the nervous system at the level of single neurons. The course examines in detail the mechanisms that permit nerve cells to generate and propagate electrical signals and to communicate these signals chemically to other cells. Topics will include the electrical and chemical signals of neurons, biophysical analysis of ion channels, and information coding and processing in sensory systems.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this laboratory course you will perform electrophysiological experiments in which signals from living neurons (action potentials, local field potentials, post synaptic potentials) are recorded using amplifiers and data logging equipment commonly found in advanced research labs around the world. You will learn to analyze and interpret the signals that you record and learn to use chemical compounds to alter neural activity. Once a basic understanding of neural recording is achieved, you will reproduce classic neuroscience experiments, such as synaptic depression in Aplysia neurons. The experience of this class will help you appreciate the complexity of the brain and will help neuroscience textbook material that you have covered in other classes come to life. Prerequisites: NEUROSCI 202-0 and NEUROSCI 206-0.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Students must obtain a permission number from the department after meeting with Instructor.
Prerequisities: NEUROSCI 202-0 and NEUROSCI 206-0.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
1. Use a patch clamp amplifier, stimulating amplifier and pClamp software (the most common software found in electrophysiology laboratories around the world) for recording and stimulating from neural systems.
2. Independently set up neural recordings and perform electrophysiology experiments.
3. Analyze neural recording data using computer software (Clampfit and Matlab).
4. Design experiments and collect data guided by statistical principles such that a specific hypothesis can be accepted or rejected with statistical confidence.
5. Effectively communicate experimental methods and results to a group of peers.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Laboratory

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
100 points total
6 lab reports x 10 points each 60 points
Class participation 25 points
Class project 15 points

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: National Brand Computation Notebook, 4 x 4 Quad, Brown, Green paper, 11.75 x 9.25 inches, 75 Sheets (43648), Amazon: $11.41 REQUIRED FOR THE FIRST CLASS!

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Must gain consent of the instructor to register.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Every day we experience our environment by sensing a combination of light (vision), pressure wave (hearing), chemical (taste, smell), and tactile (touch and pain) signals. Our nervous system is able to integrate and react to an ever-changing environment because of the existence of very specialized sensory cells throughout the body that detect external stimuli. Signals are then relayed to the brain where they allow us to perceive, interpret, and respond to sights, sounds, tastes, smells, touch, and pain. This course will provide an in-depth look at five major sensory systems: visual, auditory, gustatory, olfactory, and somatosensory, including their peripheral receptors and the central pathways leading to perception of the cues mentioned above.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: NEUROSCI 202-0; or BIOL_SCI 302-0 or BIOL_SCI 311-0.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. To acquire in-depth knowledge of key concepts and neural pathways involved in the sensations of touch, pain, taste, hearing, vision, and olfaction (smell).
2. To develop the ability to critically evaluate scientific evidence presented in published scientific literature the field of sensory neurobiology.
3. To be able to interpret and explain scientific evidence for mechanisms of sensation.
4. To understand the methods commonly used to study sensory systems.
5. To develop the ability to make effective arguments and communicate effectively orally and in writing.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How does sensory perception guide our behavior? This course will investigate how the brain processes sensory input to guide voluntary movement. The course will examine higher level of neural systems. We intend to enroll 10-15 junior and senior undergraduates for the first offering of this course. The format will include the presentation of background material, with the majority of time devoted to the review and discussion of primary literature.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This writing-intensive and discussion-based course will draw from primary literature on the neurobiology of healthy and toxic stress, individual differences in stress susceptibility and resilience, to explore biological mechanisms by which adversity can influence health and other outcomes. oral presentations and a final paper are required.

name: Topics in Neuroscience
topic: Genetic and Circuit Analysis of Motivated Behavior

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers neural circuits underlying motivated behaviors. We will examine anatomical structures and functions that provide strategies (e.g. reward vs punishment, pleasure vs pain) to set our bodies 'in motion' towards maintaining homeostasis. The course will consist of lectures, presentations by students of classical and current research articles, as well as writing a research proposal.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Instruction in writing a scientific thesis, discussion of student projects, instructor and peer feedback on thesis drafts, and continued independent research. Open only to seniors pursuing departmental honors; requires consent of the director of undergraduate studies.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: A permission number may be requested by emailing your intent to apply for honors to the Director of Undergraduate Studies in Neuroscience.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1) Improve writing in the scientific format of a thesis
2) Put the work in context for readers who are scientifically literate but not experts in the specific field
3) Learn from editorial comments to improve writing in a lasting way
4) Select and produce figures that communicate the science clearly and pleasingly
5) Adequately cite the literature

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The format of the course will be a 1.5-hour mixed-format evening group meeting in alternate weeks. Time will be arranged once students have registered. Many sessions will include general instruction in writing a thesis. Particularly in early classes, students will informally discuss their project with the group to help organize their thoughts. This will also prepare their student colleagues to provide peer feedback of drafts during class. In addition, students will have individual meetings with the DUS to review edits. The student will also work with their research laboratory to plan and edit the thesis.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Your final grade will be determined by agreement between your faculty research adviser and the Neuroscience DUS.
At least 3 drafts will be required at specified dates during the quarter. Students will be tasked with obtaining additional feedback from their home laboratory supervisor in a timely way.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: By the start of class in winter, students should have read background literature (typically dozens of articles) and thought about how this literature ties in to the student's work. Most reading will be student-specific related to the individual's research project. However, students may read examples of previous honors theses or published scientific articles as examples of the form of writing. Students should also arrive to the first class with a clear statement of the hypothesis (hypotheses) to be tested.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Persian 121-2 is the second quarter of a three-quarter sequence for students who have completed first-year Persian or have been placed in the course through the Placement Test. The primary goal of this course is to develop students' active and passive communication skills. Using the textbook Persian Learner (Vol. 3), students will review and practice basic grammar and vocabulary while exploring contemporary Iranian culture. Class meets three times a week and will be conducted in Persian. Students are expected to be on time, to participate actively, and to prepare outside of class, at least one hour daily. Intermediate Persian follows a communicative approach to enable students to produce natural language rooted in an understanding of culture.

Persian 121-2
In the second quarter of second-year Persian, students will learn about sports in Iran. They will also talk about sport and the social context in which sport is practiced in Iran. Chapters 8 and 9 will be covered.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Persian 121-1 or equivalent; or permission of the instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1) Broadening students' cultural knowledge of Persian by engaging with natural linguistic products such as daily conversations, texts (pieces of news, social media, and, by the end of the year, literary texts), films, and music videos;
2) Conversing in colloquial Persian;
3) Expanding students' vocabulary and knowledge of grammatical rules to be able to produce natural (both formal and informal) linguistic utterances;
4) Developing writing skills by working on a writing portfolio.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Following the communicative approach, grammatical structures and vocabulary are practiced throughout the course in context. This is an interactive course, and students are expected to come to class prepared to be able to participate in class actively.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class Participation; Homework; Four Tests; Writing Portfolio; Collaborative Presentation; and Oral Interview.

name: First-Year Seminar in Philosophy
topic: Promises and Pitfalls of Social Networks Online

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course we will explore the promise and pitfalls of social media. On the positive side, they enable us to stay in touch with our friends and loved ones, they help us to connect to others in our social networks (for work as well as for pleasure), the make it possible for us to coordinate with others in real time, and they enable us to engage in large-scale collective action as never before. But - on the negative - they contribute to the degradation of our political discourse, they enhance polarization and groupthink, they reinforce superficial values, they contribute to a lack of long-term focus, and they enable very destructive forms of public shaming. What, then, should we think of social media?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Freshman standing

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: In this course the focus will be on reading and writing skills, as well as public speaking skills. By the end of the course students will be expected (1) to be able to read argument-based texts and reproduce the arguments they present, (2) to evaluate critically the arguments we will examining - and so to have thoughtful thinks to say about the promise and pitfalls of social media, (3) to be able to express and defend these things in writing and in speech, with particular attention paid to written work.

descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We will discuss a range of classic philosophical texts, presenting different kinds of realism or idealism (in metaphysics, politics, ethics). We will consider questions such as: what does it mean to be an "idealist" or a "realist"? is mind or matter, both or neither the truly real? What would it mean to claim that the world does not (really) exist? Why would it be an insult - or not - to be called a political "idealist"? Or: if you are a criminal in virtual reality, are your crimes real, or not?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: first-year students only (is a first-year seminar)

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
* To gain a sense of the wide range of meaning of central philosophical terms, in this case "ideal" and "real,"
* To understand some foundational philosophical debates
* To gain familiarity with some classic philosophical texts
* To be introduced to practices of philosophical interpretation and argument

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class is an introduction to existentialism through a study of five of its principal philosophical sources: Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Sartre and Simone Weil. We will focus on existentialist theories of value. With respect to this problem, we will explore existentialist conceptions of absurdity, alienation, anxiety, and authenticity.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students are expected to learn not only that they are certainly going to die, but that death is their own most existential possibility. The main objective of the course is for students to come to understand why it is only through an impassioned freedom-towards-death [Freiheit zum Tode] that Dasein is released from ensnarement in the conformist illusions of the 'they,' particularly illusions about the existence and validity of measurable learning objectives in the humanities.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this class, we will focus on the foundations of critical theory in the works of Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud, paying particular attention to their understanding of the origins and explanation of inequality, domination, morality, good and evil, "ressentiment", repression, guilt and shame, rights, legality, and revolution, and the opposition between justice and injustice.

Lectures will primarily involve a close analysis and discussion of the readings.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To understand the foundations of critical theory. Students will acquire a competency in a number of keywords and key concepts from Freud, Nietzsche and Marx that are commonly referred to in the humanities and social sciences.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides a broad overview of philosophical discussions of race and racism in American culture. In this overview, we will focus on phenomenological issues concerning the experience of race (especially in the US), epistemological issues concerning racial distortions and racial ignorance, and ethical and political issues concerning racial oppression. Some of the central questions that we will address are: How should we understand the concept of race and the processes of racialization through which people come to see themselves as having a racial identity? What are the different kinds of racial injustice that we can identify, and the different kinds of exclusion, subordination, marginalization and stigmatization that can be part of racial oppression? How should racial oppression be resisted? How should racial violence be stopped? How should we build racial solidarity and fight for racial justice? We will also explore the connections between race and other identity categories such as gender, sexuality, class, ethnicity, religion, and nationality.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will develop familiarity with key ideas and essential authors in philosophy of race and critical race theory. Students will also learn how to apply these ideas to American history and to contemporary cultural practices and social realities, so that they learn how to give critical attention to racial phenomena and racial problems.

name: Introduction to the Philosophy of Language

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this introduction to the philosophical study of language, we will ask questions like: What is language anyway? What is meaning? And how does the meaning carried by language vary (if it does) from the sort of meaning we attribute to natural phenomena when we say, for instance, "smoke means fire" or "those rings mean that this tree is 106 years old"? We will also touch on the role that the study of language has sometimes been thought to play in philosophical inquiry broadly, and on the connection between the philosophy of language and the empirical investigation of language in other disciplines.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will become acquainted with some of the major debates in contemporary philosophy of language. They will also develop the ability to grapple with difficult texts and ideas.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

name: Introduction to Philosophy of the Natural Sciences

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course will introduce students to deep philosophical issues raised by modern natural science of metaphysical and epistemological nature. From a reflection on methodological questions, it will approach the question of realism. We will be guided by nested "what does it take"-questions. For example: What does it take for a system of sentences to count as a good scientific theory? What does it take for a scientific theory to be testable by observational and experimental data (and, by the way: what does it take for certain series of experiences to count as data or observations?)? What does it take for a given theory to be better supported by the available evidence than its competitors? What does it take for a given theory to explain the known phenomena in an area of knowledge? What does it take for an explanatory scientific theory to be credited with reference to underlying structures of reality? We will begin with a brief overview of the scientific revolution of the 16th and 17 th century, and then turn to the treatment of certain problems in the contemporary literature, like the problem of induction, the problem of the underdetermination of theory choice by the available data, the problem of rationality and conceptual change, the problem of realism.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Having worked through the materials offered, students will:
-Be competent in the major paradigms and revolutions behind contemporary natural science
-Be able to identify, discuss and appreciate foundations of advanced scientific theories that use vocabulary referring to entities not observable by the human perceptual equipment
-Be able to conduct a formally correct argument articulating methodological and/or ontological and/or evaluative aspects of scientific work
-Have gained an appreciation of the deep reach of human factors in scientific practice (like background understandings, relevance constraints, comparative judgments) of even the natural sciences, and thereby have acquired a sophisticated concept of scientific objectivity.

descriptions.value: A study of ethical problems arising in public policy, as well as philosophical approaches to addressing these problems. Topics to be discussed include punishment, immigration, climate change, and global distributive justice.

name: The Brady Scholars Program: The Moral Life

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What does morality require of us? Does acting morally amount to consistently bringing about the best consequences that we can? Or are there other important considerations that we should take into account when thinking about how to act well? When we are trying to figure out how to act, what questions should we be asking ourselves? Drawing on both classic and contemporary readings in philosophy, as well as our own experiences, we will ask what it means to live a moral life in different spheres and situations. Do we have, or can we justify, special obligations to our friends and family? Do our professional and other roles shape what we have reason to do? How do we understand our obligations towards strangers? Is there some unified way to understand the reasons that should guide us in all of these spheres, or do they operate independently?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Admission to Brady Program

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. State the basic contours of consequentialism.
2. Explain and evaluate a range of potential problems for consequentialist views.
3. Understand some moral questions associated with beneficence, interpersonal relationships, promises, and
non-ideal theory and possible answers to these questions.
4. Discuss moral issues charitably, respectfully and productively.
5. Write a clear and well-argued short philosophical paper.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides a thorough reading of the conception of empirical knowledge laid out in the first part of Kant's "Critique of Pure Reason" (the Analytic). The seminar will also relate Kant's arguments to issues in more recent philosophical debates. E.g.: Kant qualified his philosophy as "transcendental idealism and empirical realism". According to Kant, it evades the choice between saying that we must have an conceptualized access to reality in order to have factual knowledge (so that it is hard to say how we as concept-using knowers can know reality at all) on the one hand, and saying that the reality our factual knowledge represents is determined by our concepts (so that it is hard to say in what way reality is a mind-independent constraint on belief). Kant suggests that this is a non-issue if there is only one universal set of concepts constitutive of all (genuinely fact-enabling) human experience. But the course of scientific progress since reveals this as a big (and unfulfilled) IF: in light of the diversity of experience and of the sciences, it is not easy to insist that there is only one set of forms of all possible objects of experience, one set of categories to form judgments, one set of principles to form natural laws. But the impasse confronted in Kant's epistemological analysis persists -for each of the variegated forms. Can Kant's conception of experience and empirical knowledge still help us understand how we can claim to know mind-independent reality? Another example: Much of contemporary philosophy of mind centers on the question of the relation between mind and reality. Kant criticized all such attempts at founding factual knowledge on self-knowledge (which lead into "paralogisms") or knowledge of conceptualised reality in itself (which lead to "antinomies"). His arguments compel realizing that both (reality as such and a directly present foundational 'inner' self) can't be objects of knowledge at all (=are non-objects). Does this dissolve the problems of mind and reality or rather make them cognitively insolvable?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None. First and Second year students should consult instructor before enrollment.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will become familiar with one of the classic texts of the Western philosophical tradition. They will acquire conceptual, theoretical, epistemological abilities to analyze complex dependencies between basic common sense assumptions about factual knowledge and their internal tensions. In doing so, the students' analytic, critical, but also their literary and imaginative capacities will be relied on but also expanded into previously uncharted terrain. Finally, it is hoped that students learn that and how insights in a historical text of a given tradition can matter to extremely contemporary issues (e.g. the distinction between real news and constructed pseudo-facts).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Participation in class and written work;
Writing requirements:
o Undergraduates: One midterm (+5p.) and one final paper (+10p.);
o Graduates: one final research paper (+15p.)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides a thorough reading of the conception of empirical knowledge laid out in the first part of Kant's "Critique of Pure Reason" (the Analytic). The seminar will also relate Kant's arguments to issues in more recent philosophical debates. E.g.: Kant qualified his philosophy as "transcendental idealism and empirical realism". According to Kant, it evades the choice between saying that we must have an conceptualized access to reality in order to have factual knowledge (so that it is hard to say how we as concept-using knowers can know reality at all) on the one hand, and saying that the reality our factual knowledge represents is determined by our concepts (so that it is hard to say in what way reality is a mind-independent constraint on belief). Kant suggests that this is a non-issue if there is only one universal set of concepts constitutive of all (genuinely fact-enabling) human experience. But the course of scientific progress since reveals this as a big (and unfulfilled) IF: in light of the diversity of experience and of the sciences, it is not easy to insist that there is only one set of forms of all possible objects of experience, one set of categories to form judgments, one set of principles to form natural laws. But the impasse confronted in Kant's epistemological analysis persists -for each of the variegated forms. Can Kant's conception of experience and empirical knowledge still help us understand how we can claim to know mind-independent reality? Another example: Much of contemporary philosophy of mind centers on the question of the relation between mind and reality. Kant criticized all such attempts at founding factual knowledge on self-knowledge (which lead into "paralogisms") or knowledge of conceptualised reality in itself (which lead to "antinomies"). His arguments compel realizing that both (reality as such and a directly present foundational 'inner' self) can't be objects of knowledge at all (=are non-objects). Does this dissolve the problems of mind and reality or rather make them cognitively insolvable?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None. First and Second year students should consult instructor before enrollment.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will become familiar with one of the classic texts of the Western philosophical tradition. They will acquire conceptual, theoretical, epistemological abilities to analyze complex dependencies between basic common sense assumptions about factual knowledge and their internal tensions. In doing so, the students' analytic, critical, but also their literary and imaginative capacities will be relied on but also expanded into previously uncharted terrain. Finally, it is hoped that students learn that and how insights in a historical text of a given tradition can matter to extremely contemporary issues (e.g. the distinction between real news and constructed pseudo-facts).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Participation in class and written work;
Writing requirements:
o Undergraduates: One midterm (+5p.) and one final paper (+10p.);
o Graduates: one final research paper (+15p.)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Immanuel Kant: Critique of Pure Reason, trans. Werner S.Pluhar, Indianapolis: Hackett 1996. ISBN: 978-0872202573

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course we will explore the authority of science: what, if anything, makes science authoritative, and what role, if any, it ought to play in our public lives and in our politics. Special focus will be given to the epistemological basis for the credibility of scientific results, and the need for political legitimacy of any claim that is to have authority in the public domain. How do these things relate to one another? Should scientific results be given credibility in the public domain, and if so, on what basis?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: One previous philosophy course or permission of instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: In this course the focus will be on reading and writing skills, as well as public speaking skills. By the end of the course students will be expected (1) to be able to formulate the challenges involved in advancing scientific claims in the public domain, (2) to be able to articulate and defend a position on this topic, and (3) to be able to present this position in writing.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There will be two 5-7 page papers. In addition, regular class participation will be expected.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Philip Kitcher, Science in a Democratic Society
Prometheus Books, 2011
ISBN 978-1-61614-407-4

Helen Longino, The Fate of Knowledge
Princeton University Press, 2002
ISBN 0-691-08876-4

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An exploration of philosophical problems related to health and health care. Topics to be considered include the definition and moral significance of medical concepts like health, disease, and death. We will also consider how such concepts relate to moral and political debates around access to health care and the provision of public health measures.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Students will be familiar with philosophical debates around the nature and significance of medical concepts like health, disease, and death.
2. Students will understand major philosophical theories of justice in health care and frameworks of public health ethics.
3. Students will develop proficiency in analyzing, criticizing, and crafting philosophical arguments.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two papers and a group presentation, as well as participation in class.

name: Philosophy of Art
topic: Art and Truth in Schopenhauer Nietzche and Heidegg

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, we will study three great defenders of the metaphysical theory of art in the German philosophical tradition. The first of these is Arthur Schopenhauer, who viewed aesthetic experience as a release from empirical, individuated identity. The second is Friedrich Nietzsche, who in his earlier writings characterized art as the true metaphysical activity of man, and as offering the only true justification of existence, but who eventually rejected the philosophical presuppositions of this view. And the last is Martin Heidegger, who saw art as the becoming and happening of truth. The primary focus of the class will be on the relationship between metaphysical truth and art.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Jr/Sr or instructor consent

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To better understand the tradition of philosophical reflection on art that runs from Schopenhauer to Heidegger.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Papers and weekly assignments.
Final paper.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this seminar on Kant's theoretical philosophy, we will focus on Kant's conceptions of the human capacities of thought - understanding, reason, and reflection - as well as his related conceptions of philosophical practice or method: critique and dialectic. We will investigate Kant's reasons for sharpening his distinctions among these three modes of thinking over the course of his philosophical development, and the implications of those distinctions for his criticism of the rationalist philosophy of his predecessors, and for his own developing views in epistemology and metaphysics. As this course is a proseminar, we will also work on developing aspects of graduate-level work, including oral presentation/q and a, engagement with secondary literature, and revision practices.?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Preparing for, writing, and revising a research paper in philosophy.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: seminar meetings

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No new materials.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives

descriptions.name: Teaching Method

descriptions.value: None.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Since Frantz Fanon and Simone de Beauvoir, phenomenology has developed critical approaches to race, gender and sexuality that have been put to use in liberatory projects. In this seminar we will examine the critical and liberatory potential of phenomenological analyses of race, gender and sexuality in the late 20th Century and in the 21st Century. After reading some classic texts (by Frantz Fanon and Iris Marion Young), we will focus on recent intersectional approaches in critical phenomenology and how these approaches address ethical, social and political issues such as racial and sexual discrimination, homophobia and transphobia, and mistreatment of incarcerated subjects. Key authors will include Sarah Ahmed, Linda Alcoff, Moira Gatens, Lisa Guenther, María Lugones, Mariana Ortega, Gayle Salamon, and Gail Weiss.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Mastery of essential texts and authors in critical phenomenology of race, gender and sexuality in the late 20th Century and in the 21st Century. Ability to use phenomenological analyses in discussions of ethical, social, and political issues concerning race, gender, and sexuality.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, class presentation, and research paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All readings will be made available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this seminar we will examine contemporary conceptions of democracy (pluralist, agonistic, epistocratic, lottocratic, deliberative, etc.) to see how each of them interprets the democratic ideal of self-government and how they propose, in consequence, to organize social and political institutions. We will analyze the distinctive institutional proposals that each of these conceptions offer to help address the many problems that afflict democratic societies. A central question to discuss in the seminar will be the extent to which these proposals could help societies overcome their current democratic deficits or whether they might actually add to the trend of democratic deconsolidation that we are witnessing everywhere and that threatens the future of democracy as we know it.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goals of the seminar are (1) to analyze the different contemporary conceptions of democracy, (2) to explore the conceptual tools that they provide for confronting current threats to democracy everywhere and (3) to deepen the students' understanding of contemporary debates in political philosophy while enhancing their oral debate and writing skills.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Presentations (25%), class discussion (25%) and final paper (50%)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
All required texts will be available for purchase as a course packet:

Bellamy, R., Political Constitutionalism, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007, 176-95.
Cohen, J., "Reflections on Deliberative Democracy", in Philosophy, Politics, Democracy,
Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2009, 326-47.
Estlund, D., "Beyond Fairness and Deliberation: The Epistemic Dimension of Democratic
Authority", in J. Bohman and W. Rehg, eds., Deliberative Democracy, Cambridge, MA: MIT
Press, 1997, 173-204.
Fishkin, J., When the People Speaks, Oxford University Press, 2009, 65-105.
Fung, A. "Deliberation before the Revolution," Political Theory 33/2 (2005), 397-419.
Gilens, M. and Page, B., "Testing Theories of American Politics: Elites, Interest Groups, and
Average Citizens" in Perspectives on Politics 12/3 (2014), 564-81.
Guerrero, A., "Against Elections: The Lottocratic Alternative" Philosophy & Public Affairs 42/2
(2014), 135-78.
Habermas, J., "Political Communication in Media Society - Does Democracy still enjoy an
epistemic Dimension?" in Europe. The Faltering Project, Polity Press, 2009, 138-183.
Habermas, J., "Religion in the Public Sphere", in Between Naturalism and Religion, Polity Press,
2008, 114-47.
Lafont, C., Democracy without Shortcuts. A Participatory Conception of Deliberative Democracy,
Oxford University Press, 2020, 219-42.
Landemore, H., Democratic Reason, Princeton University Press, 1-52.
Mouffe, C., "Democracy, Power, and the 'Political'", in S. Benhabib, ed., Democracy and
Difference, Princeton UP, 1996, 245-56.
Mouffe, C., "For an Agonistic Model of Democracy", in The Democratic Paradox, Verso,
2000, 80-107.
Pettit, P., Republicanism, Oxford University Press, 1997, 195-200.
Pettit, P., "Depolitizing Democracy", in S. Besson and J.L. Marti, eds., Deliberative Democracy and
its Discontents, Ashgate, 2006, 93-106.
Rawls, J., "The Idea of Public Reason", in Political Liberalism, Columbia University Press, 212-54
Schumpeter, J., Capitalism, Socialism and Democracy, Harper&Row, 1942, 250-83.
Somin, I., Democracy and Political Ignorance, Stanford University Press, 2013, 1-16.
Urbinati, N., Democracy Disfigured, Harvard University Press, 2014, 1-12, 16-21.
Urbinati, N., "Populism and the Principle of Majority" in The Oxford Handbook of Populism,
Oxford University Press, 2018, 571-589.
Waldron, J., Law and Disagreement, Oxford University Press, 1-3, 8-17, 88-118
Waldron, J., "The Core of the Case Against Judicial Review," Yale Law Journal 115/6 (2006), 1346-
1406.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, we will examine central questions in legal epistemology, with a special focus on questions at the intersection of social epistemology and criminal law. Topics may include expert witness testimony, the beyond a reasonable doubt standard, jury selection, character evidence, prejudice, and confession evidence.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly seminar participation, two 4-5 page papers, one 7-8 page presentation, and one final paper.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will examine the most fundamental ideas in physics, including those from classical physics, quantum mechanics, Einstein's relativity, chaos, complexity, nuclear physics, the latest notions in cosmology, and much more. Emphasis will be placed on how these ideas fit into a historical context. We will study the subject from the "ground up" - no prior physics education is needed. Students should be comfortable with simple algebra.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To gain a good perspective of the major ideas in physics and how they have come about over the centuries.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: One or more midterm examinations, homework, and a final examination.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Physics: A Conceptual World View (7th Edition) by Kirkpatrick & Francis
Cengage learning
ISBN: 978-0495391524

*Additional notes will be provided


Previous Editions: No, use 7th edition
Online/eBook available: Yes
Other Purchases: None

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This class is not intended for students who have taken Physics 130 or 135. It is intended for non-science majors.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
General physics course relying extensively on calculus. Focus of 125-2 will be on electro-magnetic phenomena. Similar to 135-1,2,3 but more advanced and intended for ISP students. A concurrent advanced calculus course, MATH 291-1,2,3, is offered by the mathematics department.

Coulomb's Law and electric fields, dipoles, quadrupoles; electric fields for continuous charge distributions, lines, disks, planes, image charges; electrostatic potential, point charges, multipoles, symmetry, conductors, Van de Graff generator; capacitance, dielectrics, energy and force; resistance, Drude theory and Ohm's Law, circuits, Kirchhoff's Laws; magnetic fields, Lorentz force equation; Thomson's measurement of e/m ratio, Hall effect; sources of magnetic fields, Biot-Savart Law, Ampère's Law; magnetic induction, Faraday's Law, Lenz's Law, inductance, self-inductance, superconductors and flux quantization; alternating currents, RLC circuits, resonance; Maxwell's equations (differential form), wave equation.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Class consists of three lecture hours, and one discussion hour each week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: One midterm exam, and a final exam, grading is equally weighted between weekly assigned homeworks and the two exams.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Physics for Scientists and Engineers, sixth edition, by- P.A. Tipler and G. Mosca,. Publisher-W.H. Freeman and Co.
ISBN-13: 978-1429201247


Previous Editions: Yes (no restrictions)
Online/eBook available: Yes
Other Purchases: No

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This non-calculus based course explores: charges, electric and magnetic forces, electrical potentials, batteries, circuits, capacitance, induction and inductance, and finally electromagnetic radiation. Demonstrations of many physical principles will be shown in the lecture whenever possible. Weekly quizzes emphasize problem solving. The course goals focus students on developing an understanding of the nature of the physical principles; these fundamentals govern the world around us and the universe beyond, viewed through models which draw on our everyday experiences.
Topics:
1. Charge and Matter
2. The Electric Field
3. Gauss's Law
4. Electric Potential
5. Capacitors and Dielectrics
6. Current and Resistance
7. Electromotive Forces and Circuits
8. The Magnetic Field
9. Ampere's Law
10. Faraday's Law of Induction
11. Inductors in Circuits
12. Ampere-Maxwell Law
13. Maxwell's Equations
14. The Electromagnetic Wave

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Basic knowledge of High School algebra and trigonometry and 130-1.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades for this course are based on a two 50 minute in-class midterms, a two hour comprehensive final exam, best 5 of 6 quizzes and graded online homework.

descriptions.value:
College Physics: A Strategic Approach, 4ed, Knight, Jones, & Field, Pearson 2019(!). ISBN-13: 978-0134609034


There are three main versions: 1) e-book only (no printed copy) plus Mastering Physics, 2) loose-leaf printed text + e-book + Mastering Physics, 3) hardcover text + e-book + Mastering Physics.

Online e/book: Yes
Other Purchase: scientific calculator and Mastering Physics access code

Mastering Physics:
In addition to the text, you must also purchase an access code to the "Mastering Physics" companion website (All licenses to Mastering Physics include an e-book copy of the text-so don't buy two copies of the same e-book!). I will assign graded exercises from this website, so it is essential for you to get an access code. Please note that all versions of the texts sold by Norris include access to Mastering Physics. However, you can purchase an access code directly from the publisher (and perhaps other sites?) as well: https://www.pearsonmylabandmastering.com/northamerica/masteringphysics/

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is the second quarter of a three-quarter sequence in calculus-based physics that is intended
for science and engineering majors and premedical students. 135-2 deals with electric and
magnetic phenomena. Specific topics include: Static electric fields, static magnetic fields, DC
and AC circuits, time-dependent electric and magnetic fields, Maxwell's equations.

MATH 230-0 or equivalent. Concurrent registration in the corresponding quarter of PHYSICS 136-2 (laboratory) is required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is the second quarter of a three-quarter sequence in calculus-based physics that is intended
for science and engineering majors and premedical students. 135-2 deals with electric and
magnetic phenomena. Specific topics include: Static electric fields, static magnetic fields, DC
and AC circuits, time-dependent electric and magnetic fields, Maxwell's equations.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisites: PHYSICS 135-1 or PHYSICS 125-1 or GEN ENG 205-2,3 or GEN ENG 206-2,3
or equivalent. (PHYSICS 130-1 by permission of instructor.) MATH 220-0, MATH 224-0, and
MATH 230-0 or equivalent. Concurrent registration in the corresponding quarter of PHYSICS 136-2 (laboratory) is required.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: MWF lectures, Thursday discussion section. This course will occasionally utilize aspects of a flipped classroom.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on class participation, homework, and three exams.

descriptions.value:
Text: Halliday, Resnick, and Walker's "Fundamentals of Physics" 10th Edition - EXTENDED, ISBN-13: 978-1118230725

Previous editions are allowed but the student is responsible for all transposing of problems between editions.
Other Purchases: Yes, scientific calculators (with scientific notation, logs and trig functions)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This section of Physics 135-3 section 9 is the third part of a three-course sequence in physics intended primarily for prospective physics majors and minors and other students with a special interest in physics. The course offers an introduction to fundamental topics in wave phenomena, including electromagnetic waves and their superposition, interference, and diffraction; introduction to quantum mechanics including the Bohr theory, the Schrodinger equation, the Hamiltonian, the principle of uncertainty; identical particles, bosons and fermions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Physics 140-2 is the second part of a three-course sequence in classical physics intended primarily for prospective physics majors and minors and other students with a special interest in physics. The course offers an introduction to fundamental topics in classical electrodynamics, including electric fields and potentials, circuit analysis, magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction, and Maxwell's equations. This course will be taught in an active learning style.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The course will consist of lectures as well as extensive collaborative problem solving. Thursday enrichment sessions provide students with additional exposure to the course material, as well as review of relevant mathematical principles and techniques.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on participation in class activities, reading quizzes, homework assignments, and three equally weighted exams.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Digital or physical access to course text, Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Knight 4/E. Access codes for digital access is available for purchase at www.masteringphysics.com.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Permission may be obtained from Prof. Royster, mjroyster@u.northwestern.edu

name: Mathematical Tools for the Physical Sciences

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is part two of a two-quarter sequence introducing the methods of reasoning and calculation common in the physical sciences. The goal is to learn how to calculate efficiently, accurately, and quickly, in physical contexts. Quarter 1 covers the functions of physics, dimensional analysis, small parameter expansions, complex-valued functions, vectors, simultaneous linear equations, the linear eigenvalue problem, and integration. Quarter 2 covers multiple integrals, non-Cartesian coordinates, Gaussian integrals, the Gamma function, Stirling's formula, probability distributions, constant-coefficient linear differential equations, and Fourier analysis.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: PREREQUISITES: Physics 135-1,2 Math 220, 224 and 230 (or equivalent).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: It is intended that students will gain basic competency in all the areas listed in the overview.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three 50-minute lectures weekly, homework and/or quiz assignment, reading assignments.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 1 midterm, and 1 final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None. Instructor will supply notes.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the second course in a two-quarter sequence which covers advanced classical mechanics. Topics covered in Physics 330-2 include oscillations, the Hamiltonian formalism, kinematics of rigid modes, noninertial reference frames, systems with many degrees of freedom, and scattering.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisites: PHYSICS 135-1 or the equivalent
MATH 215-0, 217-0, 221-0, or the equivalent
PHYSICS 330-1

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three one-hour lectures and a one-hour discussion per week

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Homework, one or more mid-terms, and a final examination.

Classical Mechanics, by-John R. Taylor, Publisher-University Science Books. ISBN:978-1891389221

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first of a two-quarter course on quantum theory. We will discuss both the meaning of the theory, and how to use it to calculate experimentally observable quantities for simple systems such as atoms, spins, light polarization, and tunneling systems.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: second-year standing in ISP, or PHYSICS 330-1, MATH 240/PHYSICS 311-1. A strong ability to do practical calculations with calculus and familiarity with complex numbers.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Understand and apply the concepts related to the quantum mechanical amplitude, quantum states, superposition of quantum states, observables and operators, quantum measurement, unitary time evolution, transition amplitudes and probabilities, and symmetry and conservation laws.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures and discussion section

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Homework, midterm, and final exams.

J.S. Townsend, A Modern Approach to Quantum Mechanics, 2nd Edition (University Science Books, 2012)
ISBN-13: 978-1891389788
