descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The Optics/Photonics Laboratory introduces students to a range of optical phenomena encountered in technology and research. Topics include interference and coherence, lasers, quantum and nonlinear optics, spectroscopy, optical cavities, and modern photonics devices. Students in this laboratory course obtain hands-on experience with classical and modern optical techniques, including frequency doubling, multiple types of interferometry, and the generation of entangled photon pairs.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: A suggested pre-requisite is knowledge of electromagnetism at the level of Physics 135-2, 3 or higher. The instructors will consider exceptions to this on a case-by-case basis?please contact the instructors if you are interested in taking the course have not yet taken Physics 135.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn principles of photonic systems, light propagation and interference, and advanced optical techniques. Students will develop good experimental practices and physical insight into optical phenomena through independent experimentation with research-grade optical equipment.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Eight hours of lab work per week. Students will perform several experiments throughout the quarter.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance, lab reports.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Lab notebook (available at Norris)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
We investigate three advanced topics in electricity and magnetism beyond what is covered in Physics 333-1,2.
1) Electromagnetic Radiation - accelerated charges radiate, and this is the basis for communication and
many natural phenomena. Subtle issues linking causality and the space and time domains are important to this topic.
2) Wave Optics - the wave properties of light are responsible for diffraction and interference phenomena.
The basis for these phenomena lies in electro-magnetic theory.
3) Special Relativity - in contrast to mechanics, the laws of electrodynamics are already consistent with
Einstein's theory of special relativity. This theory is explained and related to the electrodynamics in detail.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Satisfactory performance in Physics 333-1,2.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students should understand the basis of radiation, diffraction, and special relativity in advanced electricity and magnetism.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures and problem sets.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly problem sets are graded. There is one midterm and one final exam. The final grade is decided from a weighted average of these three components.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is the second of a three-quarter sequence of a graduate-level course on quantum mechanics and its applications to the microphysical world.

Topics include: The Heisenberg representation and the density matrix; the Heisenberg uncertainty relations; the minimal uncertainty wave packet; symmetry with respect to translation, rotation and time reversal; angular momentum eigenfunctions; parity; motion in a centrally symmetric field; motion in a Coulomb potential; time independent perturbation theory; time dependent perturbation theory; transition probabilities; spin.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Advanced undergraduates in physical sciences may register. Pre-requisites in linear algebra, differential equations and complex variables as well as undergraduate classical and quantum mechanics will be assumed.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Working knowledge of quantum mechanics as preparation for graduate research in physical
sciences.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first quarter of a two-quarter class on Electrodynamics. We will cover: Principles of Special Relativity and invariance. Relativistic electrodynamics as a classical field theory and action principles: for point particles, scalar fields, and vector fields, including Lagrangian formulation, principle of least action, symmetry principles, gauge invariance, the electromagnetic field tensor, covariant equations of electrodynamics and mechanics. Will close the quarter by discussing constant electromagnetic fields.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Recommended: undergraduate course at the level of Griffiths.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Understanding Classical Electrodynamics as a relativistic classical field theory. Consequences and applications, as well as related analytic and numerical techniques.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Statistical mechanics seeks to explain the link between the large-scale and the microscopic descriptions of physical systems having many degrees of freedom, such as gases, solids and liquids. This course will teach the basic concepts and skills underlying the description of systems in equilibrium using Boltzmann-Gibbs statistical mechanics, including the microscopic definition of entropy, and the development of microcanonical, canonical and grand canonical ensembles together with their connection to thermodynamics. Applications of statistical mechanics to ideal quantum and classical gases, nonideal gases, and magnetic spin systems including paramagnets and ferromagnets will be discussed.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Graduate standing in Physics and Astronomy or permission of the instructor. Some advanced undergraduates, and many graduate students in other science or engineering departments will have the necessary background.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is part 2 of a 3 quarter sequence on the theory and phenomenology of condensed matter physics. The course will cover the physics of electrons in metallic, insulating, and semiconducting materials. Concrete topics in the second quarter will include band theory, Landau Fermi-Liquids, electron transport, effects of disorder, optical properties of metals, electron transport in magnetic fields and de Haas-van Alphen / de Haas-Shubnikov oscillations.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Topics selected from the following: Path-integral formulation of field theory, renormalization, non-Abelian symmetries, spontaneous symmetry breaking, the standard model of particle physics. C, P, and CP violation. Standard model phenomenology, the parton model and deep inelastic scattering, anomalies, phase transitions, physics beyond the standard model, and non-perturbative methods.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A first-year graduate-level class that will, time permitting, cover elastic behavior in solids, fluid mechanics (normal and superfluids), liquid structure, liquid crystals, polymers, capillarity, confined liquids and liquid surfaces, Langmuir monolayers, self-assembled films, and membranes.

name: Advanced Topics in Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is a special topics course in Atomic Molecular and Optical (AMO) physics, intended to cover the background material and foundations needed to understand some current research directions in the field. Topics include the oscillator model of the atom, basic structure of alkali atoms and multi-electron atoms, interaction of radiation with atoms, optical Bloch equations, laser spectroscopy, laser cooling and trapping, cavity opto-mechanics, ion trapping, and quantum logic gates. There will be a total of 4 homework assignments for this course, distributed approximately every 2 weeks. The course will culminate with a final project, where each student will present and discuss a paper from the recent AMO literature, broadly defined, chosen in consultation with the instructor.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Physics 412-1 Graduate Quantum Mechanics-I, or consent of instructor

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1) Read, understand, and make a short oral presentation of a journal article appearing in the recent literature in Atomic-Molecular- and Optical physics.
2) Sketch the evolution of a two-level atomic system interacting with radiation on the Bloch Sphere.
3) Describe at least three types of techniques used in laser spectroscopy of atoms and molecules.
4) Explain how atoms can be trapped and cooled using light and magnetic fields
5) Describe the working principles of atomic clocks and other AMO-based sensors

descriptions.value: Slavic 108-2 is the second part in a three-quarter sequence designed to introduce students to Polish language and culture. We will continue to learn the basic grammar of Polish, building on the material acquired in first quarter. Our focus will be on speaking, reading, writing, and listening.

descriptions.value: In Winter Quarter of Second Year Polish, the students expand their speaking, reading and writing skills by building on grammar and vocabulary learned during the Fall quarter. As a complement to the linguistic side of the course, the students will gain a greater familiarity with Polish history and culture through varied means including readings of literary works, articles from contemporary Polish newspapers and movies.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What does it mean to be a citizen? Who gets to decide? The UN estimates that there are 70.8 million forcibly displaced people in the world today living precariously as refugees, asylum-seekers, stateless people or internally displaced. These numbers tell us little about why so many people are deprived of meaningful citizenship. In this class we will examine the concepts of citizenship, nationhood, and belonging and the politics of displacement by reading graphic narratives that are telling the stories of the individuals behind the statistics. Graphic novels and comics have emerged as a way for individuals to tell their personal journeys, experiences of persecution, detention, and attempts to make new lives in strange lands in their search for citizenship.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will learn to:
? summarize and evaluate arguments made by others;
? formulate persuasive arguments of their own, orally and in writing, based on the careful analysis of evidence;
? cite sources appropriately; and
? write competently to satisfy the Weinberg College writing requirement.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: PresentationsWriting assignments

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Marjane Satrapi. Persepolis. Pantheon, 2004. ISBN 9780375714573
Art Spiegelman. Maus. Pantheon, 1996. ISBN 978-0679406419
Eoin Colfer and Andrew Donkin. Illegal. Sourcebooks Jabberwocky, 2018. ISBN 978-1492662143
Thi Bui. The Best We Could Do. Abrams Comicarts, 2018. ISBN 978-1419718779
George Takei. They Called Us Enemy. Top Shelf Productions, 2019. ISBN: 9781603094504
Kate Evans. Threads from the Refugee Crisis. Verso Books, 2017. ISBN 9781786631732

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Sports and politics have become increasingly intertwined over the last half-century. Local, state, and federal governments, as well as other governing bodies (e.g., the NCAA, universities), regulate who can participate (e.g., eligibility, equality) and what standards athletes must meet (e.g., drug testing, academic performance). These organizations also oversee economic (e.g., resource distribution) and symbolic (e.g., mascots) issues. Ideally, governing policies would be responsive to the wishes of their constituents (players, owners, voters), but are they? How would we know? How do we gauge their opinions? Alternatively, how do sports affect public opinion? Do citizens prefer politicians who engage in sports? Do media portrayals of sports affect what citizens think about race and/or gender? Is it appropriate for athletes to use their notoriety to make political statements? These are the kinds of questions we will consider in this class. This involves learning the science of public opinion polling and applying it to study opinions about public policies relevant to sports

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Attendance at first class required

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All readings will be available online via the NU Library

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Technologies dependent on data science are shaping our world. We now inhabit cyberspace in our personal and public lives. Artificial intelligence and robotics are remaking work and play. Digital media frame our personal, professional and civic relationships. In this new world, data are the new oil. In this seminar, students will learn to identify some of the ethical and political challenges that these developments raise. Topics can include the inequalities of wealth set in motion by the monetization of digital behavior, automation's impact on employment, privacy concerns that follow from the growth of surveillance for commercial as well as security purposes, the impact of the personalization of news content on public discourse and the implications for the well-being of individual minds and political deliberation (and thus the integrity of elections) of the ease with which information of all sorts can circulate speedily, widely and sometimes in very precisely targeted ways. All reading is nontechnical and designed for general audiences. The course will look at general commentaries and case studies. (The instructor is not a data scientist.)

name: Introduction to Interpretive Methods in Political Science

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: From Colin Kaepernick to Confederate statues to yellow vests, political controversies often spring from competing interpretations of meaning and symbols. Political science research also involves interpretation: of data, of concepts, of ideas, and more. This course considers the many faces of interpretation in social science research. It works through examples of methodological strategies for political science students, pairing research questions with practical methods that suits the circumstance. With examples from international relations, American politics, and comparative politics, it gives students a foundation on which to formulate their own research with a well-chosen match between research methods, the questions being asked, and the subject under study.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will receive an introduction to the philosophy of science; see examples of research design in ethnography, interpretivism, sense-making, and qualitative forms; and understand the appropriate pairing of methodological approaches to empirical questions

It will acquaint students with some of the 'classics' of the field and engage these theories with contemporary cases. Topics covered include why citizens obey political authority; how the modern state developed; why some countries have advanced economies and others do not; why some countries have democratic political systems and others do not; and the United States in comparative perspective.

name: Human Rights Between East and West

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Are human rights universal or are they a Western product? Does the Universal Declaration of Human Rights represent a global consensus or an imposition by the West on the rest of the world? What are the origins of the idea of human rights? Can human rights, or similar ideas, be found in all traditions of thought? In this course, students consider the question of the universality of human rights from philosophical, political, historical, and cultural angles. They also analyze specific challenges leveled against the declared universalism of human rights from the perspective of two non-western traditions: Confucianism and Islam.

name: Political Theories of the Rule of Law

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
he phrase "rule of law" conveys a range of expectations we have of government and each other. Is the rule of law a meaningful aspiration for a legal system that is fair and ensures everyone, including government officials are equally accountable? Or is the phrase a cynical ruse on behalf of the powerful to control wealth, territory, and populations? This course will explore the origins of the concept in European political thought and compare selected theorists' descriptions of the relation between law's form and political consequences.

The course will focus substantively on the use of state violence and civil penalties in contexts of war, families, and corporations, including the university. The jurisprudence of U.S. statutory interpretation will be explored through analysis of debates about the implementation of national security and sexual harassment policies. The theoretical frameworks of Max Weber, Walter Benjamin, Franz Kafka, Carl Schmitt, Hans Kelsen, H.L.A. Hart, Lon Fuller, Jacques Derrida, Catherine MacKinnon, Jeremy Waldron, and Janet Halley will be compared for their usefulness in understanding the interpretation of contemporary laws and imagining alternatives. The purpose of this class is to introduce students to the primary texts, theories, and techniques necessary for grasping the rule of law in the United States today. Your grade will be based on assessments of one-page weekly papers analyzing a citation of your choice from the assigned texts; a class presentation; participation; and a final paper.

This class introduces students to the primary texts, theories, and techniques necessary for grasping the rule of law in the United States today. The objective is to improve basic legal literacy in the context of larger questions of political and legal theory. Skills student learn include legal research using online databases, including LexisUni, and Proquest Congressional research databases, as well as how to understand the U.S. Code and Code of Federal Regulations. Students learn these skills in the context of reflecting on larger principles of statutory interpretation - does a law mean what the plain text says, what Congress "intends," or a "purpose" imputed to law by judges?

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course takes stock of African-American politics in the decades since the Civil Rights Movement. We will explore the complex internal dynamics of Black political life, paying attention to the "who-gets-what-when-where-how" dimension of politics. As we chart the shifts in the political fortunes and policy interests of Blacks, we will focus on class, gender, and other cleavages within the population. One of our chief aims will be to consider how different segments of the population have been affected by these shifts and changing fortunes. We also will examine Blacks' relations with whites and their engagement with mainstream political institutions. In doing so, we will take up several topics that have occupied students of race and American politics since the Civil Rights Movement: party politics, racial dynamics in voting patterns, intergroup conflict and prejudice, the tension between integration and segregation, welfare and criminal justice policies, and political representation, including the election of the country's first Black president. Ultimately, the goal of the course is to shed light on the nature of American democracy by analyzing the contemporary political experiences of African Americans.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The course is designed to expose students to key concepts, theories, and methods for understanding the workings of American politics and the nature of American democracy through a close analysis of the contemporary political experiences of African Americans, their bids for democratic responsiveness, as well as redress for racial inequality.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course offers students an understanding of the U.S. Supreme Court in the American political system. We will focus primarily on the Court as an institution: the institutional processes of decision making, the powers and constraints of the court and investigate how the Court operates as both a legal and political institution, as well as its place in the larger political system. This course will also emphasize the social scientific study of the Supreme Court, involving topics such as judicial selection, the Court's agenda-setting and control of its docket, and decision making on the merits, and, on the theoretical side, jurisprudence and political ideology in decision making. We will conclude by learning about the role and doctrinal approaches of the Justices on the Court today.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will learn to:
? Assess the Supreme Court's role in the larger American political system, its place in the separation of powers, and how the political environment shapes judicial policy.
? Understand the factors that affect the judicial selection process, including the president's primary considerations when making an appointment to the Supreme Court and the major factors influencing Senate confirmation.
? Identify and explain doctrinal approaches and political ideologies in decision making
? Understand the factors that influence the justices' decision making at each stage and contribution of empirical social science to our understanding of these factors."

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The surge in the Latino/a population has brought about profound economic, educational, and political implications for states, cities and the U.S. polity. As their electoral clout continues to grow, as evidence by the 2012 and 2016 presidential elections, Latinos/as will have the opportunity to exert greater influence in the politics and policies of our country. The 2018 midterm elections proved that with the proper outreach, Latinos are interested and engaged in politics.

This course will explore these implications and the histories, including the more contemporary social and political developments of Latino communities, in the United States from a comparative framework. We will focus on the political experiences of America's three largest groups of Latino-origin: Mexican Americans, Puerto Ricans, and Cuban Americans.

The first part of the course will examine the social construction of Latino identities and trace the historical experiences of all three groups, comparing the elements behind each group's migration and how those processes affect their incorporation in mainstream society. We also examine demographic resources and the impact of immigration on the politics of the Latino collective. Next, we turn to the development of a Latino politics, placing special emphasis on political attitudes, mobilization strategies and electoral participation. Lastly, we tackle public policy issues such as voting rights and language policy.

The question that we will return to throughout the course is the degree to which and under what circumstances it is appropriate to speak of a Latino community.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisite class: any 3XX in the social sciences division
Attendance at first class required

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will learn:
- How to contextualize the politics of Latinos, how to deconstruct political identities including ideologies
- Why and which political outreach efforts work; the various modes of political incorporation efforts including the political integration of immigrants in civic society
- How foreign policy and immigration impacts the politics of different Latino/a national-origins.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course focuses on the forces shaping countries' foreign economic policies. Why do governments choose to protect some industries behind high tariff walls while leaving others exposed to the vagaries of international competition? Why do most countries rely on the U.S. dollar for their primary reserve currency - and will the dollar continue to serve that function? Why have many countries removed barriers to cross-border financial flows - and what are the social and political consequences of financial market openness? Does international trade and investment make military conflict less or more likely? Do economic sanctions even work? Have the series of economic crises over the past half-decade - the 2008 financial market meltdown in the U.S., the global credit crunch the followed, and the ongoing sovereign debt crises (in the Eurozone countries and elsewhere) - shifted the distribution of global economic and political power?

In this course we will develop an analytical toolkit to provide some insight into these and other questions, paying particular attention to evaluating the theoretical arguments with two types of evidence: qualitative and historical and quantitative and cross-national.

The course is organized thematically. We start with an introduction to the study of International Political Economy (IPE) and explore why it is distinct from international economics; following the introduction to the course we will discuss the problem of international cooperation when national economic policies have spillover effects. The next three topics (weeks 2-6) are devoted to three of the main issue areas that concern IPE specialists: the politics of the international trade, monetary, and financial systems. We then turn our attention to economic development strategies pursued by low- and middle-income countries and the role of foreign development aid in promoting growth. The last two weeks of the course are devoted to the relationship between transnational economic linkages and conflict and to the rise of new economic powerhouses (namely, China) and the possible consequences of this shift for American influence in global economic affairs.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores how the international legal system works from a legal and political perspective, shaping international relations today. At its core, international law is an idea about how to use the tools of law and legal systems to facilitate peaceful and mutually beneficial relations in the world. The course introduces some aspects of the method and substance of international law, such as concepts like sovereign immunity, jus cogens, customary international law, general principles of international law, principles of jurisdiction etc. This is not a law course; we cover legal subjects to understand how politics and law interact in shaping international relations today. Substantively, the course examines international laws related to the oceans, the environment, human rights, trade and war. We read treaties, and use case studies to see how international law is made, why national governments and national courts at times contest international law, and why international law can be difficult to enforce. We explore the legal and political issues surrounding contemporary flashpoints in international relations: China's claims to the South China Seas, how civil conflict is fueling the poaching of elephants, the United States Supreme Court's ambivalence regarding international law, how international law regarding torture is and is not politically relevant.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Attendance at first class required

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn core features of the international legal framework, including how treaties, reservations, ratification, jurisdictional issues and sovereign immunity work. Students will be able to find a country's international legal obligations. In this respect, students will learn to find and work with primary materials such as Treaties and legal decisions. Navigating ambiguity is a key skill this course teaches. Students learn to work in a structure with clear rules of the road, yet the pieces do not fully fit together. Politics becomes the art of navigation, invention, and exploiting ambiguity. This is how all legal politics works, thus we use international law to teach fundamental realities about law's ambiguity.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What makes some countries rich and others poor? Why are some states successful in forging economic development, while others are not? Are there inherent trade-offs between economic growth and democracy, or between development and stability or equality? Are there any universal models countries can apply when seeking development success? These are the sorts of questions that have motivated various analyses and perspectives on the political economy of development. This course is designed as an intensive reading seminar that will help students begin to think seriously and systematically about the most salient theories and debates from the field, with limited looks at particular cases and countries. The countries looked at will be mostly examined in the context of broader theoretical issues and arguments, rather than their intrinsic study, and will be drawn from North America, Europe, Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: From civil war to nuclear weapons, mafia thugs to oligarchs, and natural resource battles to modern-day dictators, Russia has experienced a remarkable range of political phenomena over the past two decades. This course analyzes the political, economic, and foreign policy revolutions that shook Russia after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Through the lens of the Russian experience, we will examine key concepts in comparative politics, such as revolution, regime change, market formation, nationalism, and state building. Whether you plan to professionally engage in politics, conduct international business, or simply be a well-educated global citizen, you need to know about Russia. It is the world's largest country by geographic size and the ninth largest country by population. It remains one of the world's only two nuclear superpowers. It is the world's largest oil producer and exporter. And it widely is considered - along with China, India, and Brazil - to be one of the world's most important emerging economies.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course approaches the study of sociological institutions-often referred to as "the rules of the game"-from a design perspective. We'll work to understand how these institutions emerge and address existing societal problems, ultimately analyzing the potential of different institutional configurations to encourage or discourage desired outcomes. We focus on both coordination-type dilemmas (e.g. how to parent, which side of the street to drive on, who provides health care) and collective-action dilemmas (e.g. how to police fishermen going over quota, farmers reining in downstream pollution). We end with a study of how institutions persist-possibly beyond their useful lifespan-such as the persistence of the intentionally inefficient ?QWERTY' keyboard, and a conversation about why it's difficult to enact policy change. The course has two overarching goals. This first is to develop a new way of approaching and analyzing social institutions. The second is to build skills in critical analysis of what we cover in the course though recursive writing.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Socrates' questioning way of life, trial and execution have captured imaginations for a very long time and in a wide variety of cultural settings. In this seminar, students will explore the "afterlife" of the story of Socrates by investigating a newly-created archive curated by the instructor of examples of appropriations of Socrates in post-WWII popular culture. This archive includes diverse treatments in various fields (journalism, visual arts, theater, film, music, political activism, fiction, marketing, education) mainly, but not exclusively, in the U.S. After first choosing a contemporary source on which to focus, students will be expected to research additional context, write a script and learn to use digital tools to produce a short essay about it. The Media and Design Studio will provide lab training sessions, equipment, and advice for the technical parts of the class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Bad News. That is what Americans are experiencing as a result of the corporate media mergers that took place in the closing years of the last century. Today there are six major companies that control much of what people read, hear and see. Those firms are AOL-Time Warner, General Electric, Walt Disney, News Corporation, Viacom/CBS, and Bertelsman. This course will examine the monetary forces that are driving the industry away from its primary mission of information. Critics contend that the drive for higher ratings, circulation and web page clicks is coming at the expense of the quality of news on television, radio, newspapers, magazines, and the Internet. Charges of Fake News combined with the ever-diminishing number of news providers is threatening democracy by limiting the number of voices that can be heard in our society.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What is corruption? How does it affect politics, economics, and the overall quality of life around the world? This course explores these and related questions. The first part of the course investigates various types of corruption - such as bribery, vote buying, and financial kickbacks - with a focus on recent examples from numerous countries. The second part of the course considers the consequences of corruption, with a particular emphasis on its impact on democracy and economic development. The final part of the course focuses on corruption's roots and examines a variety of anti-corruption policies.

The culmination of the class is a major seminar paper of 15-20 pages which will propose a change to the U.S. Constitution and evaluate its potential effects.

name: Political Research Seminar
topic: Utopia and its Dyscontents: Visions of the Future

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This political research seminar is an advanced introduction to the political and literary genre of utopias and dystopias, that is, imagined futures that are good (eu) or bad (dys) as yet may happen. The genre is an especially powerful form of political theorizing by authors (and actors) that are confronting and projecting imminent problems, prospects, or possibilities. Utopian literature goes back to Plato's Republic, but its first modern instance was Thomas More's Utopia (1516). The seminar will begin with Utopia and unfold by reading political works with tantalizing titles, among them, A New View of Society, The Communist Manifesto, We, Herland, Out of the Silent Planet, The Road to Serfdom, An American Utopia, The Uninhabitable Earth, and Utopia for Realists. Some of these texts are classics in the history of political thought, and thus invite us to think about past futures. Others are works of contemporary political critique, that force us to face our imminent possible futures.

name: Political Research Seminar
topic: Race, Place, and Space in Democratic Politics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Racial and ethnic politics in the U.S. (and elsewhere) have often been understood in terms of spatial dynamics and composition: Does local diversity heighten or soften intergroup tension? What kinds of diversity create the most challenges for governance? These kinds of questions have become even more salient under conditions of demographic change and deepening political polarization. This seminar will encourage students to critically engage with and contribute to current debates and research on the relationship between political geography and intergroup relations, especially in the U.S.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is about linear models, the major workhorses of statistics for description and prediction - and the most common quantitative methods in political science. We will use a linear models framework to discuss significance tests, graphical displays, tests of assumptions, interpretation of coefficients and interactions, and questions of causal inference. We will also work through statistical computing skills such that students can use all of the above in their own work.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides an introduction to the literature on American political behavior, highlighting foundational works as well as emerging research in areas of public opinion and political psychology (such as the formation of political identities and issue preferences) and participation and mobilization (such as theories and explanations of voter turnout). Throughout the course we attend closely to questions of measurement, methodology, and research design.

descriptions.value: No required materials

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This graduate-level seminar will explore the conditions and processes shaping social and political mobilization. We will examine major theories from the fields of sociology and political science about social movements: collective challenges to authority that aim to change society or institute structural changes in an existing state or states. We will consider competing explanations of the emergence of collective action, the conditions under which people do or do not rebel, various aspects of the strategic interaction between social movements and states, the sources of movement strategy, and the determinants of movement outcomes. We will read theoretical works and case studies on a range of social movements in both democratic and nondemocratic state settings. This examination of major analytical debates, as well as varied empirical material, aim to give students a solid foundation on which to build their own research projects.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of this course is to give students a solid background in the literature on social movements and mobilization as necessary to conduct original research in this field. Assignments are designed to assist students' professional and intellectual formation by sharpening four skills that they will use throughout their academic careers: (1) engaging in critical analysis and discussion of important readings, (2) writing research papers, (3) delivering oral presentations of information and original analysis, and (4) offering constructive comments on peers' work.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to game theory: the formal, mathematical analysis of strategic decision-making. Focused on applications in political science, this course will present theories of individual and social choice through abstractions on strategic environments ("games"). Students in this course will be able to use a variety of solution concepts to solve game theoretic problems, and will develop intuitions about how formal theory can model political interactions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The primary aim of this "post-Beauvoir" seminar is to identify and investigate some of the most significant "zones of contestation" that populate the vast array of debates and disputations in contemporary academic feminist theorizing. The approach and methodology is text interpretive, problem-oriented, and extensive in spirit rather than historical-chronological or circumscribed by the pursuit of a single, highly focused, topic. Accordingly, the syllabus is organized in "advanced survey" style, with a view toward staging pointed encounters between theories, texts, and thinkers from week to week. Depending on the problem or subject in question (e.g. feminist historical materialism; social and sexual contract; standpoint theory; intersectionality and identity knowledges; subaltern politics; masculine domination/white supremacy/heteropatriarchy; sexuality and sexual difference; global feminisms; new materialisms; feminist politics of gender), we'll place some significant "second wave" feminist works (1970s-80s) in juxtaposition with more recent contributions to the literature (1990s-present). The point of this orientation is to create a fluid, creative, and comparative interplay across feminist texts and theorists that is activated by a collective spirit of interrogation and problematizing, while at the same time resisting the presentist, progress narrative attitude that holds whatever comes later is always better and what is past is irrevocably dead (one of the common drawbacks of "wave" thinking).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This seminar focuses on the parallel development of capitalism and international economic ideas and law across time, considering empirical, political, normative and historical aspects of these developments. The goal is to understand how the forces of capitalism shape politics and law, and how politics and law enable capitalism.

The law part of this equation may not be readily apparent. Capitalism is by design a form of creative destruction. Market forces and the pursuit of profit are supposed to spur innovation and economic development that benefits all. Because capitalism operates through creative destruction, the market, trade and monetary dimensions of capitalism have always been regulated. Indeed a fundamental premise of this course is that there is no such thing as a free market; markets are always regulated. The way governments regulate markets is through law, and thus law enables capitalism in essential ways. For example, property is protected by law, which defines what counts as property (e.g. intellectual property law turns an idea into property, financial law creates balance sheet assets), and through a distribution of rights wherein property owners gain an enforceable legal right to have their property protected. In the era of globalization, law has facilitated the flow of financial capital in ways that greatly constrain governments and contribute to huge wealth inequities.

The historical part of the equation helps us better understand the political choices across time, and thus better understand how politics, technology, and culture shape the choices we make. By examining capitalism across time, we can better understand the interaction of choice and structural forces generated by capitalism (e.g. the industrial revolution, the creation of global supply chains, and the unleashing of global finance), and the changing political calculus as empire declined and democracy evolved.

The normative part of the equation will always be in the room. Our political decisions regarding how we use law to protect property and to facilitate capitalism has huge costs and consequences. The normative costs remind us that choices are encoded in capitalism through law and politics.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: As a graduate seminar, students will learn about key readings and frameworks for thinking about the relationship between capitalism and law.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The Creation of Online News in Portuguese

In this course, the students will deepen their knowledge of Portuguese language grammar and common usage as we study different discourse genres. The main goal of this course is the creation of an online Portuguese language News. For that, we will study language and persuasion from the Classical Rhetoric to Brazilian short stories and current news and advertisements. We will consider the use of the linguistic sign in the oral and written discourses as a carrier of ideology of illocutionary force.

name: Topics in Lusophone Cultures
topic: ?Where Memory Dwells?: The Memory Debate within Co

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
"Where Memory Dwells": The Memory Debate within Contemporary Latin America

This class will introduce students to the various roles that memory, as a concept, has played in twentieth and twenty-first century Latin American politics and society. To consider such roles, this class will address a range of sociopolitical contexts, such as Argentina's and Brazil's authoritarian regimes and Guatemala's civil war. At the same time, it will not be limited to instances of state-sponsored violence but will interrogate broader systems of repression to explore how memory is constructed and what its limits are. While this class will focus on a range of primary sources, it will focus primarily on feature films, novels, and sites of memory.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: For many, music serves a valuable function in everyday life. Music can serve as a mode of artistic expression, a method of relaxation, a means of influencing mood, and an avenue toward transcendence. This course will focus on the human experience of music by integrating research and theory from cognitive, social, and developmental psychology. Special attention will be given to topics such as the perception of music, the development of musical expertise and creativity, the effect of music on cognition, the emotional impact of music, and effective musical instruction.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Class time will be spent mainly in discussion but I plan on showing videos and listening to musical excerpts. We will also attend musical performances outside of class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this course is to present an overview of the field of psychology. The topics we will cover include research methods, the biology of behavior and emotion, perception, memory, thinking and problem solving, emotion, social influences on behavior, personality, and psychological disorders. A combination of class lectures, readings, and laboratory experiences will convey a sense of the foundational questions and methods of the science of psychology. Ultimately, the goal of this course is to impart an initial understanding of some fundamentals of human nature and behavior, as well as instill a deeper appreciation for the science of psychology. To this end, 10 hours of laboratory experience are required across the quarter to allow you to have first¬hand experience of the way research is conducted in psychology. Alternatively, a paper (requiring roughly the same number of hours outside of class) reviewing primary research articles in psychology may be substituted for the laboratory experience. If you are under the age of 18, you must use the paper requirement to satisfy your laboratory credit.

You may choose to take an optional final exam (which will be cumulative) on the date of the scheduled final exam (Thursday, March 19, 9am). You can use your score on this exam to replace your lowest midterm score

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce students to methods used in psychological research. Through readings, lectures, discussion, and hands-on activities (specifically the handling of a statistics program used for data collection and analyses), students will learn about the scientific approach to research designs and about the analysis and interpretation of data. They will participate in novel research projects and will write a report on each in the style used by research psychologists. Primary goals are for students to learn (1) testing hypotheses, including data collection and statistical analyses, (2) writing effectively about research plans and findings, and (3) critically evaluating psychological research done by other people.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides a broad overview of social psychology revolving around one general question: In what ways do our social relations affect who we are and how we act? In approaching this question, we will examine three basic social motives, "Belonging", "Understanding", and "Controlling", and explore how these motives influence how we explain our own and others' behaviors, how we form and change our attitudes and opinions, how we are influenced by the groups to which we belong, and what compels us to help or hurt those with whom we interact. At the end of the course, we will then discuss some ways in which the answers to these questions are relevant for addressing a variety of social problems.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Course meetings will primarily consist of multimedia lectures with as many impromptu discussions as I am able to inspire. To facilitate engagement during class, there will also be periodic "quizzes" and discussions using the classroom interaction system TopHat, so even if you don't like talking in big groups, you will still have opportunities to participate.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: This course will not feature in-class midterms in which you are tested on the material that was covered over the course of several weeks. Instead, after each class you will be assigned two short-answer questions that will be due at the beginning of the following week. You will prepare the answers to these questions using your class notes, textbook, or any other outside sources you choose. There will also be a take-home final-exam that covers all of the material in the course due during finals week.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Aronson, E., Wilson, T. D., & Sommers, S. R. (2019) Social Psychology (10th edition). New York: Pearson.


In this course, we will be using the classroom interaction software Top Hat. This software will be used to take attendance, conduct surveys, run real-time experiments, and guide discussions. This software is required material for the course and involves a modest subscription fee for use. It is designed to run in a web browser on a laptop or through an app that runs on all IOS or Android compatible smart phone or tablet. If you do not have one of these devices that you can bring to class, you can also respond by text from any cell phone. If you do not own a cell phone, an alternative will be arranged.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The goal of this course is to study how people come to be the unique individuals that they are. We will begin at the very beginning of life and learn the biological and environmental influences that help to shape people's personalities over time. We will look at the basic building blocks of temperament and how they these fundamental characteristics of children develop into the major personality characteristics of adults. We will seek to answer questions about what motivates us, how we manage our emotions internally and in social settings, and how we interact as social beings. We will also look at ways in which personality traits may be stable over time or may be susceptible to change. Finally, we will examine the relation between personality and mental health. In what ways do different personality characteristics predispose us to or protect us from the development of psychopathology? What does it mean to have a disordered personality?

In this course, we will use both a book that will serve as our primary text and additional required articles that will include research and theoretical articles. Both sources of reading will be critical for understanding this course and will not be fully covered in lectures. Class will also cover material that is not explicitly in the readings and will include examples and discussions that will be instrumental to your ability to master the material. If you do not attend class regularly, you should expect that the exams will probably be very challenging for you.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students are expected to attend lectures, participate in in-class discussions and assignments, read all of the assigned readings before coming to class, complete 4 short papers (33% of your grade), attend class and participate in discussions (2%), take a midterm exam (30%), and a final exam (35%).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How do we perceive, remember, reason, and talk about the world? This course is an introduction to cognitive psychology, covering topics such as perception, attention, memory, knowledge representation, language, reasoning, problem solving, judgment, and decision-making. Students learn to think critically about the assumptions and methods underlying research in cognition. Students achieve and overview of topics in cognition, read original empirical research papers, and participate in demonstrations of experiments.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Classes consist of lectures, in-class demonstrations, and discussion. Students learn to think critically about the assumptions and methods underlying research in cognition.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The focus of this course is human development from infancy through adolescence. Students will learn how culture and context influence the development of perception, cognition, language, identity, and social interaction. The course considers perspectives and methods in developmental research. As each new topic is introduced, students are encouraged to think critically about the assumptions and methods that underlie research on particular issues. A central goal is to help students develop an appreciation of different criteria for evaluating research and other forms of evidence. The discussion sections will allow students to consider how theory and research are relevant in specific domains and will generally focus on more applied issues.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture and discussion sections

List Price: $62.00

Tatum, B. D. (2017). "Why are all the Black kids sitting together in the cafeteria?" And other conversations about race. New York, NY: Basic Books. ISBN-13: 978-0465060689
List Price: $11.00

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
Class Attributes:
Social & Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will provide an introduction to the major categories of psychological disorders and related research findings. Goals/topics include: encouraging thoughtful and critical evaluation of the DSM system of classification; exploring etiological theories and how these theories have changed throughout recent history; considering ethical, legal, and social issues involved in the diagnosis and treatment of psychological disorders; developing critical thinking skills through the study of several controversial issues in abnormal psychology; and emphasizing the human face of psychological distress through case studies, readings, and videos.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The dominant teaching method for this course will be lecture, although discussion is also welcome. Grades will be based on three exams and three short response papers.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required Text:
Butcher, J.N., Hooley, J.M., Nock, M., & Mineka, S. (2016). Abnormal Psychology (17th ed.). Pearson.


ISBN: 9780133852059

Other assigned readings are available on the course website.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this class, students will learn about the field of clinical psychology, including its scope, range of activities, required educational/training background, and career possibilities. The course will focus mostly on the primary activities of practicing clinical psychologists: assessment, diagnosis, and treatment, but will also cover topics including research, ethics, forensics, and consultation. There will be guest lectures from people in the field, as well as regular lectures, class discussion, and analysis of case studies.

Objectives:

By the end of this course, my goal is that you will be able to:

1. Have a comprehensive understanding of the scope of the field of clinical psychology.
2. Understand the different components involved in clinical assessment and how a psychologist selects which tools to use for a given client.
3. Have a basic command of several different theoretical approaches to psychotherapy and the pros and cons of each approach.
4. Have a good command of the education and training requirements involved in clinical psychology and the best way to maximize your chance of finding and getting accepted to a good fit graduate program.
5. Write both applied and research papers about clinical intervention.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Psychology 303 (Psychopathology)

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students are expected to attend lectures, participate in in-class discussions and exercises, read all of the assigned readings before coming to class, complete 2 papers, and take a midterm (20%) and a final exam (25%). The first paper (20%) will be a clinical case analysis, and the second is a research paper (33%). Attendance will be taken in class, and you will regularly submit responses on Discussion Boards that will serve as participation in addition to answering and asking questions verbally in class (2%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Kramer, G.P, Bernstein, D.A., & Phares, V. (2019). Introduction to Clinical Psychology, 8th Ed. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN13:9781108593823

Corey, G. (2013). Case Approach to Counseling and Psychotherapy, 8th Ed. Belmont, CA: Brooks/Cole. ISBN13: 9781111841768

Please note that I have extra copies of the textbooks, particularly the Kramer text that I can loan out to reduce costs, in addition to library availability.

name: Selected Topics in Neuroscience and Psychophysiology

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers hot topics in applied psychophysiology, such as 1) brain wave codes of psychological states, voluntary control of brain waves (Neurofeedback) and autonomic responses (biofeedback) with psychological and health consequences, 2)opiate and pain mechanisms, 3) lie detection.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three hours of lecture and one hour optional discussion per week

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two large exams = 100%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Carlson, Neil R. & Birkett, M. A. Physiology of Behavior (2017). Pearson Publishers, 12th Edition
ISBN-13: 978-0205239399

Andreassi, John. (2006). Psychophysiology: Human Behaviors and Physiological Response, 5th edition. ISBN 978-0805849516

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Where does human knowledge come from? In this course we will explore the origins and development of human knowledge. We will learn about the earliest evidence of our cognitive capacities in infancy and describe what changes and what stays the same over development. This will be a class dedicated to big ideas. Through this process we will gain information critical to understanding cognition in general.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: class presentations and weekly posts on canvas (30%), leading discussion (20%) and a term paper (50%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
The text will be Developmental Cascades by Lisa Oakes and David Rakison. Oxford ISBN 978-0-190539189-3

There will be additional articles to read and these will be available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course treats central concepts in cognitive psychology and cognitive science, including conceptions of everyday objects and their matter, the identity of people, and ideas of parts and wholes.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Presentations: one class presentation of research project; Homework; Research project

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Articles and chapters available online. No required text books.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this course is to consider psychological theory, methodology, and empirical data relating to questions such as the following: What is it that makes us find beautiful people beautiful? How can evolutionary psychology explain why we find certain features beautiful? Where does evolutionary theory fail in terms of predicting perceptions of beauty? Is beauty really in the eye of the beholder? How have beauty ideals shifted over history? How are gender roles and sexual orientation related to beauty and its pursuit? Why is beauty associated with femininity? What cultural biases help those perceived as beautiful and hurt those perceived as lacking in beauty? Are beautiful people happier or more successful? In what ways are beauty standards sometimes destructive? How do cultural standards of beauty affect disorders such as anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and body dysmorphic disorder?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: The only per-requisite for this class is Introduction to Psychology (Psych 110).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The teaching method will be a combination of lecture, class discussions, student presentations, and in-class activities/demonstrations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grading will be based on two exams, three short papers, and a final (group) research project and presentation

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There is no textbook required for this course.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: All readings can be downloaded from Canvas at no charge. You must be present for the final exam (as that will be the date of student presentations of research projects).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Lots of people have beliefs that other people think are just plain weird. Why do people have these beliefs? We'll look at "weird" beliefs within our culture as well as some cross-cultural examples, and try to understand what leads people to develop and maintain these beliefs. Another issue is that one person's "weird" belief may be another person's firmly held conviction. From this perspective, we'll also try to understand which beliefs are rational. Among the topics we may cover are: superstition, parapsychology, conspiracy theories, ghosts, witchcraft, alien abduction, evolution vs. creationism, and repressed memories of abuse. Students will use a wide variety of academic and popular media resources (including empirical research articles, ethnographic descriptions, philosophical arguments, popular press books, and documentary films) to explore the bases for these beliefs and practices.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Primarily discussion supplemented with videos and some brief lectures.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on weekly written assignments, an independent research paper (~10 pages), and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
In addition to the required books, we will have articles and chapters from a variety of other sources that will be available through the Canvas course management system. The required books are most likely to be:
1. Clancy, S.A. (2005). Abducted: How people come to believe they were kidnapped by aliens. Harvard University Press. ISBN: 0-674-01879-6
2. Gilovich, T. (1991). How we know what isn't so: The fallibility of human reason in everyday life. Free Press. ISBN: 0-02-911706-2
3. Merlan, A. (2019). Republic of lies: American conspiracy theorists and their surprising rise to power. Metropolitan Books. ISBN: 978-1250159052
4. Miller, K.R. (2008). Only a theory: Evolution and the battle for America's soul. Viking Press. ISBN: 978-0143115663
5. Sagan, C. (1996). The demon-haunted world. Ballantine Books. ISBN: 0-345-40946-9
6. Shermer, M. (2011). The believing brain. New York: Henry Holt. ISBN: 978-0-8050-9125-0
7. Wiseman, R. (2010). Paranormality: Why we see what isn't there. ISBN: 978-0-9568756-5-5

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a seminar on the cognitive, motivational, social, and cultural processes that lead to the phenomena and processes associated with one's beliefs about members of social groups (stereotypes), attitudes and evaluative responses toward group members (prejudice), and behaviors toward members of a social group based on their group membership (discrimination). The coverage will emphasize contemporary forms of racial bias in the United States and their psychological underpinnings and social consequences.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Participation and a Final Paper

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Mostly primary source research articles.

name: Advanced Seminar in Personality, Clinical, or Social Psychology

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Over the past 15 years, psychologists of many different persuasions have turned their attention to the psychology of life stories, collecting narrative data from research participants and explicitly conceptualizing human experience as a story that is told and lived. This discussion-based and research-oriented seminar considers the different ways that personality, developmental, clinical, cognitive, and cultural psychologists examine the stories people tell about the most important events in their lives. Topics of interest include the evolution of the storytelling brain, the origins of autobiographical memory, the development of self-storytelling in children and adolescents, autobiographical reasoning, narrative identity, the psychological role of master cultural narratives, stories of redemption and contamination in human lives, narrative and the life course, the role of narrative in psychotherapy, and strange cases in which people are unable or unwilling to construe their lives in narrative terms. For the research component of the course, students will collect data on life stories and learn how to code and analyze the data.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The grade for the course will be based on one midterm exam (in class), a final research paper, and in-class presentations and discussions.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There is no textbook. Readings and course materials will be provided through Canvas.

name: Advanced Seminar in Personality, Clinical, or Social Psychology

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this class, we will learn about child maltreatment and the context in which it occurs. We will consider the risk factors associated with child maltreatment from the macrosystem to the microsystem (cultural factors, historical factors, social policy, to the proximal issues that inform caregiving). We will examine the consequences of maltreatment across developmental domains and over time. Finally, we will look at prevention and intervention, taking on both clinical and policy lenses. The class will build upon Psych 205, so you will need a reasonable command of research methods to read the assigned articles and to write your research proposal.

The course will include lectures, discussions, and case studies. It is predominantly a research-focused class, but we will also look at clinical or applied issues, using the science to inform our understanding of the individual.

In this course, we will rely primarily on empirical articles, though we will also read some theoretical articles and book chapters. The readings will be dense, so be sure to allocate enough time to have a thorough understanding of the material and to be ready to discuss the articles in class.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Psych 205 is required

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Evaluation will be based on three papers: an analysis of a case study/movie related to maltreatment (30%), a policy paper on maltreatment prevention (30%), and a research proposal based on student interest (40%). There are no exams.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required. All readings will be posted on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will provide an overview of the neurobiology of emotion and emotional disorders such as depression, bipolar disorder and anxiety. The course will include discussion of contemporary theories of emotion, 21st century methods for examining the emotional brain (e.g., MRI, EEG), the circuits in the brain underlying our experience of emotion, the biological mechanisms underlying emotional disorders, the mechanisms underlying the treatment of emotional disorders, and future directions in the study of the emotional brain. The course is introductory in nature and it is not expected that students have previous courses in either neurobiology or mood disorders.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Psychology 205

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There will not be a textbook for this course. Reading materials will be research articles and book chapters that will be provided as .pdf files by the professor.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Open only to students pursuing departmental honors. They must apply for admission in spring quarter of junior year.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of the seminar is to give psychology graduate students an opportunity to get to know the faculty and their research interests. Every psychology faculty member will talk with the proseminar for one hour. In the fall quarter, the faculty from the Brain, Behavior, and Cogniton and the Cognitive areas participated, and in the winter quarter, the faculty from the Social and the Clinical and Personality areas participate. Also, three meetings are used for special presentations. In the fall, Stephan Hill from the Office of Fellowships described fellowship opportunities. In the winter, David Smith will discuss the teaching aspect of academic careers and describe the programs offered by the Searle Center for Teaching Excellence.

descriptions.value: Articles assigned
