descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Introduction to modern statistical thinking about causal inference. Topics include completely randomized experiments, confounding, the potential outcomes framework, ignorability of assignment mechanisms, observational studies, matching, propensity scores, and other quasi-experimental designs.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: STAT 320-2, STAT 350-0

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Combination of lecture and seminar.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Homework and projects.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
We will use a combination of open source materials, including books and articles. The primary text will be:

Hernán MA, Robins JM (2020). Causal Inference: What If. Boca Raton: Chapman & Hall/CRC. Available at: https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/miguel-hernan/causal-inference-book/

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is an applied regression course. We will discuss statistical estimation and inferential techniques such as least-squares, confidence intervals, and hypothesis tests, regarding both the regression parameters and the error variance. We will study the regression models by specifying what the underlying assumptions are, how to check them through diagnostics, and how to build models based on data.

Homework will be assigned weekly or biweekly (about 7 assignments). One close-book midterm exam (one double-sided formula sheet is allowed); One final group project with presentation and written report.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite or co requisite: STAT 320-2.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the class students are expected to (1) formulate statistical questions for a real life problem; (2) use visualization techniques to explore the data; (3) choose the appropriate statistical methods and justify the choice; (4) perform regression analysis using R programming; (5) describe and present the data analysis results.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Homework assignments (30%), midterm exam (40%) and final project (30%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Applied Linear Regression Models by Kutner, Nachtsheim and Neter. 4th edition (publication year 2004), ISBN: 0073014664. Amazon price as in Oct. 2019 is about $115 (new). Northwestern bookstore should have the textbook available for purchase.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: Lecture notes and R codes will be posted on canvas.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Computing: Statistical Software, R will be used to demonstrate the methodologies. Template R programs will be posted on the course web page.

name: Introduction to the Analysis of Financial Data

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goal of this course is to present an introduction to the use of statistical methods in finance. The topics to be covered include models for returns, portfolio theory, the capital asset pricing model, and the market model. The emphasis will be on understanding the basic methods of finance and using these methods to guide the statistical analysis of financial data.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Math 240 and Statistics 320-3 (or the equivalent).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: 1. Understand the nature and properties of return data used in finance 2. Develop and interpret statistical models for financial data 3. Understand the role of statistical concepts in evaluating assets 4. Use mathematical and statistical techniques to construct optimal portfolios 5. Use statistical software to analyze financial data, estimate parameters of return distributions, and to draw appropriate conclusions

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on homework assignments, an exam, and a final project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Introduction to Statistical Methods for Financial Models by T. A. Severini. CRC Press. ISBN: 978-1-138-19837-1 Price: $71.19 (Amazon)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An introduction to probability and statistics, emphasizing scientific examples and applications. Topics covered include probability spaces, random variables, expectation and variance, basic limit theorems, parameter estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis tests, linear and non-linear regression.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Ordinarily taken only by students in ISP; special permission required otherwise. Prerequisites: MATH 281-1,2,3; PHYSICS 125-1,2,3 Students may not receive credit for both 383 and any of 320-1; MATH 310-1, 383, 385; or EECS 302.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The basics of probability theory, statistical inference, and data analysis.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly homework, a midterm exam and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to theory and method in statistical inference. Topics to be covered in this course include point estimation, hypothesis testing, interval estimation, large-sample theory and Bayesian methods.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Stat 420-1 or equivalent.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on weekly homework, a take-home exam, and an in-class final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1. Statistical Inference by Casella and Berger, Duxbury. Second Edition ? ISBN-10: 0534243126 ? ISBN-13: 978-0534243128

2. Mathematical Statistics by Bickel and Doksum (Volume 1), Publisher: Chapman and Hall/CRC; 2 edition (April 13, 2015) ? Language: English ? ISBN-10: 1498723802 ? ISBN-13: 978-1498723800

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to the theory and practice of meta-analysis.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: A working knowledge of statistics in a scientific field. Talk with the instructor if there are questions.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The student will obtain the skills necessary to carry out a meta-analysis of effects from a systematic review of a quantitative scientific literature. More detailed objectives are supplied in class.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture/discussion/project

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class Project

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Recommended texts Cooper, H. M., Hedges, L. V., & Valentine, J. (Eds.) (2019). The Handbook of Research Synthesis and meta-analysis (3rd Edition). New York: The Russell Sage Foundation. ISBN #978-0-87154-163-5 ($99.95)

Borenstein, M., Hedges, L. V., Higgins, J. P. T., & Rothstein, H. R. (2009) . Introduction to meta-analysis. London: John Wiley. ISBN# 978-0-470-05724-7 ($55.38)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the second part of a three-quarter sequence of introduction to Swahili language and culture. The course is designed purposely to reinforce the acquisition of basic conversational Swahili through activities that enhance the four communicative skills (speaking, writing, listening and reading) that was started in the previous quarter. Through performance of cultural communicative activities, students will continue to gain an understanding of basic Swahili grammatical structures, and cultural insights about the people of East Africa.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: To enroll in the course, students must have satisfactorily completed Swahili 111-1 or the equivalent.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
i. Hinnebusch, Thomas J. and Sarah Mirza. (1998). Kiswahili: Msingi wa Kusema, Kusoma na Kuandika, 2nd Ed. Lenham, Maryland: University Press of America.
ii. Swahili-English, English-Swahili Practical Dictionary (Hippocrene Practical Dictionary) by Nicholas Awde.

descriptions.value:

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the second part of intermediate Swahili. The course builds on the foundation established in beginning Swahili courses. It is designed to enhance students' communicative skills and a deeper cultural awareness about Swahili and East Africa.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: To enroll in the course, a student is required to have satisfactorily completed the three beginning levels of Swahili (Swahili 111-1,2,3) or the equivalent.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
i) Muaka, L., & Muaka, A. (2006). Tusome Kiswahili: A Multidimensional Approach to the Teaching and Learning of Swahili as a Foreign Language. Madison, WI: NALRC Press.
ii) Swahili - English, English - Swahili Practical Dictionary (Hippocrene Practical Dictionary) by Nicholas Awde.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
First-year Turkish (Turkish 111) is a three-quarter introductory course in modern Turkish. This course aims to introduce students to the essential points of modern Turkish grammar and vocabulary to develop basic reading, writing, speaking and listening skills. The course also provides insights into modern Turkish culture through the language. With this in mind, the textbook is supplemented by additional printed and audio-visual materials provided by the instructor.

Turkish 111-2
Turkish 111-2, taught in the Winter Quarter, is the second quarter of first-year Turkish. The course builds on material learned in the first quarter by introducing additional grammar and fundamental sentence structures, by presenting new vocabulary, and by providing students ample opportunities to practice and expand all skills. We will continue to use texts and audio centered around topics in Elementary Turkish I as well as work with additional printed audio and video material provided by the instructor. The course covers Unites 7-12 in Elementary Turkish I.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Turkish 111-1 or equivalent; or instructor's consent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students completing three quarters of Turkish 111 will be able to read and comprehend simple, authentic texts on familiar topics, write informal notes and short paragraphs on topics connected to daily life, and to initiate and sustain conversations on daily-life topics with educated native speakers.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: First-year Turkish uses a communicative, proficiency-oriented approach with fully integrated audiovisual media to teach modern Turkish as a living language. The instructor will use an interactive approach in the classroom, including reading, translations, listening and conversational practice as interactive small group exercises.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
The final grade for the course will be based on the following criteria:
- Class participation and attendance,
- Homework consisting of (but not limited to) assignments from the exercises in the textbook and handouts,
- Grammar and vocabulary quizzes to determine the general level of progress in the classroom,
- One midterm and one final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Elementary Turkish: A Complete Course for Beginners. Revised Third Edition (2015). Kurtulu? Öztopçu. Kebikeç-Yay?nlar? Sanat Kitabevi. ISBN: 978-975-7981-40-4.
The two-volume textbook can be purchased online at http://www.elementaryturkish.com/buy/. Additional materials will be provided by the instructor.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Full attendance and active class participation are strongly encouraged for the successful completion of the course. In addition to regular participation in class activities, it is important to complete all your homework on time.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Second-year Turkish (Turkish 121) is a three-quarter intermediate course in modern Turkish. This course aims to continue basic Turkish grammar, and further develop reading, writing, speaking and listening skills acquired in elementary Turkish, through the use of printed and audio-visual materials. The course also provides insights into modern Turkish culture through the language.

Turkish 121-2
Turkish 121-2, taught in the Winter Quarter, is the second quarter of second-year Turkish. The course builds on material learned in the first quarter by introducing additional grammar and sentence structures, by presenting new vocabulary, and by providing students ample opportunities to practice and expand all skills. We will continue to use texts and audio centered around topics in Elementary Turkish II as well as work with additional printed audio and video material provided by the instructor. The course overs Unites 22-26 in Elementary Turkish II.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Turkish 121-1 or equivalent; or instructor's consent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students completing three quarters of Turkish 121 will be able to understand and produce passages in written Turkish of medium length, understand spoken Turkish and engage in spoken discourse of medium complexity on everyday topics.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Second-year Turkish uses a communicative, proficiency-oriented approach with fully integrated audiovisual media to teach modern Turkish as a living language. The instructor will use an interactive approach in the classroom, including reading, translations, listening and conversational practice as interactive small group exercises.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
The final grade for the course will be based on the following criteria:
- Class participation and attendance,
- Homework consisting of (but not limited to) assignments from the exercises in the textbook and handouts,
- Grammar and vocabulary quizzes to determine the general level of progress in the classroom,
- One midterm and one final exam.
